PREFACE 
    This Code constitutes a codification of the general and permanent ordinances of the City of Utica, Michigan. 
    Source materials used in the preparation of the Code were the ordinances adopted by the common council. The source of each section is included in the history note appearing in parentheses at the end thereof. The absence of such a note indicates that the section is new and was adopted for the first time with the adoption of the Code. By use of the comparative tables appearing in the back of this Code, the reader can locate any section of any ordinance included herein. 
    The chapters of the Code have been conveniently arranged in alphabetical order, and the various sections within each chapter have been catchlined to facilitate usage. Notes which tie related sections of the Code together and which refer to relevant state law have been included. A table listing the state law citations and setting forth their location within the Code is included at the back of this Code. 
Chapter and Section Numbering System 
    The chapter and section numbering system used in this Code is the same system used in many state and local government codes. Each section number consists of two parts separated by a dash. The figure before the dash refers to the chapter number, and the figure after the dash refers to the position of the section within the chapter. Thus, the second section of chapter 1 is numbered 1-2, and the first section of chapter 6 is 6-1. Under this system, each section is identified with its chapter, and at the same time new sections can be inserted in their proper place by using the decimal system for amendments. For example, if new material consisting of one section that would logically come between sections 6-1 and 6-2 is desired to be added, such new section would be numbered 6-1.5. New articles and new divisions may be included in the same way or, in the case of articles, may be placed at the end of the chapter embracing the subject, and, in the case of divisions, may be placed at the end of the article embracing the subject. The next successive number shall be assigned to the new article or division. New chapters may be included by using one of the reserved chapter numbers. Care should be taken that the alphabetical arrangement of chapters is maintained when including new chapters. 
Page Numbering System 
    The page numbering system used in this Code is a prefix system. The letters to the left of the colon are an abbreviation which represents a certain portion of the volume. The number to the right of the colon represents the number of the page in that portion. In the case of a chapter of the Code, the number to the left of the colon indicates the number of the chapter. In the case of an appendix to the Code, the letter immediately to the left of the colon indicates the letter of the appendix. The following are typical parts of codes of ordinances, which may or may not appear in this Code at this time, and their corresponding prefixes: 
CHARTERCHT:1CHARTER COMPARATIVE TABLECHTCT:1CODECD1:1CODE APPENDIXCDA:1CODE COMPARATIVE TABLESCCT:1STATE LAW REFERENCE TABLESLT:1CHARTER INDEXCHTi:1CODE INDEXCDi:1 
Indexes 
    The indexes have been prepared with the greatest of care. Each particular item has been placed under several headings, some of which are couched in lay phraseology, others in legal terminology, and still others in language generally used by local government officials and employees. There are numerous cross references within the indexes themselves which stand as guideposts to direct the user to the particular item in which the user is interested. 
Looseleaf Supplements 
    A special feature of this publication is the looseleaf system of binding and supplemental servicing of the publication. With this system, the publication will be kept up-to-date. Subsequent amendatory legislation will be properly edited, and the affected page or pages will be reprinted. These new pages will be distributed to holders of copies of the publication, with instructions for the manner of inserting the new pages and deleting the obsolete pages. 
    Keeping this publication up-to-date at all times will depend largely upon the holder of the publication. As revised pages are received, it will then become the responsibility of the holder to have the amendments inserted according to the attached instructions. It is strongly recommended by the publisher that all such amendments be inserted immediately upon receipt to avoid misplacing them and, in addition, that all deleted pages be saved and filed for historical reference purposes.

    This publication was under the direct supervision of Roger D. Merriam, Senior Code Attorney, and William B. Eddy, Editor, of the Municipal Code Corporation, Tallahassee, Florida. Credit is gratefully given to the other members of the publisher's staff for their sincere interest and able assistance throughout the project. 
    The publisher is most grateful to Ms. M. Cathrine McGrail, City Clerk, and Mr. William J. McGrail, Jr., City Attorney, for their cooperation and assistance during the progress of the work on this publication. It is hoped that their efforts and those of the publisher have resulted in a Code of Ordinances which will make the active law of the city readily accessible to all citizens and which will be a valuable tool in the day-to-day administration of the city's affairs.

PART I - CHARTER 
PREAMBLE 
    We, the People of the City of Utica, Macomb County, Michigan, formerly known as the Village of Utica, by virtue of the authority of the Constitution of the State of Michigan and the Public Acts of the Legislature of the State of Michigan duly adopted, do hereby ordain and establish this Charter for the City of Utica in order to promote, maintain and better provide for the interests and welfare of all of the People. 
FOOTNOTE(S):
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Printed in this part is the Utica City Charter, as adopted by the voters on November 4, 1997. Amendments are indicated by parenthetical history notes following amended provisions. The absence of a history note indicates that the provision remains unchanged from the original. Obvious misspellings have been corrected without notation. For stylistic purposes, a uniform system of headings, catchlines and citations to state statutes has been used. Additions for clarity are indicated by brackets. 
State Law reference- Home rule cities, MCL 117.1 et seq. (Back)
ARTICLE I. - TITLE AND BOUNDARIES 

Section 1.1. - Official title. 
    The official title shall be "The City of Utica." 
Section 1.2. - Boundaries. 
    The boundaries for the City of Utica shall be registered at the Office of the Great Seal, State of Michigan, Lansing, Michigan. 
State law reference- Boundaries and annexations, MCL 117.6 et seq. 
Section 1.3. - Wards. 
    There shall be one (1) ward in the City of Utica, which shall comprise the boundaries of the City of Utica as described in Article 1, Section 1.2 of this Charter. 
State law reference- Mandatory that charter provided for at least one ward, MCL 117.3(e). 
ARTICLE II. - ELECTIVE OFFICE 

Section 2.1. - Mayor: Qualifications and terms of office. 
    There shall be a Mayor of the City, elected by the registered electors. No person shall be elected to the office of Mayor unless he/she shall be a qualified and registered elector of the City, and shall be a resident thereof for a period of at least one (1) year prior to the date of the election at which such Mayor is elected. The term of office of the Mayor shall be for a period of two (2) years, commencing January 1 succeeding his/her election. 
State law reference- Mandatory that charter provide for a mayor, MCL 117.3(a); mandatory that charter provide for qualifications of city officers, MCL 117.3(d). 
Section 2.2. - Duties of office. 
    The Mayor shall be the chief executive officer of the City and conservator of the peace. He/She shall, by virtue of his/her office, be a member of the Common Council and shall have the right to vote on all questions and to offer resolutions, introduce ordinances and exercise all other rights, powers and privileges of a member of the said Council. He/She shall not have the right to veto. He/She shall countersign all orders drawn upon the City Treasury. He/She shall from time to time furnish information to the Council concerning the affairs of the City and of the public property belonging thereto, and see that the laws relating to the City and the ordinances and regulations of the Council are enforced. He/She shall have full power and authority to nominate appointees for all appointive offices provided for under the provisions of this Charter or which may hereafter be created and it shall be the duty of the Common Council to vote on such nominations not later than the next regular meeting of the Council after nomination is made by the Mayor. He/She shall execute, in the name of the City, all bonds and obligation issued by the City and all contracts and other documents requiring execution on behalf of the City. The Mayor shall perform such additional duties as are or may be prescribed in this Charter or by resolutions and ordinances of the City. 
State law reference- Mayor to be chief executive officer, MCL 117.3(a). 
Section 2.3. - Mayor pro tempore. 
    The Common Council at its first meeting in January following its election or as soon thereafter as it may deem it necessary, shall elect one of its members to act as Mayor Pro Tempore of the City, with full power to perform all duties of the Mayor in the event of the absence or disability of the Mayor. 
Section 2.4. - Common council: Qualifications and terms of office of members. 
    The legislative authority of the City shall be vested in the Common Council, consisting of the Mayor and six (6) members to be elected at large by the registered electors in the City. The members of the Common Council shall be qualified and registered electors of the City, and shall be residents thereof for a period of at least one (1) year prior to the date of the election at which such Council member shall have been elected. Three Common Council members shall be elected every two (2) years. The term of office of the members of Common Council shall be for a period of four (4) years commencing January 1st. 
State law reference- Mandatory that charter provide for an elected legislative body, MCL 117.3(a); mandatory that charter provide for qualifications of city officers, MCL 117.3(d). 
Section 2.5. - Regular meetings. 
    The Common Council shall meet in the Council Chambers on the second Tuesday in each month provided, however, that if any such Tuesday shall be a legal holiday, then such regular meeting shall be held at the same time and place the next secular day which is not a holiday. Common Council shall have the authority to reschedule regular meetings as they deem necessary. There shall be a written or printed journal of minutes of each session of the legislative body for keeping in the English language. 
State law reference- Mandatory that charter provide for keeping a journal in English, MCL 117.3(m). 
Section 2.6. - Special and emergency meetings. 
    Special meetings of the Common Council may be held upon the request of the Mayor or any two (2) members of Common Council, provided a good faith attempt is made to give all Common Council members at least eighteen (18) hours notice of the time and place at which such meeting shall be transacted. The business to be transacted at such special meetings shall be confined to the business proposed at the time of notice unless all members of the Council attend such meeting, in which event any business which might lawfully come before a regular meeting may be presented and acted upon. 
Section 2.7. - Quorum. 
    A majority of the members in attendance of the Common Council shall constitute a quorum of the Council for the transaction of business, but a less number may adjourn a regular meeting and compel the absent members to attend in such manner as shall be prescribed by the Common Council. 
Section 2.8. - Rules of procedure. 
    The Common Council shall prescribe rules of order governing its own proceedings, provided, however, that the rules of procedure of any preceding Common Council shall be followed until modified or amended. 
Section 2.9. - Resolutions, motions and recording of votes. 
    All proceedings of the Common Council shall be by resolution or motion except where, in accordance with the provisions of this Charter, it shall be necessary to take action by the adoption of an ordinance. The vote upon any resolution, ordinance or motion shall be taken upon roll call and entered in the Minute Book of the Common Council. The journal of minutes of any meeting shall be signed by the City Clerk, after reading and approval by the Common Council, shall be attested by the Mayor and Mayor Pro Tempore thereof. 
Section 2.10. - Reconsideration. 
    Any member of the Common Council shall have the right to reconsider their vote upon any resolution, ordinance, or action adopted by the Common Council. Any member of the Common Council may file with the City Clerk within thirty-six (36) hours after the adoption of such resolution, ordinance, or action taken by Common Council a written statement of the reasons for such reconsideration. Said adoption shall be held in abeyance until action is taken upon such reconsideration. Such reconsideration shall be acted upon by the Common Council at its next regular meeting unless a special meeting is called for that purpose. 
State law reference- Mandatory that charter provide for the manner of adopting, amending or repealing ordinances, MCL 117.3(k). 
Section 2.11. - Hearing before common council. 
    Any resident maybe heard at the Council meeting under the rules prescribed by the Common Council in accordance with the Open Meetings Act (MCL 15.261 et seq.). 
State law reference- Mandatory charter provisions, MCL 117.3(l). 
Section 2.12. - Disbursement of funds of the city. 
    No disbursement of funds of the City shall be made unless authority is granted by the appropriate action of the Common Council. 
Section 2.13. - Vote required to adopt motion, resolution or ordinance. 
    The concurring vote of at least four (4) members of the Common Council shall be required for the adoption of any motion, resolution or ordinance. 
Section 2.14. - Vacancy in elected office. 
    In the event that the office of mayor becomes vacant, the Mayor Pro Tempore shall become the mayor of the City. Common Council shall elect one of its members as Mayor Pro Tempore. Such officers will hold office until the next regular municipal election when such vacancy shall be filled under the provisions of this Charter. 
(a.)	All other Vacancies, except those caused by a recall election, shall be filled by nomination for appointment by the Mayor and confirmation by the Common Council, as in other appointive offices and such appointees shall hold office until the next regular election at which such office is to be filled under the provisions of this Charter. 
(b.)	In the event that a Common Council vacancy is not filled within ninety (90) days from the date of the vacancy, a special election shall be held to fill said vacancy for the remainder of the vacant term. Candidates shall file in the same manner as he/she would for any regular City election. 
(c.)	In the event that by reason of vacancies, the Common Council shall be reduced to less than four (4) in number, the remaining members thereof shall call a special election to fill all vacancies in the Common Council. 
State law reference- Mandatory that charter provide for ordinance adoption procedures, MCL 117.3(k). 
Section 2.15. - When common council may declare office vacated. 
    If any elected officer shall fail to subscribe to the constitutional oath of office within two (2) months of certification of the election, Common Council may declare the office vacated and shall have power to proceed to fill such vacancy as herein provided. 
Section 2.16. - Appointive officers to hold office until successors are appointed and qualified. 
    All appointed officers, unless removed under the provisions of this Charter, shall hold office until their successors have been duly appointed and have qualified. 
Section 2.17. - Property to be delivered to successor. 
    Whenever any elected officer shall resign or be removed from office, or the term for which he/she has been elected or appointed expires, he/she shall deliver over to his/her successor all books, papers, monies and effects in his/her care and custody. Any person willfully violating the provisions of this section may be prosecuted. 
ARTICLE III. - APPOINTED OFFICE 

FOOTNOTE(S):
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Mandatory that charter provide for qualifications, duties and compensation of officers, MCL 117.3(d). (Back)
Section 3.1. - General provisions of office: Creation of appointed office. 
    There shall be a City Clerk, Treasurer, Assessor and City Attorney who shall be hired pursuant to a competitive hiring process as determined by Common Council. Such appointment shall be pursuant to other Charter provisions. 
Section 3.2. - Compensation. 
    All appointed officers shall receive compensation as shall be determined by Common Council. 
Section 3.3. - Office hours. 
    All appointed officers shall be required to devote sufficient time to the official duties of the City to properly perform the same, and shall maintain such office hours as the Common Council shall determine. 
Section 3.4. - City clerk: Custodian of the seal, books and records of the city. 
    The City Clerk shall be the clerk of the meetings of the Common Council and shall be its clerk, recording all proceedings, ordinances and resolutions of the Common Council, and in the event of the absence of the City Clerk at any such meeting, the Deputy Clerk or designee of the Clerk shall perform the duties of the Clerk at such meetings. 
Section 3.5. - Certify records. 
    The City Clerk shall, when required, make and certify, under the hand and seal of the City, copies of the papers and proceedings of the matters therein contained to the same extent as the original would be. 
Section 3.6. - Power to administer oaths. 
    The City Clerk shall have authority to administer oaths and affirmations. 
Section 3.7. - Custodian of election supplies. 
    The City Clerk shall be the custodian of all ballot boxes, election supplies and equipment. 
Section 3.8. - Disposition of monies. 
    The City Clerk or his/her designee shall pay over to the City Treasurer periodically all monies received by him belonging to the City and shall account for same in whatever method generally accepted by State Law. 
Section 3.9. - City clerk to receive all complaints. 
    All complaints of citizens relative to the public service shall be filed in the office of the City Clerk and referred to the proper department for investigation and report, and upon receiving such report it shall be the duty of the City Clerk to advise the citizen making such complaint of the report so made. The City Clerk in receiving any complaint may require that such complaint be made in writing and subscribed by the citizen offering the same. 
Section 3.10. - City clerk to execute contracts. 
    The City Clerk, in conjunction with the Mayor, shall execute all contracts, documents and instruments requiring execution on behalf of the City. 
Section 3.11. - Water and sewer department. 
    The City Clerk shall keep complete records of all receipts for the accounts of the Water & Sewer Systems; keep the account of all users of such water supply and sewer system; direct billings for such accounts; pay over all monies received therefrom to the Treasurer; authorize water shut off where accounts are two billings delinquent; authorize the placing of delinquent bills as a lien on property; to appear on property tax bills; and supply statistical information from such records to the Common Council, Governmental Department or Bondholders, at stated intervals or upon request, keeping a true copy thereof on file for public inspection. 
Section 3.12. - Other powers and duties. 
    The City Clerk shall have such powers and perform such other duties as may be provided by general laws of the State, and as the Common Council may by resolution or ordinance direct. 
Section 3.13. - Deputy clerk. 
    The Common Council may create the office of Deputy City Clerk, and fix the compensation therefor. Such Deputy or Deputies shall possess all the powers and authority of the City Clerk in his/her absence, and upon all other occasions, such powers as shall be delegated to such deputy or deputies by the Common Council or by the City Clerk. 
Section 3.14. - City treasurer: Powers and duties. 
    The Powers and Duties of the City Treasurer shall be as follows: 
(a.)	He/She shall receive all taxes and other monies belonging to and the receivables by the City and keep an accurate account of all receipts and expenditures thereof, on receipt of monies paid on taxes for real and personal property, he/she shall place upon the tax roll after the description of such property, the name and address of the owner of same; and shall perform such other duties with reference to the collection of taxes as are provided in this Charter. 
(b.)	He/She shall have the custody, and be accountable for, all monies, bonds, mortgages, notes, leases and evidences of value belonging to the City; and shall deposit all monies received, in a bank designated by Common Council. 
(c.)	He/She shall keep an accurate account of, and be charged with all taxes and monies appropriated, raised and received for each fund of the City. 
(d.)	He/She shall pay no money out of the treasury except in pursuance of an order of the Common Council and by authority of law, and on a warrant drafted and signed by the Treasurer and countersigned by the Mayor, which shall specify the purpose for which the amount thereof is to be paid. 
(e.)	He/She may present to the Common Council quarterly, and as often and for such period as may be required, a full and detailed account of all receipts and disbursements since the date of his/her last quarterly report, classifying them by funds to which such receipts are credited, and out of which such disbursements are made, which account shall show the exact condition of the treasury; and he/she shall file a copy of such account in the office of the City Clerk. 
(f.)	There shall be [a] system of accounts that conforms to a uniform system of accounts as required by law. 
State law reference- Mandatory charter provisions, MCL 117.3(n). 
(g.)	He/She shall perform such other duties as required by State Law.
Section 3.15. - Deputy treasurer. 
    The Common Council may create the position of Deputy Treasurer, appoint treasury support staff, and set compensation and duties. 
Section 3.16. - City assessor: Powers and duties. 
    The City Assessor shall possess all powers vested in and shall be charged with all the duties imposed upon assessing officers by State Law. In addition, he/she shall make and prepare all regular and special assessment rolls in the manner prescribed by this Charter, ordinances of the City and by State Law. 
Section 3.17. - City attorney: Creation of office, qualifications and term of office. 
    There shall be a City Attorney, who shall be nominated for appointment to such office by the Mayor pursuant to a competitive hiring process and confirmed as such by the Common Council under the provisions of this Charter. He/She shall be a practicing attorney of the State of Michigan. 
Section 3.18. - City attorney: Power and duties. 
    He/She shall superintend and conduct all of the legal business of the City for its various departments. He/She shall draft proposed resolutions and ordinances, or approve of same as to form. He/She shall draft all leases, deeds, contracts and other documents that may be required by any department of the City. He/She shall furnish upon request written opinions when subjects are submitted to him/her by the Common Council, the Mayor or any department head. He/She shall have such other powers and duties as shall be prescribed by resolution or ordinance. 
Section 3.19. - Counsel for state in city cases. 
    The City Attorney, when required by the Court or any City department, shall appear and act for the People of the State of Michigan in all cases involving violations or ordinances of the City. 
Section 3.20. - Procedure for all city cases. 
    Any officer, upon whom any process or other paper may be served in any case commenced or pending against the City, shall at once transmit such process or paper to the City Attorney, who shall thereupon inform the Common Council of the status of such suit or proceedings. Unless otherwise directed by the Common Council, the City Attorney shall appear in such suit or proceeding in behalf of the City. If a judgement or decree be entered therein, he/she may cause an appeal or other appropriate proceedings to be taken to remove the case to the appellate court, if, in his/her judgement, the interests of the City require it. 
Section 3.21. - Assistants to the city attorney and special legal counsel. 
    Upon the City Attorney's recommendation or upon it's own initiative, the Council may provide for one or more assistants to the City Attorney and may retain special legal counsel to handle any matter in which the City has an interest or to assist the City Attorney. Each appointment made as herein authorized shall be made by the Common Council with consideration given to recommendations made by the City Attorney. 
ARTICLE IV. - PUBLIC SERVICES 

Section 4.1. - Police department: Creation of office of the police chief. 
    There shall be a Police Chief who shall be hired pursuant to a competitive hiring process as determined by Common Council. Such appointment shall be pursuant to other Charter provisions. 
Section 4.2. - General powers and duties of the police chief. 
    It shall be the duty of the Police Chief to enforce the laws of the State of Michigan and the ordinances of the City of Utica, to prevent crime, apprehend criminals, promote traffic safety through enforcement of traffic laws, protect life and property, conduct criminal investigations, and work with the public to provide a safe and secure community in which to live and work. 
Section 4.3. - Members of the police department. 
    Common Council may hire such support staff as necessary to undertake the duties of the Police Department. In the absence of the Police Chief, the Police Chief shall appoint an assistant who shall perform all of the duties of the Police Chief. 
Section 4.4. - Fire department: Creation of the office of the fire chief. 
    There shall be a Fire Chief who shall be hired pursuant to a competitive hiring process as determined by Common Council. Such appointment shall be pursuant to other Charter provisions. The Fire Chief shall be responsible to the Mayor and Common Council for the functions of the Fire Department. 
Section 4.5. - General power and duties of the fire chief. 
    The Fire Chief shall be responsible for the maintenance and care of all fire apparatus, equipment, and property used by the Fire Department. The Fire Chief shall have the general supervision and control of all officers and employees of the department, including such training as necessary. 
Section 4.6. - Creation of the fire department. 
    Common Council may hire such support staff as necessary to undertake the duties of the Fire Department. 
Section 4.7. - Office of assistant fire chief. 
    The Common Council shall create the position of Assistant Fire Chief who shall be hired pursuant to a competitive hiring process as determined by Common Council. Such appointment shall be pursuant to other Charter provisions. In the absence of the Fire Chief, the assistant shall perform all the duties of the Fire Chief. 
Section 4.8. - Duties of members of the fire department. 
    It shall be the duty of members of the Fire Department to prevent and extinguish fires, protect life and property against fire, the removal of fire hazards, provide a variety of emergency services and rescue operations, provide fire inspections and investigations, and educate the public in fire safety and prevention. 
Section 4.9. - Public works: Office of public works superintendent. 
    There shall be a Public Works Superintendent, who shall be hired pursuant to the competitive hiring process as determined by Common Council. Such appointment shall be pursuant to other Charter provisions. The Public Works Superintendent shall be compensated and hold office as the Common Council shall direct. 
Section 4.10. - General powers and duties of the public works superintendent. 
    The Public Works Superintendent shall be responsible for certain matters relating to the construction, management, maintenance, and operation of the physical properties and services of the City. The Public Works Superintendent shall have the general supervision and control of all officers and employees of the department, including such training as necessary. The Public Works Superintendent shall perform such other duties as the Common Council may direct. 
Section 4.11. - Creation of the department of public works. 
    Common Council may hire such support staff as necessary to undertake the duties of the Department of Public Works. 
Section 4.12. - Duties of members of the department of public works. 
    It shall be the duty of members of the Department of Public Works to maintain and operate the streets, parks, water and sewers of the City. 
Section 4.13. - Additional department, agencies and officials. 
    The Council may create and maintain such additional administrative agencies, boards, commissions and officials as it shall deem necessary for the conduct of the administrative affairs of the City, provided, that no such administrative agencies, boards, commissions or officials shall be given any powers and duties which overlap or interfere with the powers and duties imposed upon any office or department created by this Charter. Each such administrative agency, board, commission or official shall be created by ordinance which ordinance shall conform to the provisions of this Charter relating thereto and shall clearly set forth the powers and duties thereof and the standards for the acts to be performed. Each such administrative agency, board, commission or official shall be responsible to the Mayor for the conduct of the affairs of the City entrusted to it and to the Council for the carrying out of its general policies pertaining thereto. 
ARTICLE V. - COMPENSATION AND SELF-INTEREST 

Section 5.1. - Employees and departments: Employees of department. 
    The Common Council shall designate the number of employees for each department of the City, and shall fix their respective compensations. 
Section 5.2. - Local officers compensation commission. 
    The Commission shall consist of five (5) members appointed by the Mayor subject to confirmation by a majority of the members of the Common Council for a term of five (5) years. Members shall be appointed before October 1, of the year [of] appointment. Vacancies shall be filled for the remainder of the unexpired term. Commission members shall be registered electors of the City of Utica. The Commission shall meet for not more than fifteen (15) session days in every odd-numbered year and shall make its determination within forty-five (45) calendar days of its first meeting. The Commission shall determine salaries for elective offices no later than forty-five (45) days prior to filing deadline. The Commission shall determine the salaries of all elected officials of the City of Utica, which determination shall be the salary unless the legislative body of the City of Utica, by resolution, adopted by two-thirds (2/3) of the members of elected, reject same. The determination of the Commission shall be effective thirty (30) days following the filing thereof with the City Clerk unless rejected by the Common Council. A majority of the members of the Commission constitutes a quorum for conducting the business of the commission. 
State law reference- Mandatory that charter provide for compensation of officers, MCL 117.3(d); local officers compensation commission, MCL 117.5c. 
ARTICLE VI. - BUDGET AND APPROPRIATION 

FOOTNOTE(S):
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Uniform Budgeting and Accounting Act, MCL 141.421 et seq.; Revised Municipal Finance Act, MCL 141.2101 et seq. (Back)
Section 6.1. - Budget: Departmental estimates. 
    The various officers and departments of the City, created by law and under provisions of this Charter, or which may be hereafter created, shall respectively transmit to the City Clerk or whomever the Mayor and Common Council shall otherwise designate, their estimates of the amount of money necessary for each activity within their respective departments for the ensuing fiscal year. 
Section 6.2. - Budget prepared. 
    The City Clerk or whomever the Mayor and Common Council shall otherwise designate shall make up and transmit to the Common Council a tabulation of such estimates by such time as shall be determined by the Mayor and Common Council to ensure that the budget process will be completed in accordance with State Law. Said person shall also furnish a comparative statement showing the appropriations and expenditures for each department for the current and next proceeding fiscal year; a statement of the financial condition of the City; an inventory of all property owned by the City and the estimated revenue of the City for the next ensuing fiscal year, including the amount of taxes required. Said person shall also furnish such other information as the Common Council may require. 
Section 6.3. - Consideration and adoption by common council. 
    The Common Council shall consider the budget and may revise or alter the same in accordance with State Law. In no event shall the Common Council adopt a deficit budget. 
Section 6.4. - Appropriations and taxation. 
    Common Council shall adopt the budget no later than the last working day of the current fiscal year in accordance with State Law. Concurrent with the formal adoption of the budget, the Common Council shall adopt an annual appropriation ordinance for municipal purposes which shall be based on the budget as approved by the Common Council. Said ordinance shall provide for a levy of the amount necessary to be raised by taxes as allowed by State Law. Said ordinance shall provide for an annual levying and collecting of taxes in a sum, except as otherwise provided by law, not to exceed two (2) percent of the assessed value of the real and personal property in the City, subject to the Municipal Finance Act. 
Editor's note- 
The reference in Municipal Finance Act has been repealed and replaced by the Revised Municipal Finance Act (MCL 141.2101 et seq.). 
State law reference- Mandatory that charter provide for an annual appropriation of money for municipal purposes, MCL 117.3(h); mandatory that charter provide for an annual levying and collection of taxes, MCL 117.3(g). 
Section 6.5. - Budget controls and amendments. 
    The adoption of a budget shall not be construed as authority to any officer of the City to spend the money set forth in such budget unless expenditure has been authorized by the proper warrant. 
Section 6.6. - Appropriations: When exhausted. 
    It shall be unlawful for any expenditures to be made for any municipal activity after the budget appropriation has been exhausted unless and until funds therefor shall have been duly and legally provided. 
ARTICLE VII. - GENERAL OBLIGATION BONDS AND LOANS 

Section 7.1. - Borrowing money in Anticipation of the Collection of Taxes. 
    The City shall have all of the mandatory and permissive powers of borrowing under the Home Rule Cities Act, including but not limited to: 
(a.)	The City may provide for the borrowing of money on the credit of the City and issuing bonds for the borrowing of money, for any purpose within the scope of the powers of the City consistent with State Law. In case of fire, flood, or other calamity, the Common Council may borrow for the relief of the inhabitants of the City and for the preservation of municipal property, a sum not to exceed 3/8 of 1% of the assessed value of all real and personal property in the City, due in not more than five (5) years. 
(b.)	The City may borrow money and issue bonds for the borrowing of money in anticipation of the payment of special assessments, which bonds may be an obligation of the special assessment district or may be both an obligation of the special assessment district and a general obligation of the City. 
(c.)	Common Council shall have the power for the installation and connection of sewers and waterworks on and to property within the City, for assessing the cost thereof to the several properties and making the same a lien thereon, and for the borrowing of money and issuing bonds in anticipation of the collection of such special assessments. 
State law reference- Borrowing money, MCL 117.4a et seq.; Revenue Bond Act of 1933, MCL 141.101 et seq. 
ARTICLE VIII. - TAXATION 

FOOTNOTE(S):
--- (4) --- 
State Law reference- Charter to provide for annual levying and collecting of taxes, MCL 117.3(g). (Back)
Section 8.1. - Taxes: Property subject to taxation. 
    All real and personal property within the City of Utica shall be subject to taxation in accordance with the provisions of the general tax laws of the State of Michigan. The City of Utica shall levy, collect, and return state, county, and school taxes in conformance with the general laws of the state. The subjects of taxation for municipal purposes shall be the same as for state, county, and school purposes under the general law. 
State law reference- Mandatory charter provisions, MCL 117.3(f); assessments, MCL 211.10 et seq. 
Section 8.2. - Description of properly assessed. 
    In all assessments, the lands, tenements and subdivisions assessed shall be described by referring to the county property identification number, and of the name of the owner or occupant thereof, and if it said cannot be ascertained, then by such other sufficient description as the Assessor may deem proper. If by mistake or otherwise any person may be improperly designated as the owner of any lot, tenement or premises, such assessment or tax shall not for the cause be vitiated, but the same shall be a lien on such lot, tenement or premises and collected as in other cases under general tax laws of the State of Michigan. 
State law reference- Assessments, MCL 211.10 et seq. 
Section 8.3. - Notice, complaints, assessor review and delivery of rolls. 
    Notice shall be given that the assessment roll will be completed as mandated by State Law, and shall be published in accordance with State Law. Any person considering himself aggrieved by reason of any assessment, may make complaint either verbally or in writing to the Assessor, and upon sufficient cause being shown, the Assessor may alter or correct the same as to the person charged thereby, the property described therein and the estimated value thereof. The Assessor, having completed the review and correction of said assessment roll, shall present the same to the Board of Review as pursuant to State Law. 
Section 8.4. - Review of assessment roll. 
    Such assessment roll shall be reviewed by the Board of Review in accordance with the provisions of this Charter and State Law, and shall thereupon be certified by such Board and shall become the assessment of the City of Utica. 
Section 8.5. - Tax rolls. 
    Upon receipt of the assessment rolls, as confirmed, the Assessor shall prepare a tax roll upon which shall be placed the amount of taxes authorized to be assessed and collected in each year. There shall be an annual levying and collecting of taxes in a sum, except as otherwise provided by law, not to exceed two (2) percent of the assessed value of the real and personal property in the City, subject to the Municipal Finance Act. Upon completion of the tax rolls, the Assessor shall deliver the rolls together with the proper warrant issued to the City Treasurer two weeks prior to the tax due date directing him/her to collect taxes assessed. 
Section 8.6. - Special assessment taxes placed upon general roll. 
    The Common Council shall certify to the Assessor all special assessments and other special taxes which shall be placed upon the general tax roll for the current year. 
Section 8.7. - Funds. 
    All revenues raised by the general tax in the City shall be placed in the following general funds: 
(a.)	General fund to defray general expenses and liabilities of the City and carry into effect the powers herein granted in this Charter. 
(b.)	Interest and Sinking Fund to pay the bonded indebtedness of the City, if any, and the interest thereon. The Common Council shall have authority to provide two (2) separate and distinct funds for each of these items if it shall see fit to do so. 
(c.)	Contingency Fund to pay additional and unforseen expenses.
(d.)	Such other funds as the Common Council may from time to time establish.
Section 8.8. - Date payable and liability for payment. 
    All City taxes shall be due and payable on the first (1st) day in July in each year, or on such other day as required by State Law, and on that date shall become a lien on the property taxed. The owners or parties in interest to any real estate assessed hereunder shall be liable to pay such taxes and all assessments levied in accordance herewith. Owners or persons in possession of any personal property shall pay all taxes assessed thereon. 
Section 8.9. - Taxes due and notification thereof. 
    City taxes shall be due pursuant to State Law on the first (1st) day in July in each year, or such other day as required by State Law. The Treasurer shall not be required to call upon the persons named in the City tax rolls, nor to make personal demands for payment of taxes. He/She shall publish in a paper in general circulation in the City two (2) weeks prior to tax due date notice of the time when said taxes will be due for collection and penalties for late payment of the same. He/She shall mail a bill to each person named in said rolls, but in case of multiple ownership of property, only one bill need be mailed. The City Treasurer shall have the authority to assess penalties and/or fees for late or nonpayment of taxes as determined by Common Council in accordance with applicable State Law. Failure on the part of the Treasurer to publish said notice or of the owner to receive such bills shall not invalidate the taxes on said tax rolls nor release to persons or property assessed from the penalties and fees provided in this Charter in case of late payment or nonpayment of the same. 
Section 8.10. - Board of review: Creation of office and qualifications. 
    There shall be a Board of Review, consisting of three (3) members, who shall be nominated for appointment to such office by the Mayor and confirmed therein by the Common Council under the provisions of this Charter. No person shall be appointed to such office unless he shall be a qualified registered elector of the City. 
State law reference- Charter to provide for a board of review, MCL 117.3(a); board of review, MCL 211.28 et seq., 211.107. 
Section 8.11. - Term of office and compensation. 
    The term of office of the members of the Board of Review shall commence on appointment for a period of three (3) years. The members of the Board of Review shall receive such compensation as determined by Common Council. 
Section 8.12. - Members of board of review not to be holders of other public office. 
    No member of the Board of Review shall hold any other public office or employment, except that of Notary Public. 
Section 8.13. - Meetings of board of review. 
    The Board of Review shall meet in accordance with State Law, including the Open Meetings Act. 
Section 8.14. - Powers and duties. 
    The powers and duties of the Board of Review shall be in accordance with State Law and as the Common Council may by resolution or Ordinance direct. 
State law reference- Powers of board of review, MCL 211.28 et seq., 211.107. 
Section 8.15. - Bonds of the city may be accepted in payments of taxes. 
    Bonds and obligations of the City maybe accepted in the payment of either special assessment taxes or general City taxes in the manner and form prescribed by the Common Council. 
ARTICLE IX. - SPECIAL ASSESSMENTS 

Section 9.1. - Purposes of special assessments. 
    The Common Council may raise by special assessments in improvement districts established by it for the purpose of defraying the cost and expense of grading, graveling, paving and curbing all streets; for the construction of sidewalks and crosswalks; for the construction of sewers, drains, water distributing pipes and mains; house connection for sewers, drains or water distributing pipes; for the opening, widening, extending, straightening or altering of highways, streets or alleys; for installing lighting systems and all other improvements in any public highway, place or space. 
Section 9.2. - Necessity determined and special assessments collected. 
    City Council shall adopt by ordinance procedures for special assessments. 
Section 9.3. - Cost of Improvements. 
    The amount of money required to complete any public improvement shall be established by competitive bidding under the direction of the Common Council and a contract shall be entered into with the lowest responsible bidder on furnishing a bond to the City for the full performance thereof, provided nothing herein contained shall prevent the Common Council from rejection of any or all bids. 
Section 9.4. - Miscellaneous. 
    The Common Council shall cause all proceedings to be taken that are required by law, to institute any public improvement permitted under the provisions of the Charter and complete the same under its control and direction. 
ARTICLE X. - ELECTIONS 

FOOTNOTE(S):
--- (5) --- 
State Law reference- Charter to provide for time, manner and means of holding elections and the registration of electors, MCL 117.3(c); Michigan Election Law, MCL 168.1 et seq. (Back)
Section 10.1. - Elections. 
    The general Election laws of the State of Michigan and the similar or comparable, provisions of any future laws of the State and the applicable federal laws shall apply to and control all procedures relating to City elections including but not limited to qualifications of electors, establishment of precincts, verification of petitions, registration of voters and voting hours. The Clerk shall give public notice of each City election in the same manner as is referred by law for the giving of public notice of general election in the State. The City shall not be required to hold a primary election. City elections shall be nonpartisan and shall be held in November in odd-calendar years. 
State law reference- Notice of elections, MCL 168.653a; odd year municipal elections, MCL 168.641 et seq. 
Section 10.2. - Nominating petitions. 
    Each candidate for any elective office shall at the time that the statement of candidacy is filed with the City Clerk also file therewith a petition placing in nomination the name of such candidate which petition shall be signed by not less than twenty-five (25) nor more than fifty (50) qualified and registered electors of the City. Said petition shall be filed by 4 P.M. on the 12th Tuesday prior to the general election. 
State law reference- Mandatory that charter provided for nomination of elective officers by partisan or nonpartisan primary, by petition, or by convention, MCL 117.3(b); nominating petitions, MCL 168.322, 168.644f. 
Section 10.3. - Special elections. 
    Special Elections may be called by the Common Council for the submission of any question or proposition, said election to be held in compliance with State Election Laws, similar or comparable provisions with any future general law of the State and applicable federal laws. 
Section 10.4. - Recall: Who may be recalled. 
    Any elective officer of the City of Utica shall be subject to recall by the legal voters of the City. Such recall elections shall be conducted in accordance with State Law. 
State law reference- Recall, MCL 168.951 et seq. 
ARTICLE XI. - INITIATIVE AND REFERENDUM 

Section 11.1. - Ordinance initiated by petition. 
    An ordinance may be initiated by petition, or electors may petition for a referendum on an ordinance enacted by the Council where the expenditure of the general funds of the City is in amount in excess of that which it would cost to hold said referendum. 
Section 11.2. - Initiatory and referendary petitions. 
    An initiatory or referendary petition shall be signed by registered electors of the City. The minimum number of valid signatures shall be ten percent (10%) of the number of active voters registered at the last City or general election preceding the filing date of said petition. 
(a.)	The petition shall be filed with the Clerk not more than ninety (90) days after the date of the earliest signature. 
(b.)	Before circulation, all such petitions may be approved as to form by the Clerk. Petitions may be on more than one page. 
(c.)	Each signer of a petition shall sign in ink or indelible pencil and shall include the date and place of residence by street and number or by description sufficient to identify it. 
(d.)	On each petition, there shall be a sworn affidavit by the circulator thereof stating the number of signers thereto, attesting that each signature is that of the person filing, and attesting that each signature was signed in the presence of the circulator. 
(e.)	If the petition is found to contain an insufficient number of signatures of registered electors of the City or to be improper as to form or compliance with the provisions of this Charter, the person filing such petition shall be allowed ten (10) days from notification of noncompliance for the filing of supplemental petition papers. The ten (10) days shall not be part of the ninety (90) day limitation. Only one supplemental filing shall be allowed. 
(f.)	When the petition is found sufficient and proper, the Clerk shall present it [to] the Council at its next regular meeting. 
Section 11.3. - Petition procedure. 
    Upon receiving an initiatory or referendary petition from the Clerk, the Council shall within thirty (30) days either: 
(a.)	If it is an initiatory petition, adopt the ordinance as submitted in the petition or determine to submit the proposal to the electors of the City, or 
(b.)	If it is a referendary petition, repeal the ordinance to which the petition refers or determine to submit the proposal to the electors of the City. 
Section 11.4. - Submission to the electors. 
    Should the Council decide to submit the proposal to the electors, it shall be submitted at the next election in the City for any other purpose, or, in the discretion of the Council, at a special election. The result shall be determined by the majority vote of the electors voting, except in the cases where otherwise required by the Constitution or laws of the State. The Council shall approve the form of any question submitted to the electors. 
Section 11.5. - Ordinance suspended-amended. 
    The certification of the Clerk of the sufficiency of a referendary petition, which was filed with the Clerk not more than thirty (30) days after the passage of the ordinance to which the petition refers, shall automatically suspend the operation of the ordinance in question pending repeal by the Council or final determination by the electors as the case may be. An ordinance adopted by the electorate through initiatory proceedings may not be amended or repealed by the Council for a period of two (2) years after the date of the election at which it was adopted and then only by the affirmative vote of not fewer than five (5) Council Members. Should two (2) or more ordinances adopted at the same election have conflicting provisions, the one receiving the highest vote shall prevail as to those provisions. 
ARTICLE XII. - CONDEMNATION 

Section 12.1. - Condemnation, appropriation and purchase of private property. 
    Private property whether within or without the City limits, may be condemned, appropriated or purchased for public use for the purpose of opening, widening, altering or extending streets, alleys and avenues; for the construction of bridges, viaducts, grade separation, public buildings, parks, parkways, markets and marketplaces, sewers, drains and watercourses; public and detention hospitals; sewage disposal; water supply, water mains, water works; and for the protection thereof, or any lawful public use not specifically enumerated herein. 
State law reference- The Uniform Condemnation Procedures Act, MCL 213.51 et seq. 
ARTICLE XIII. - GENERAL POWERS 

Section 13.1. - General powers. 
    Unless otherwise provided or limited in this Charter, the City and its officers shall possess and be vested with any and all powers, privileges and immunities, expressed or implied, which cities are, or hereafter may be, permitted to exercise or to provide for in their charters under the Constitution and statutes of the State, including Act 279 of the Public Acts of 1909, as amended (MCL 117.1 et seq.), as fully and completely as those powers, privileges and immunities were specifically enumerated in and provided for in this Charter. In no case shall any enumeration of particular powers, privileges or immunities herein be held to be exclusive. 
ARTICLE XIV. - ORDINANCES 

FOOTNOTE(S):
--- (6) --- 
State Law reference- Mandatory that charter provide for adopting, amending, repealing and continuing city ordinances, MCL 117.3(k). (Back)
Section 14.1. - Adopting clause. 
    The adopting clause of all ordinances shall take effect upon publication, unless a later date is prescribed therein. 
Section 14.2. - Continuance of ordinances. 
    All valid ordinances of the City of Utica which are not inconsistent with this Charter, and which are in full force and effect at the time of the effective date of this Charter, shall be ordinances of the City. If any such ordinance provides for the appointment of any officers or members of any boards or commissions, such officers or members of any boards or commissions shall, after the effective date of this Charter, be appointed in accordance with the provisions of this Charter. Provisions of any ordinance which are inconsistent with this Charter are hereby repealed. 
Section 14.3. - Repeal of ordinances. 
    Any ordinance of the City of Utica may be repealed by subsequent ordinance by reference to that particular ordinance. 
Section 14.4. - Amendment of ordinances. 
    Any ordinance or section thereof may be amended by subsequent ordinance. 
Section 14.5. - Recording of ordinances. 
    The City Clerk shall provide a book to be called "The Ordinance Book of the City of Utica", wherein properly authenticated copies of the ordinances shall be contained, and it shall be the duty of the Mayor to authenticate all ordinances adopted by the Common Council. 
Section 14.6. - Publication. 
    Ordinances shall be published in a newspaper of general circulation. 
Editor's note- 
The provisions of charter  14.6 are superseded by MCL 117.3(k) in that such statute allows publication of a summary of an ordinance in lieu of the text of the ordinance, notwithstanding any charter provision. 
Section 14.7. - Judicial notice. 
    Whenever it shall be necessary to prove any of the laws, regulations or ordinances of the City of Utica or any resolution adopted by the Common Council of the City of Utica the same may read in all courts of justice and in all proceedings; first, from a record thereof kept by the City Clerk; second, from a copy of the ordinance, regulation or resolution or the record thereof certified by the City Clerk under the corporate seal of the City of Utica; third, from a volume of ordinances, regulations or resolutions purporting to have been written or printed by the authority of the Common Council. 
Editor's note- 
The provisions of Charter  14.7 are superseded by MCL 117.3(k) in that such statute allows a city to adopt an ordinance punishable by imprisonment for not more than 93 days or a fine of not more than $500.00, or both, if the violation substantially corresponds to a violation of state law that is a misdemeanor for which the maximum period of imprisonment is 93 days. 
Section 14.8. - Penalties. 
    When by the provisions of this Charter, the Common Council has authority to pass ordinances for any purpose, it may prescribe fines, penalties, forfeitures, or imprisonment not exceeding ninety (90) days, or both, in the discretion of the Court, together with court costs, for each violation of any such ordinance and may provide that the offender, on failing to pay such fine, penalty, forfeiture or court costs, may be imprisoned for any time not exceeding ninety (90) days, unless payment thereof be sooner made. Such fine, penalty or forfeiture and imprisonment for the violation of any ordinance, shall be prescribed in the ordinance and if imprisonment be adjudged in any case, the Court may, in its discretion, direct that such imprisonment shall be in the City or County jail, or in such other place of imprisonment provided by the City or general or special laws of the State of Michigan for such purpose. The Common Council may authorize the institution of a civil suit to recover fines and costs assessed for the violation of any City ordinance and recovery thereon may be had in the same manner as the collection of a debt, under the civil practice in the State of Michigan. 
Section 14.9. - Ordinance enforcement. 
    In the absence of authority for the enforcement of a particular ordinance, it shall be the duty of the Chief of Police to ensure that the terms of the ordinance are enforced. 
Section 14.10. - City jail. 
    The Common Council shall have the power to provide and maintain a City jail, and such watch or station houses as may be necessary and may provide for the confinement therein of all persons liable to imprisonment or detention under the ordinances of the City. 
ARTICLE XV. - OPERATION OF CHARTER 

Section 15.1. - Effective date of Charter. 
    The effective date of this Charter shall be January 1, 1998. 
Section 15.2. - Officials elected under former charter. 
    The Mayor, Common Council, Treasurer and Assessor under this Charter will be elected officials under the former Charter for the term of office elected under the former Charter. 
Section 15.3. - Construction of Charter. 
    This Charter shall be constructed in a manner so as to give full consideration to every section thereof, and if there shall be inconsistencies, the Common Council shall be authorized to interpret the Charter so as to give reasonable effect thereto, and if any section of this Charter shall be declared void, illegal or unconstitutional, such finding shall not invalidate the remainder of this Charter. 
Section 15.4. - Revision or amendment. 
    The procedure for revising or amending this Charter shall be in accordance with State Law. 
Section 15.5. - Vacation of the incorporation of the charter. 
    The City maybe vacated in accordance with State Law. 
ARTICLE XVI. - MISCELLANEOUS 

Section 16.1. - When certain days are Sundays or Holidays. 
    Whenever the day upon which a transaction is required to take place under the provisions of the Charter falls upon a Sunday or holiday, then such Sunday or holiday shall be excluded in computing time, and such transaction shall take place on the next business day. 
Section 16.2. - Service of process. 
    The service of any process against the City in any action pending shall be made upon the Mayor or the City Clerk. 
Section 16.3. - Fiscal year. 
    The fiscal year of the City shall commence July 1st and end June 30th. 
Section 16.4. - New powers. 
    Any new and additional powers that may be hereafter granted to cities by either the general laws of the State of Michigan or by the constitution of the State of Michigan shall be conferred upon and exercised by the City of Utica. 
Section 16.5. - Open Meetings Act. 
    All business of the Common Council shall be conducted at a public meeting held in compliance with the Open Meetings Act (MCL 15.261 et seq.). 
State law reference- Mandatory charter provisions, MCL 117.3(l). 
Section 16.6. - Freedom of Information Act. 
    All records of the municipality shall be made available to the general public in compliance with the Freedom of Information Act. 
ARTICLE XVII. - DEFINITIONS 

Section 17.1. - Definitions. 
    All words indicating the present tense are not limited to the time of the adoption of this Charter, but shall extend to and include the time of happening of any event or requirement to which a charter provision is applied. 
(a.)	City. The City of Utica. 
(b.)	Council/Common Council. The City Council of the City of Utica. 
(c.)	Freedom of Information Act. Act No. 442 of the Public Acts 1976, as amended, being sections 15.231 to 15.246 of the Michigan Compiled Laws (MCL 15.231 et seq.). 
(d.)	He/She. An individual, male or female. The masculine gender shall include the feminine, the singular shall include the plural where indicated by context. 
(e.)	Law. Applicable federal law, the Constitution and Statutes of the State of Michigan, applicable common law, and this Charter. 
(f.)	Officer. The Mayor, the members of the Council, and, as herein provided, the administrative officers, deputy administrative officers, members of city boards and commissions created by and pursuant to this Charter. 
(g.)	Open Meetings Act. Act No. 267 of Public Acts of 1976, as amended, being sections 15.261 to 15.275 of the Michigan Compiled Laws (MCL 15.261 et seq.). 
(h.)	Person. An individual, partnership, copartnership, firm, company, corporation, association, trust, estate, governmental entity or any other legal entity, or their legal representatives, agents, or assigns. This definition includes all federal, state or local government entities. 
(i.)	Printed or Printing. Reproductions by typewriting, electronic reproduction, printing, engraving, stencil duplicating, lithographing, photostating, or any similar method of reproducing or recording language. 
(j.)	Publication, Publish, or Publishing. Publication of any matter provided by law, or, where there is no applicable law, in one or more newspaper[s] of general circulation within the City and which is qualified to publish legal advertisements. 
(k.)	Reconsideration. Moving that a question shall come before Common Council again as if it had not previously been considered or acted upon. 
(l.)	Written or In Writing. Handwritten script, printing, typewriting, electronic reproduction, teletype and telegraphic communications, except in reference to signatures. 
CHARTER COMPARATIVE TABLE 
This table shows the location of amendments to the city charter. The charter was approved by the voters on November 4, 1997.
