(2)	$250.00 for the first repeat first offense.
(3)	$500.00 for a second or subsequent repeat offense.
(f)	The civil fines for a municipal civil infraction citation directing the violator to appear in court, per section 2-278, shall be as follows: 
(1)	Schedule:
a.	$100.00 for each violation, unless a higher amount was payable through the city municipal ordinance violations bureau, in which case the higher amount is payable. 
b.	$250.00 for the first repeat first offense.
c.	$500.00 for the second or subsequent repeat offense.
(2)	The court in its discretion may waive all or a portion of any civil fine for good cause shown. 
(Ord. No. 156,  12, 5-8-2007) 
Chapter 6 - ANIMALS 
FOOTNOTE(S):
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Environment, ch. 26; dead animals,  26-2; hunting wild game or birds,  46-141; animals in parks,  50-42. (Back)
State Law reference- Crimes relating to animals and birds, MCL 750.49 et seq.; authority to adopt animal control ordinances, MCL 287.290. (Back)
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 6-1. - Violations declared misdemeanor. 
    Except as otherwise provided by law or as otherwise stated in this chapter, violations of this chapter are a misdemeanor. 
Sec. 6-2. - Possession of certain animals prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to keep, maintain or have in his possession or under his control within the city any poisonous reptile or any other dangerous or carnivorous wild animal, reptile, or insects, any vicious or dangerous domesticated animal or any other animal or reptile of wild, vicious or dangerous propensities, including but not limited to: 
(1)	All poisonous animals including rear-fang snakes.
(2)	Apes; Chimpanzees (Pan); gibbons (Hylobates); gorillas (Gorilla); orangutans (Pongo); and siamangs (Symphalangus). 
(3)	Baboons (Papoi, Mandrillus).
(4)	Bears (Ursidae).
(5)	Bison (Bison).
(6)	Cheetahs (Acinonyx jubatus).
(7)	Crocodilians (Crocodilia), 30 inches in length or more.
(8)	Constrictor snakes, six feet in length or more.
(9)	Coyotes (Ganis latrans).
(10)	Deer (Cervidae); includes all members of the deer family, for example, white-tailed deer, elk, antelope and moose. 
(11)	Elephants (Elephas and Loxodonta).
(12)	Game cocks and other fighting birds.
(13)	Hippopotami (Hippopotamidae).
(14)	Hyenas (Hyaenidae).
(15)	Jaguars (Panthera onca).
(16)	Leopards (Panthera pardus).
(17)	Lions (Panthera leo).
(18)	Lynxes (Lynx).
(19)	Monkeys, old world (Cercopithecidae).
(20)	Ostriches (Struthio).
(21)	Piranha fish (Characidae).
(22)	Pumas (Felis concolor); also known as cougars, mountain lions and panthers.
(23)	Rhinoceroses (Rhinocero tidae).
(24)	Sharks (class Chondrichthyes).
(25)	Snow leopards (Panthera uncia).
(26)	Swine (Suidae).
(27)	Tigers (Panthera tigris).
(28)	Wolves (Canis lupus).
(29)	Bees (kept or housed as a colony or in a beehive).
(30)	Poisonous spiders.
(Ord. No. 104,  1, 6-12-1979) 
Secs. 6-3-6-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - DOGS 

FOOTNOTE(S):
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Dog Law of 1919, MCL 287.261 et seq. (Back)
Sec. 6-31. - Licensing. 
    No person shall keep, possess, harbor or have the care or charge of any dog, male or female, of the age of four months or over, within the city, unless such dog shall wear a collar to which is attached the license tag provided for by the Dog Law of 1919 (MCL 287.261 et seq.), provided this article shall not apply to any person transporting a dog through the city if such dog is taxed at the residence of the owner. Every person in possession of any dog or who shall permit any dog to remain on or about his premises for a period of five days or more shall, for the purposes of this article be deemed to be the owner of such dog. 
(Ord. No. 37,  1, 9-8-1959) 
State law reference- License tags, MCL 287.265 et seq. 
Sec. 6-32. - Running at large. 
(a)	No dog shall be allowed to run at large in the city unless such dog is under reasonable control and properly leashed and restrained by the person that accompanies such dog. A dog shall be deemed not to be under reasonable control when such dog commits damage to the person or property of the one other than the owner, except in defense of the owner, his family or property. Running at large is being outside of the fenced (or other means of restraint) area of the owner's property or motor vehicle. 
(b)	It shall be unlawful for an owner of a female dog to permit such female dog to go beyond the premises of such owner when she is in heat, unless such female dog is properly leashed. 
(c)	The common council, on receipt of notice from the city health officer or the county health department that dogs should be prohibited from running at large because of the possible presence of rabies in the city or adjacent thereto, shall order the clerk to publish a notice in the official newspaper entitled "Notice of Quarantine" providing for a period during which all dogs within the corporate limits of the city shall be confined to the premises of the owner. 
(d)	Twenty-four hours after the publication of such "Notice of Quarantine," it shall be the duty of the officers of the police department to shoot or otherwise kill or destroy all dogs found running at large within the limits of the city during the period named in such quarantine notice, and the common council shall make provisions for the sale, burying, carrying away, or other disposal of the bodies of all dogs that have been so destroyed. 
(Ord. No. 37,  2, 9-8-1959; Ord. No. 37B, 11-9-2005) 
Sec. 6-33. - Noise disturbances. 
    No person shall own, harbor or keep any dog, which by loud or frequent barking, yelping or howling shall cause annoyance to any of the inhabitants of the city. 
(Ord. No. 37,  3(A), 9-8-1959) 
Sec. 6-34. - Destruction of property. 
    No person shall own, harbor or keep any dog, whether licensed or unlicensed, which by destruction of property, trespassing on others property or by attacking persons becomes a nuisance in the neighborhood in which such dog is kept. 
(Ord. No. 37,  3(B), 9-8-1959) 
Sec. 6-35. - Fierce or vicious dogs; dogs afflicted with rabies. 
    No person shall own or harbor a fierce or vicious dog or a dog which has been bitten by any animal known to have been afflicted with rabies. 
(Ord. No. 37,  3(C), 9-8-1959) 
State law reference- Dangerous animals, MCL 287.321 et seq. 
Sec. 6-36. - Investigation of rabies. 
(a)	Any person who shall have possession of a dog which has contracted rabies or which has been subjected to rabies, or which is suspected of having rabies, or which has bitten any person, upon demand of any member of the police department, shall surrender up such dog to the police department to be held for observation, or confine such dog to the owner's premises at the discretion of such officer. 
(b)	It shall be the duty of any person owning or harboring a dog which has been attacked or bitten by another dog or other animal showing the symptoms of rabies to immediately notify the police department that such person has such a dog in his possession. 
(Ord. No. 37,  4, 9-8-1959) 
Sec. 6-37. - Removal of tags. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to remove any license tag, immunization tag or the collar bearing the license or immunization tag from any dog without the consent of the owner thereof, who shall be deemed responsible for any violation of this article. 
(Ord. No. 37,  5, 9-8-1959) 
Sec. 6-38. - Kennels prohibited. 
    No person shall keep, operate or maintain a dog kennel within the limits of the city. The term "dog kennel," as used in this article, means any establishment, wherein or whereon, more than one dog is owned, kept, or harbored, for the purpose of breeding, sale, or otherwise. 
(Ord. No. 37,  6, 9-8-1959) 
Sec. 6-39. - Containment of dog manure and offal. 
(a)	Every person lawfully keeping or harboring any dog shall keep or cause to be kept all manure or offal therefrom, which shall be deposited by or which accumulated from such dog, securely and closely confined to or buried upon his premises and in such manner as will prevent it from being scattered from such place of deposit into or upon any street, sidewalk, alley or gutter of the city, and shall so cover and care for it as to prevent any malodorous or offensive condition to exist and to prevent any nuisance to arise therefrom. 
(b)	A person having custody of any dog shall not permit, either willfully or through failure to exercise due care or control, such dog to commit any nuisance by defecating or urinating upon the sidewalk of any public highway or upon any building, fence or wall immediately abutting on a public sidewalk, or without the consent of the owner or person in lawful occupation thereof, any lawn, yard, or any other private property whatever, which is either improved or occupied. 
(c)	A person in possession or control of any dog shall immediately package and remove any fecal droppings of the dog deposited during this time of that person's possession or control. 
(d)	The owner of any dog, upon being notified, shall immediately package and remove any fecal droppings of the dog deposited upon any private or public property. The person listed in the dog's license application as owner shall be presumed to be the lawful owner of that dog. If no dog permit exists, the occupant or occupants of the property where the dog is kept or maintained shall be presumed to be the owner of said dog. 
(Ord. No. 37, 1-13-2004) 
Chapter 10 - BUILDINGS AND BUILDING REGULATIONS 
FOOTNOTE(S):
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Environment, ch. 26; fire prevention and protection, ch. 30; fire prevention code,  30-56 et seq.; floods, ch. 34; historic preservation, ch. 38; solid waste, ch. 54; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 62; subdivisions and other divisions of land, ch. 66; utilities, ch. 82; building sewers and connections,  82-186 et seq.; vegetation, ch. 86; zoning, app. A; zoning districts and maps, app. A,  300 et seq.; building regulations, app. A,  1401; building appearance, structure completion, and personal construction authority, app. A,  1402; nonconforming lots, nonconforming uses of land, nonconfoming structures, and nonconforming uses of structures and premises, app. A,  1403. (Back)
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 10-1. - Violations declared misdemeanor. 
    Except as otherwise provided by law or as otherwise stated in this chapter, violations of this chapter are a misdemeanor. 
Sec. 10-2. - Property maintenance code. 
    The 2000 edition of the International Property Maintenance Code as promulgated by the International Code Council, which code as previously been made a public record of the city, is hereby adopted by reference. 
(Mo. of 9-9-1998) 
State law reference- Adoption by reference, MCL 117.4(k). 
Sec. 10-3. - Registration of persons in electrical industry. 
    No person shall do any act in the city for which a license is required under the Electrical Administrative Act (MCL 338.881 et seq.) without registering with the city clerk. No such registration shall be granted unless the person holds the appropriate license under such act. 
(Ord. No. 148,  6, 4-10-2001) 
Sec. 10-4. - Changing of property grades. 
(a)	The general objective of this section is to ensure land improvements, which provide for: 
(1)	An appropriate setting for buildings;
(2)	Immediate diversion of water away from buildings and disposal of water from lot;
(3)	Suitable access from abutting streets to dwellings;
(4)	Proper grade and location with regard to existing and future public utilities and structures; 
(5)	Minimum nuisance and possible danger to the health and welfare of the city residents from unregulated fill operations. 
(b)	No person shall change, modify, create, or establish the grade of any property or building line grade of any property within the city without first obtaining a permit as required in this section. 
(c)	Prior to the issuance of any building permit or of any permit as is required in this section, each applicant shall submit to the city clerk: 
(1)	A satisfactory plot plan, in duplicate, indicating and describing the proposed work.
(2)	The plot plan shall be on a minimum scale of one inch equals 20 feet or 1/16-inch equals one foot and shall be placed on an 81/2-inch by 11-inch sheet or other standard size sheet. 
(3)	The plot plan shall provide the following information: lot and block number; street number, if any; dimension of front, rear and side yards; location of walks, driveways, and approaches; and sufficient information to establish the elevation of the proposed buildings and lot grading relative to existing sidewalks and streets, neighboring lots, and other pertinent structures, and ground elevations. 
(d)	Building elevations and lot grading shall be such that the following requirements are adhered to: 
(1)	The grading of the lot shall be such that surface runoff is away from buildings and towards swales, ditches or drainage structures. Grades shall provide for safe and convenient access and maintenance of the buildings and lot. Minimum grade for: 
a.	Concrete or other impervious surface shall be 1/16-inch per foot (one-half percent);
b.	Pervious surface shall be one-quarter inch per foot (two percent).
(2)	Where finished grades indicate a substantial amount of drainage across adjoining lots, drainage swale or enclosed drain of sufficient size, depth and slope shall be provided on or near the lot line to intercept this drainage. 
(3)	Lots that lie within a floodplain shall be filled to a sufficient elevation to conform to the adjacent area which is not subject to flooding. In no case will the filling of a lot be permitted if the floodplain is so restricted as to cause possible flooding or backing up of the stream. 
(e)	No landfill, involving more than 50 yards of material, shall be permitted until the property owner obtains a landfill permit under this section. To obtain a permit, the applicant shall submit to the city clerk, in writing, an application containing the following information: 
(1)	The type of fill and the location and extent of the filling operation.
(2)	If the fill operation will result in blocking existing drainage or damage to existing structures, the applicant shall submit information to the city indicating a satisfactory means of providing for existing drainage or protecting existing structures. 
(3)	No fill shall be such that it will in any way endanger the health and welfare of adjacent properties or residents, nor shall filling of land within the floodplain of a stream be permitted if the filling results in possible flooding or backing up of a stream. 
(4)	No fill shall contain putrescible material, nor oils, paints, sludges, thinners or other similar materials and the use of such materials for fill will be sufficient grounds for cancelling permit. All materials used in any fill shall be satisfactorily leveled as the work progresses and on completion of the filling operations, the land shall be left in a reasonably level condition. 
(f)	In the case of landfill exceeding 50 cubic yards, no permit shall be granted until not less than two weeks' notice has been given to all adjacent landowners and a hearing held before the common council on the advisability of such fill. 
(g)	The city clerk shall collect a permit fee in the amount established by a resolution prior to the issuance of a permit under this section. 
(h)	Violations of this section are a misdemeanor.
(Ord. No. 40,  1-7, 9-13-1960) 
Sec. 10-5. - Driveways from parking lots. 
(a)	Any person conducting a business or maintaining a parking lot on any premises in the city, where vehicular access to such premises is granted, shall provide and maintain a paved driveway between the paved portion of the street and the sidewalk abutting such premises. 
(b)	Any person conducting a business on any premises in the city and permitting the parking of motor vehicles on such premises shall provide and maintain a paved driveway between the paved portion of the street and such parking area. Such parking area shall be paved. 
(c)	The paving required in subsections (a) and (b) of this section may be constructed of either an asphaltic mix or concrete and shall be constructed to the grades established or approved by the city engineer and shall be maintained in good condition. 
(d)	Before commencing the construction of any such driveway or parking area, a permit therefor shall be obtained from the city clerk. Prior to the issuance of such permit, each applicant shall submit to the city clerk: 
(1)	A satisfactory plot plan in duplicate indicating and describing the proposed work.
(2)	The plot plan shall provide the following information: lot and block number, street number, if any, dimensions of front, rear, and side yards, location of driveway or parking area, and proposed construction area and material to be used; elevation of land, if known, and provisions for drainage and shall show the location of any public utility facilities. 
(e)	The city clerk shall collect a permit fee as established by resolution for the issuance of any permit issued under this section, provided that if such application is made in connection with a building permit, the permit required in this section shall be issued without charge. When required by the city clerk, an applicant for a construction permit under this section shall place with the city clerk a deposit as established by resolution against the cost to the city of any engineering services performed by the city engineer to establish building grades and other pertinent grade lines. When the exact cost of the engineering services has been determined, the applicant shall pay the city the balance due or receive a refund prior to receiving the permit under this section. 
(Ord. No. 45,  1-5, 10-11-1960) 
Sec. 10-6. - Construction debris containment and devices. 
(a)	For the purpose of construction and application of this section, the following definitions shall apply: 
    Construction debris means miscellaneous materials commonly discarded during the construction, renovation, or destruction of a dwelling or structure, including but not limited to shingles, scrap wood, packaging materials, nails, tarps, insulation, drywall, paint and stain containers, roofing material, pipes, wires, hoses, tubing, electrical supplies, trash, paper products and junk. 
    Construction site means each and every lot upon which a building, dwelling or structure is being or is intended to be constructed. 
    Containment device means a mobile container designed for containment and or disposal of construction debris, rubbish, trash, junk, and scrap materials. The containment device shall be a minimum of eight feet in length, eight feet in width and four feet deep. The containment device shall be constructed in such a manner as to effectively contain construction debris and shall have an attached lid capable of preventing the escape of debris. 
    Lot means a parcel of land occupied or intended to be occupied, by a building and its accessory building, or by group dwellings and their accessory buildings, together with any open spaces. 
(b)	A construction debris containment device shall be required for each and every construction site for the purpose of disposing of all construction debris. The construction debris containment device shall remain on the construction site until such time as the city has issued a certificate of occupancy. The construction debris containment device shall be regularly emptied and continually maintained in a neat and orderly condition. The construction debris containment device shall be located 15 feet from all buildings. 
(c)	It shall be unlawful for any person to maintain a construction site without providing, at the construction site, a construction debris containment device. It shall be unlawful to maintain a construction debris containment device, which is not regularly emptied and continually maintained in a neat and orderly condition. It shall be unlawful for any person to use land within the city for the dumping or disposal of scrap, iron, junk, garbage, rubbish, or other construction debris. It shall be unlawful for any person to utilize a construction debris containment device for burning purposes. 
(d)	The builder or contractor, as well as the landowner shall be responsible for properly disposing of debris, etc., and preventing the accumulation of debris, etc., prohibited by this section. 
(e)	The building inspector, upon determining there has been a violation of this section, may order the stoppage of work, withholding of inspections and/or staying or revocation of the building permit until the violation ceases. 
(Ord. No. 149,  4-7, 9-8-1959) 
Secs. 10-7-10-30. - Reserved.

ARTICLE III. - SWIMMING POOLS 

Sec. 10-61. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Nonportable pool means any pool in or above ground measuring more than 30 square feet in its surface, and having a depth in excess of 11/2 feet. 
    Swimming pool means any artificially constructed, nonportable pool, to be used in connection with a single-family residence by the occupant thereof and his guests. A swimming pool is hereby declared to be a structure for accessory use within the meaning of the building code of the city. 
(Ord. No. 59,  2, 7-5-1961; Ord. No. 59-1,  1, 4-11-1972) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally,  1-2. 
Sec. 10-62. - Illuminating lights. 
    Illuminating lights shall be so created, installed and shielded so as to eliminate direct rays and minimize reflected rays upon adjoining premises. 
(Ord. No. 59,  4(d), 7-5-1961) 
Sec. 10-63. - Connection of drainline. 
    The drainline for the pool may be connected to the sewer and be large enough to empty a pool in eight hours or less. Wastewater must be pumped into the sewer under pressure and provisions must be made to prevent sewage backflow. 
(Ord. No. 59,  4(h), 7-5-1961) 
Sec. 10-64. - Draining during periods of excessive rainfall. 
    No swimming pool shall be drained during periods of excessive rainfall so as to overload the city's sewer system. 
(Ord. No. 59,  4(m), 7-5-1961) 
Secs. 10-65-10-90. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - STORMWATER MANAGEMENT 

Sec. 10-91. - Adoption of county design criteria and guidelines. 
    The City of Utica shall adopt by reference the Design Criteria and Guidelines for Stormwater Management as adopted by the Macomb County Public Works Commissioner's Office in November 2006. 
(Ord. No. 164,  1, 5-20-2013) 
Sec. 10-92. - Violations. 
(a)	Civil infractions. A violation of this article is a municipal civil infraction, punishable by a civil fine of not more than $500.00, plus and costs, damages, and expenses. 
(b)	If stormwater management has not been adequately maintained, the city may notify the applicant(s) in writing and require the necessary maintenance or repairs within 90 days of the written notice. Should the applicant fail to comply with the provisions of this article, the city may, after giving reasonable notice and opportunity for compliance, have the necessary work done and the applicant shall be obligated to promptly reimburse the city for all such costs incurred. if said costs are not paid by the applicant, the city may pursue the collection of same through appropriate court actions or as a lien on the property. 
(c)	When emergency measures are necessary to mediate a nuisance, to protect public safety, health, welfare, or to prevent loss of life, injury or damage to property, the city is authorized to, but not required to, carry out or arrange for all such emergency measures. Property owners shall be responsible for the cost of such measures made necessary as a violation of this article and shall promptly reimburse the city for all such costs. If said costs are not paid by the applicant, the city may pursue the collection of same through appropriate court actions or as a lien on the property. 
(Ord. No. 164,  1, 5-20-2013) 
Chapter 14 - BUSINESSES 
FOOTNOTE(S):
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Community development, ch. 18; emergency services and emergency management, ch. 22; taxation, ch. 70; telecommunications, ch. 74; franchise,  74-56 et seq.; utilities, ch. 82; home occupations, app. A,  1415; bed and breakfast operations, app. A,  1416; O-1, office districts, app. A,  700 et seq.; C-1, central business district, app. A,  800 et seq.; C-2, general business district, app. A,  900 et seq.; MXD, mixed-use district, app. A,  1000 et seq.; industrial district, app. A,  1100 et seq.; P-1, vehicular parking district, app. A,  1200 et seq. (Back)
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL

ARTICLE II. - BUSINESS REGISTRATION 

Sec. 14-31. - Definition. 
    For the purpose of this article, the following definition shall apply unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning. 
    Business means any trade, occupation, work, commerce or other activity owned or operated for profit by any person within the city, except the term "business" shall not include home occupations, as defined in section 201 and section 1415 of the city's zoning ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 136,  3.01, 3-12-1996) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally,  1-2. 
Sec. 14-32. - Purpose. 
    All businesses shall be registered annually within the city: 
(1)	To assist the city with information to help provide:
a.	More adequate police and fire protection;
b.	More equal and equitable real and personal property taxation;
c.	Better efficiency and economy in furnishing public utility services; and
d.	More comprehensive and informed planning and zoning uses of land and structures.
(2)	To establish a registry of businesses operating within the city for the general information of the public and for the promotion of the city. 
(Ord. No. 136,  2.01, 3-12-1996) 
Sec. 14-33. - Violations declared misdemeanor. 
    Except as otherwise provided by law or as otherwise stated in this article, violations of this article are a misdemeanor. 
Sec. 14-34. - Requirement established. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to operate a business within the city without having first obtained a certificate of registration. 
(Ord. No. 136,  4.01(A), 3-12-1996) 
Sec. 14-35. - Registration form. 
    In order to register, the owner or operator of a business shall submit registration information on a form prepared by the city clerk. The information on the registration form shall be true and accurate. The business and the person signing the form shall be responsible for the accuracy of the information. 
(Ord. No. 136,  4.01(B), 3-12-1996) 
Sec. 14-36. - Fees. 
    The owner or operator of a business in operation and legally existing at the time of the adoption of this article shall not be charged a fee for registration. An applicant for a certificate of registration issued for a new business or change of business ownership shall be charged a fee as provided by resolution. 
(Ord. No. 136,  4.01(C), 3-12-1996) 
Sec. 14-37. - Illegal businesses. 
    No certificate of registration shall be issued by the city clerk where upon written recommendation of any city department or official, the existing or proposed business would be illegal under any law or ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 136,  4.01(D), 3-12-1996) 
Sec. 14-38. - Issuance of a certificate. 
    Upon receipt of the form and upon determining compliance with the requirements of this article, the city clerk shall issue a certificate of registration for the current year. 
(Ord. No. 136,  4.01(E), 3-12-1996) 
Sec. 14-39. - Duration. 
    The certificate of registration shall be effective until the business ceases to operate or a change of ownership or use occurs. 
(Ord. No. 136,  4.01(F), 3-12-1996) 
Sec. 14-40. - Renewals. 
    Every owner or operator of a business shall apply for a renewal certificate if the use or ownership is partially changed. There is no fee for a partial change. 
(Ord. No. 136,  4.01(G), 3-12-1996) 
Sec. 14-41. - Issuance of a new certificate. 
    If there is a necessity for the issuance of a new certificate due to a name change, or other reason, the city clerk shall issue a new certificate of registration. 
(Ord. No. 136,  4.01(H), 3-12-1996) 
Sec. 14-42. - Inspection. 
    No certificate of registration for a new business shall be issued by the city until the place of business has been inspected. The city shall have the right of inspection of the premises to ensure compliance with this chapter, either before or after the issuance of a certificate of registration. 
(Ord. No. 136,  4.01(J), 3-12-1996) 
Sec. 14-43. - Transfer. 
    No certificate of registration may be transferred by the holder to any other person. 
(Ord. No. 136,  4.01(I), 3-12-1996) 
Sec. 14-44. - Display. 
    The certificate of registration shall be prominently displayed in the place of business. 
(Ord. No. 136,  4.01(K), 3-12-1996) 
Sec. 14-45. - Discontinuance or termination of business. 
    Any business covered by this article which is discontinued or terminated shall notify the city clerk to such effect personally or by certified mail, and when the discontinuance or termination is voluntary, such notice shall precede the discontinuance or termination by 30 days. 
(Ord. No. 136,  6.01, 3-12-1996) 
Sec. 14-46. - Revocation and/or suspension. 
(a)	Noncompliance. In the event of any noncompliance with the provisions of this article after a certificate of registration has been issued, the certificate may be revoked or suspended by order of the city until the noncompliance has been corrected as determined by the city. 
(b)	Written notice. Upon any revocation and/or suspension, the city shall notify in writing the business of the action taken and shall specify the nature of any violations. 
(c)	Hearing. Any business aggrieved of the action taken by the city may request a hearing before the mayor, or the mayor's designate, to be held within 21 calendar days of the request. 
(d)	Final determination. The common council shall determine whether or not a violation has occurred, and if so, shall determine whether the revocation and/or suspension should be continued and, if so, under what conditions. 
(Ord. No. 136,  5.01, 3-12-1996) 
Secs. 14-47-14-70. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - LANDLORDS 

Sec. 14-71. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Business of leasing means the actual leasing or offering to let or to hire by a person, owner, landlord, firm or corporation, or any combination thereof, of property for residential use for any period of time in excess of six months successively or for a period of time amounting to six months within a period of one year. 
    Landlord means any person, owner, landlord, individual, firm, or corporation, or any combination thereof, engaged in the business of leasing an apartment building, multiple dwellings, rooming house, dwelling or dwellings to another person for residential use. 
    Year means July 1 to June 30 for inspection period. 
(Ord. No. 75,  1, 7-9-1968; Ord. of 3-10-2008) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally,  1-2. 
Sec. 14-72. - Violations declared a civil infraction. 
    Except as otherwise provided by law or as otherwise stated in this article, violations of this article are a civil infraction enforced pursuant the City of Utica Civil Infraction Ordinance [Chapter 2, Article VI of this Code]. 
(Ord. of 3-10-2008) 
Sec. 14-73. - License procedure; duration, license fee and late penalties. 
(a)	Every person, individual, firm, owner, corporation or landlord, or combination thereof, engaged in the business of leasing or renting any apartment building, multiple unit, multiple dwelling, dwelling or dwelling units is hereby required to make application to and receive an annual license from the city clerk before engaging in the business of leasing. The application shall be accompanied by the applicable license fee payable to the city. The applicant shall state his name and address and identify the number of tenants occupying the property. The city clerk shall issue the license if: 
(1)	The applicant's property is not in violation of any ordinance of the city; and
(2)	The applicant provides a full legal description of all parcels of property being rented.
(3)	The building department has inspected the premises and has certified that the property is in compliance with all city codes. 
(b)	A fee in the amount established by this ordinance or by resolution shall be assessed and paid at the time the application is submitted. 
(c)	The city clerk is hereby empowered to revoke the license if it is discovered that the applicant either: 
(1)	Has misrepresented himself or the state of his property;
(2)	Has refused access to premises for inspection as required in this article; or
(3)	The rental property is or becomes violative of any of the ordinances of the city and/or statutes of the state; or 
(4)	Has not paid an inspection fee by September 1 of the year in which an inspection is scheduled or within 45 days of an inspection, whichever is sooner. 
(d)	The city clerk shall cause notice of the revocation of the license to be served on the licensee either personally or by United States Mail, and the reason or reasons therefor, and such licensee may within ten days of the date of such notice, petition the common council of the city for restoration of license under such conditions as the common council may deem necessary for the correction of conditions set forth in revocation notice. 
(Ord. No. 75,  2, 5, 7-9-1968; Ord. No. 75A, 12-14-1982; Ord. No. 75B, 8-14-1990; Ord. of 3-10-2008) 
Sec. 14-74. - Periodic inspections. 
(a)	The city clerk shall cause the health officer, building inspector or such other appropriate public official as he or she may designate to make periodic inspections to which an applicant for a license or licenses shall consent, to determine the health and safety condition of the apartment building, multiple dwellings, rooming house, dwelling or dwelling units, within the city. For the purpose of making such inspections, the health officer, building inspector or the appointed public official is hereby authorized to enter, examine and survey at all reasonable times all apartment buildings, multiple dwellings, rooming houses, dwelling or dwelling units. The tenant or person in charge of an apartment building, multiple dwelling, rooming house, dwelling or dwelling unit shall at all reasonable times give the health officer, building inspector, and/or designated official access to the leased portion of an apartment building, multiple dwelling, rooming house, dwelling or dwelling unit and central facilities and common areas serving such places for the purpose of such inspection, examination and survey. 
(b)	Periodic inspections:
(1)	All residential dwellings subject to this article shall be inspected every two years. An inspection fee shall be paid on or before July 31 of the year in which an inspection is scheduled. 
(2)	Complaint(s) relevant to the condition or the property shall cause an immediate inspection. An inspection fee is payable if the inspection confirms the complaint. 
(c)	Inspection fees: An inspection fee is due and payable by July 31 of the year in which an inspection is scheduled. The Council for the City of Utica finds and determines that the following inspection fees shall be charges and that the charges do no exceed the actual, reasonable cost of providing the inspection: 
(1)	Single family dwellings: $75.00.
(2)	Duplex units: $125.00.
(3)	Multiple units (three or more): $75.00 for the first unit, and $50.00 for each additional unit. 
(4)	Reinspection: $25.00 for each dwelling unit.
(d)	No person may occupy any premises for which a landlord license is required unless a valid landlord license for the premises has been issued by the city and is currently in good standing. 
(Ord. No. 75,  3, 7-9-1968; Ord. of 3-10-2008) 
Sec. 14-75. - Applicable law 
(a)	Pursuant to Section 1 of the Housing Law of Michigan (MCL 125.401), the Act, the City of Utica acknowledges that it is subject to the provisions of the Act as being on the border and within 2&half miles of a city having a population in excess of 100,000. 
(b)	The more stringent requirements of the Act, the Michigan Construction/Building Code, and the International Property Maintenance Code and/or this article (Landlords - Codified Ordinance section 14-71 through 14-75) shall apply without waiving any other provision of said Act, ordinance and/or codes. 
(c)	The provisions of the Act, relevant to residential requirements for rental property, MCL 125.523 through 125.537, are implemented by this article with the following meaning of terms used in the Act: 
(1)	Registration is an application for a landlord license and registry shall be the list of landlord licenses. 
(2)	Enforcing agency is the building department or police department with concurrent jurisdiction. The building department shall maintain all routine records such as checklists or the likes. 
(3)	Court of competent jurisdiction is understood to be the 41A District Court for the issuance and enforcement of civil infractions and the issuance of any inspection warrant. This does not exclude concurrent enforcement through any circuit court in Michigan. 
(4)	Certificate and certificate of compliance is a landlord license. 
(5)	Escrow account for suspended rent shall be such account or depository as may be approved by a judge or magistrate of the 41A District Court or a circuit court judge. Disbursements from an escrow account must be approved by court order. 
(6)	Appropriate county register of deeds is the Macomb County Register of Deeds. 
(Ord. of 3-10-2008) 
Secs. 14-76-14-100. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - MASSAGE PARLORS 
FOOTNOTE(S):
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Zoning, app. A. (Back)
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 14-101. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Employee means any individual who renders any service in connection with the operation of a massage establishment and receives compensation therefor including but not limited to massagers. 
    Establishment means a massage parlor or school of massage. 
    Instructor means a person who is a licensed myomassologist and teaches in a school of massage. 
    Massage means the rubbing, kneading, tapping, compression, vibration, application of friction, or percussion of the human body or parts of it by hand or with an instrument or apparatus. 
    Massager, masseur and myomassologist mean an individual who administers massages. 
    Massage parlor means a business establishment where massagers practice massage; a building, room, place, or establishment, other than a regularly licensed hospital or dispensary, in which body massage is practiced on the human body, for other than cosmetic or beautifying purposes, with or without the use of nonpowered mechanical or bathing devices. The term "massage parlor" includes a health club, health spa or any physical fitness club or business that offers massages on occasion or incidental to its regular operation. The term "massage parlor" and the term "massage establishment" are synonymous and are used interchangeably in this article. 
    Owner means a person who conducts or owns a massage establishment or school of massage with his respective duly licensed myomassologists. 
    Patron means any individual who receives a massage. 
    School of massage means a building, room, place, or establishment which satisfies the requirements of the state department of education, if any, and/or of the administrators of this article and is accredited under this article; which requires for admission students with a tenth grade education or its equivalent; which employs one or more competent, certified and/or licensed myomassologists as instructors; and which has minimum requirements of a continuous course of study and training consisting of study in physiology, anatomy, massage theory, hydrotherapy, hygiene, ethics, and practical massage, which courses of study and training are approved by the state department of education and the state exam licensing board, if so required, or are promulgated by a myomassologist duly certified by the American Massage Therapy Association or International Myomassitic Federation. 
    Student means a person who is 16 years of age or older and is engaged in the study of myomassology. 
(Ord. No. 120,  3, 3-10-1987; Ord. No. 120A,  I(2), 8-9-1988) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally,  1-2. 
Sec. 14-102. - Violations declared misdemeanor. 
    Except as otherwise provided by law or as otherwise stated in this article, violations of this article are a misdemeanor. 
Sec. 14-103. - Licensed physical therapist and similar professions excepted. 
(a)	This article does not apply to a licensed physical therapist, a licensed athletic trainer, a licensed cosmetologist, or a licensed barber performing functions authorized under the license held, nor does this article apply to a licensed medical doctor, osteopath, nurse or chiropractor, or any individual working under the direct supervision of a licensed medical doctor, osteopath, nurse or chiropractor, while engaged in practicing the healing arts. 
(b)	This article does not apply to the administration of massage for therapeutic purposes in a hospital, nursing home, or other medical care facility. 
(Ord. No. 120,  4, 3-10-1987) 
Sec. 14-104. - Administration. 
    Pursuant to the provisions of this article, the police chief is designated as the inspection officer and the city clerk is designated as licensing officer. 
(Ord. No. 120,  2, 3-10-1987; Ord. No. 120A,  I(1), 8-9-1988) 
Cross reference- Administration, ch. 2. 
Sec. 14-105. - Responsibility of employer. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person operating an establishment to permit or allow an employee, student, agent or massager thereof, or any person whatsoever, to violate this article on the premises of the establishment. 
(Ord. No. 120,  8, 3-10-1987) 
Sec. 14-106. - Compliance by students and instructors. 
(a)	Students and instructors must also fully comply with the terms of this article except that the credit requirements defined in subsection 14-147(c)(3) are not applicable to a student unless the student has already satisfied these requirements while taking instruction for these requirements in a course of study which includes this subject matter and satisfies the definition of myomassology. 
(b)	The student shall make application for student license with the city clerk and shall be bound by the terms of section 14-147 in the same manner as though he were applying for a myomassologist license under such section except that to satisfy subsection 14-147(b)(2)c he shall include his student history, if any, in the field of myomassology, physical therapy and/or like fields of endeavor wherein the scientific art form of massage is performed, including but not limited to nursing, athletic trainer, barbers, beauticians, chiropractic medicine, osteopathic medicine or medical doctor. 
(c)	The instructor in a school of massage shall make application for a license with the city clerk and shall satisfy the requirements for licensing of a myomassologist under this article. 
(Ord. No. 120,  23, 3-10-1987; Ord. No. 120A,  I(7), 8-9-1988) 
Secs. 14-107-14-125. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - LICENSES AND CERTIFICATES 
Subdivision I. - In General 

Sec. 14-126. - Required. 
(a)	It shall be unlawful for any person to operate an establishment without a valid establishment license therefor issued by the city clerk in accordance with the provisions of this article. 
(b)	It shall be unlawful for any person to operate an establishment unless each and every massager thereof has a valid massager's or student's license issued by the city clerk in accordance with the provisions of this article. 
(c)	It shall be unlawful for any individual to work as a massager without having a valid massager's or student's license issued by the city clerk in accordance with the provisions of this article. 
(d)	It shall be unlawful for any person to operate an establishment unless each and every employee thereof has a valid health certificate card in accordance with the provisions of this article. 
(e)	It shall be unlawful for any individual to work in an establishment without having a valid health certificate card issued in accordance with the provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. 120,  5, 3-10-1987; Ord. No. 120A,  I(3), 8-9-1988) 
Sec. 14-127. - Duty of city clerk. 
    The city clerk shall: 
(1)	Accept all applications and fees required to be filed under this article.
(2)	Keep a record of all applications made.
(3)	Ensure that fees in the proper amount accompany each application and submit the fees to the city treasurer. 
(4)	After completion of the applications, turn the applications into the police chief.
(5)	Grant, refuse, suspend or revoke licenses or applications upon the investigation, recommendation or approval or nonapproval of the police chief or his representative; the police chief shall record such disposition including the results of any court actions or appeals taken under this article and advise the city clerk thereof. 
(Ord. No. 120,  5, 25, 33, 3-10-1987) 
Sec. 14-128. - Appeals. 
(a)	Any person aggrieved by an action or decision of the city clerk or police chief or his duly authorized representative regarding the issuance, suspension or revocation of a license required under this article or the cancellation of a health certificate card required under this article may, within 30 days thereafter, appeal to a hearing examiner appointed by the common council. The appeal of a revocation of a license or the cancellation of a health certificate card shall be accompanied by the posting of $1,000.00 cash bond. If the revocation or cancellation is set aside, then the bond is to be refunded in full. If the revocation or cancellation is upheld, then the bond is forfeited to the city as a reasonable estimate of the expenses associated with the appeal process. 
(b)	The appeal to the hearing examiner shall be initiated by filing a written objection with the hearing examiner. The written objection shall state what the action or decision of the city clerk or police chief should have been and why. A copy of the document containing the notice of the action or decision complained of shall be attached to the written objection. Upon receipt of the written objection and attachment, the hearing examiner shall set the objection down for a hearing to be held within the next 15 days and advise all parties of the date, time and place of hearing. The person aggrieved shall bring to the hearing all licenses issued to him pursuant to this article. The city attorney may appear and represent the interests of the city clerk or police chief. 
(c)	At hearings before the hearing examiner, all witnesses will be sworn. The hearing examiner will hear the testimony of the city clerk or police chief or his duly authorized representative and/or each individual as will be called by him, the hearing examiner will hear the testimony of the persons aggrieved along with any witnesses the person aggrieved may call. Additionally, the hearing examiner will review all documents and exhibits submitted to him by the parties. The hearing examiner will not be bound by formal rules of evidence and will control the evidence, reserving to himself the power to exclude testimony or exhibits he does not consider relevant. 
(d)	The hearing examiner will maintain an accurate record of the evidence adduced at the hearing. 
(e)	Within 48 hours of the close of the hearing, the hearing examiner will notify the parties of his decision. Within three days of the close of the hearing, the hearing examiner will reduce to writing his report, which will consist of a finding of facts and his decision. The hearing examiner will file the original of his report with the city clerk, will keep one copy for himself, will send one copy to the person aggrieved and will send one copy to the police chief. 
(f)	If the city clerk or police chief or the person aggrieved is dissatisfied with the hearing examiner's decision, he may, within five days from the date the hearing examiner filed his report, file a written objection with the common council. When such an objection is filed, the common council will place the matter on the agenda of the common council for review at the next meeting of the common council which is at least five days after the date of the filing of the objection. If the objection is filed by the city clerk or police chief, notice that the matter is on the agenda will be sent to the applicant by mail. The person aggrieved shall bring to the common council hearing all licenses issued to him pursuant to this article. When the matter comes before common council, the common council will review the matter, considering such information as is in the hearing examiner's file and report and will either affirm, reverse, or modify the decision of the hearing examiner. 
(g)	As to an appeal taken to common council by the city clerk or police chief, the decision of the common council shall be final. 
(Ord. No. 120,  67, 3-10-1987; Ord. No. 120A,  6, 8-9-1988) 
Sec. 14-129. - Licenses and certificates required. 
(a)	The city clerk shall issue licenses and certificates upon investigation, recommendation and approval of the police chief or his representative. 
(b)	As to an appeal taken to common council by a licensee, the decision or decisions of which the licensee objects, the licensee may thereafter pursue his remedy by appealing the decision of the common council to the county circuit court. The time and procedure used for filing such appeal shall comply with chapter 6 of the Administrative Procedures Act of 1969 (MCL 24.301 et seq.) and the Michigan Court Rules. 
(Ord. No. 120,  5, 67, 3-10-1987) 
Secs. 14-130-14-145. - Reserved. 
Subdivision II. - Licenses 

Sec. 14-146. - Application for establishment license. 
(a)	Any person desiring an establishment license shall file a written application, in triplicate, with the city clerk on a form to be furnished by the city clerk. 
(b)	The application shall set forth the following:
(1)	The name of the applicant and whether it is an individual, partnership, corporation, or otherwise, and if a corporation, the state of incorporation; 
(2)	The name, style, and designation under which the establishment is to be operated;
(3)	The business address where the establishment is to be operated;
(4)	The name, residence addresses and telephone numbers of the manager or other individual to be principally in charge of the operation of the establishment; 
(5)	The following personal information concerning the applicant, if an individual; and concerning each stockholder holding more than ten percent of the stock of the corporation, each officer and each director, if the applicant is a corporation; and concerning the partners, including limited partners, if the applicant is a partnership; and the holder of any lien, of any nature, upon the establishment and/or the equipment used therein; and concerning the manager or other individual principally in charge of the operation of the establishment: 
a.	Name, complete residence address.
b.	All addresses used during the five-year period immediately prior to the date of the application, and the period of time each was used. 
c.	Written proof of age. Birth certificate or affidavit that applicant is at least 18 years of age. 
d.	Height, weight, color of hair and eyes, and sex.
e.	The massage or similar business history and experience ten years prior to the date of application, including but not limited to whether or not such individual is previously operating in this or another county, city or state or any other state, city or county of these United States under license or permit has had such license or permit denied, revoked, or suspended and the reason thereof, and the business activities or occupations subsequent to such action of denial, suspension or revocation. 
f.	All criminal arrests and convictions therefor other than misdemeanor traffic violations, fully disclosing the jurisdictions in which convicted, the offense on which arrested initially and the offense for which he was ultimately convicted, and the dates of conviction and penalty suffered therefor. 
(6)	A schedule of days and times to accommodate a use of the establishment by male or female patrons. 
(7)	Release and authorization for the city, its agents and employees to seek information and conduct an investigation into the truth of the statements set forth in the application and the qualifications of the applicant for the license. 
(8)	The names and addresses of three registered voters of the state who will serve as character references for each individual listed in subsection (b)(5) of this section. These references must be individuals other than relatives and business associates. 
(9)	Written declaration by the applicant, given under oath or affirmation, under penalty of perjury, that the information contained in and attached to the application is true and correct, such declaration being duly dated and signed. 
(c)	The application shall be accompanied by the following:
(1)	A tender of the correct license fee as provided in this article.
(2)	Proof that an assumed name certificate has been filed with the county clerk, or secretary of state, corporation division if the applicant is to operate the establishment under an assumed name. 
(3)	Articles of incorporation or proof that applicant is authorized to do business in the state, if the applicant is a foreign corporation. 
(4)	Two front-face portrait photographs taken within 30 days of the date of the application and at least two inches by two inches in size, for each individual listed in subsection (b)(5) of this section. 
(5)	Business, occupation or employment of the applicant for three years immediately preceding the date of application. 
(d)	The applicant shall cooperate with the police department for purposes of supplying fingerprints and shall likewise cooperate to supply a blood sample to a doctor designated by the police chief, the costs thereof to be paid by the applicant. 
(e)	It shall be the responsibility of the holder of the license for the establishment, or the employer of any persons purporting to act as masseur to ensure that each person employed as a masseur or student shall first have obtained a valid license pursuant to the provisions of this article. All other employees who work closely with the massage activities shall provide annually the medical certificate required under subsection 14-147(c)(4). 
(Ord. No. 120,  31, 3-10-1987) 
Sec. 14-147. - Application for massager's or student's license. 
(a)	Any individual desiring a massager's or student's license shall file a written application, in triplicate, with the city clerk on a form to be furnished by the city clerk. 
(b)	The application, or information sheet for a nonlicensee employee, shall set forth the following: 
(1)	The business name, address and all telephone numbers where the massage is to be practiced, if known. If not known, the applicant shall so state. 
(2)	The following personal information concerning the applicant:
a.	The name, complete residence address and residence telephone number;
b.	All addresses used during the five-year period immediately prior to the date of the application, and the period of time each was used; 
c.	Written proof of being 18 years of age or older;
d.	Height, weight, color of hair and eyes, and sex;
e.	The massage or similar business history and experience ten years prior to the date of application, including but not limited to whether or not such individual is previously operating in this city, county or state or another city, county or state under license or permit has had such license or permit denied, revoked, or suspended and the reason therefor, and the business activities or occupations subsequent to such action of denial, suspension or revocation; 
f.	All criminal arrests and the convictions therefor other than misdemeanor traffic violations, fully disclosing the jurisdiction in which convicted and the offense on which originally arrested and the offense for which he was finally convicted; and the date of conviction and penalty suffered. 
(3)	Release and authorization for the city, its agents and employees to seek information and conduct an investigation into the truth of the statements set forth in the application and the qualifications of the applicant for the license. 
(4)	Written declaration by the applicant, given under oath or affirmation, under penalty of perjury; that the information contained in and attached to the application is true and correct, such declaration being duly dated and signed. 
(c)	The application shall be accompanied by the following:
(1)	A tender of the correct license fee as provided in this article.
(2)	Two front-face portrait photographs of the applicant taken within 30 days of the date of application and at least two inches by two inches in size. 
(3)	For a massager's license, any one of the following:
a.	A photocopy of the applicant's grade record, reflecting successful completion of three semester hours each of human anatomy and physiology at an institution of higher education which is accredited by a recognized accrediting agency of this state or any state of the United States; or certified statement by a myomassologist instructor who is duly certified and in good standing with the American Massage Therapy Association or International Myomassitic Federation that the applicant has successfully completed 100 myomassitic classroom and/or actual therapy practice hours under instruction taught by and utilizing course materials and curriculum arranged by such instructor; or Certificate by the American Massage Therapy Association or the International Myomassitic Federation that the applicant is duly certified and in good standing on the date application is made or renewed; or certificate of myomassology from this state, or any other state of these United States, approved school of massage therapy. 
b.	For a massager student's license, any one of the following:
1.	A photocopy of the registration record or transcript from an accredited institution of higher learning that the applicant is enrolled in and/or has successfully completed three semester hours of a course in human anatomy and three semester hours of physiology; 
2.	A certified and sworn statement that he has been accepted and will commence or complete or be in the process toward completing studies in the above-mentioned course material at an institution of higher learning naming such institution; 
3.	A sworn statement by a myomassologist instructor, together with:
i.	A copy of the instructors certification of good standing (on the date application is made by applicant) in the American Massage Therapy Association or International Myomassitic Federation; 
ii.	Instructors syllabus of curriculum, that student license applicant is enrolled in his course; and 
iii.	The number of hours the applicant has successfully completed under such instruction; or 
4.	Certified statement under oath by student licensee applicant that he will, within six months after receiving a temporary license as defined in subsections 14-151(6)b.1 and 2, commence enrollment in a course of study for at least 100 hours under a duly certified and in good standing myomassologist instructor as stated in the subsection (c)(3)b.3 of this section; and shall further certify under oath that upon commencing in such course of study shall obtain and present to the city clerk the documentation as set forth in subsection (c)(3)b.3 of this section. 
(4)	A valid health certificate card issued to the applicant pursuant to these regulations.
(5)	Business, occupation or employment of the applicant for three years immediately preceding the date of application. 
(d)	The applicant shall cooperate with the police department for purposes of supplying fingerprints and shall likewise cooperate to supply a blood sample to a doctor designated by the police chief, the costs thereof to be paid by the applicant. 
(Ord. No. 120,  32, 3-10-1987; Ord. No. 120A,  8, 8-9-1988) 
Sec. 14-148. - Investigation. 
(a)	Upon receiving the application for a massage parlor or massager's license or school, instructor's or student's license, the police chief shall conduct an investigation of the applicant, if an individual, or of the stockholders holding more than ten percent of the stock of the corporation, and of the officers and directors, if the applicant is a corporation, or of the partners, including limited partners, if the applicant is a partnership, or the holder of any lien, of any nature, upon the establishment and/or the equipment used therein or of the manager or other individual principally in charge of the operation of the massage establishment, and personal and criminal history, the police chief may, in his discretion, require a personal interview of the applicant, and such further information, identification and physical examination of the applicant as shall bear on the investigation. 
(b)	In the case of applications for massage parlors or school of massage licenses, the police chief shall cause to be conducted an investigation of the premises where the establishment is to be carried on, for the purposes of ensuring that such premises comply with all the sanitation requirements as set forth in this article and with the regulations of public health, safety and welfare of the city including but not limited to zoning, building and fire codes. 
(Ord. No. 120,  33, 3-10-1987) 
Sec. 14-149. - Issuance of massage parlor license. 
    The police chief shall present his findings to the city clerk for issuance of a massage parlor license within 60 days of receipt of the application unless the police chief finds that: 
(1)	The correct license fee has not been tendered to the city, and, in the case of a check, or bank draft, honored with payment upon presentation. 
(2)	The operation as proposed by the applicant, if permitted, would not comply with all applicable laws. 
(3)	The applicant, if an individual, or any of the stockholders holding more than ten percent of the stock of the corporation, or any of the officers or directors, if the applicant is a corporation, or any of the partners, including limited partners, if the applicant is a partnership, or the holder of any lien, of any nature, upon the massage establishment and/or the equipment used therein the manager or other individual principally in charge of the operation of the massage establishment, has been convicted of any felony or a misdemeanor involving a violation of laws relating to massages or health codes prior to the date of the application. 
(4)	The applicant has knowingly made any false, misleading, or fraudulent statement of fact in the license application or in any document required by the city in conjunction therewith. 
(5)	The applicant has had a massage establishment, massager's, instructor's, student's or similar license or permit revoked or suspended by the city, county or state or any other city, county or state or local agency prior to the date of the application. 
(6)	The applicant, if an individual, or any of the officers or directors, if the applicant is a corporation, or any of the partners, including limited partners, if the applicant is a partnership, or the manager or other individual principally in charge of the operation of the establishment, is not over the age of 18 years. 
(7)	The applicant did not designate the days and times that the establishment would accommodate male and/or female patrons. 
(8)	The applicant has an infectious or contagious disease.
(9)	The applicant and/or application does not meet all other requirements of this article or other ordinances of the city pertaining to business establishments included but not limited to fire, health, building and zoning ordinances. 
(Ord. No. 120,  34, 3-10-1987) 
Sec. 14-150. - Issuance of massager's license. 
    The city clerk shall issue a massager's license within 60 days of receipt of the application unless the police chief finds that: 
(1)	The correct license fee has not been tendered to the city, and, in the case of a check or bank draft, honored with payment upon presentation. 
(2)	The applicant has been convicted of a felony or a crime involving a violation of laws relating to massages or health codes prior to the date of the application. 
(3)	The applicant has knowingly made any false, misleading, or fraudulent statements of fact in the license application or in any document required by the city in conjunction therewith. 
(4)	The applicant has had a massage establishment, massager's, or other similar license or permit revoked or suspended by this city, county or state, or any other city, county or state or local agency of these United States prior to the date of application. 
(5)	The applicant is not over the age of 18 years (or 16 years of age if a student applicant).
(6)	The massager's license applicant does not satisfy any one of the following requirements:
a.	Successful completion of three semester hours each of human anatomy and physiology at an institution of higher education which is accredited by a recognized accrediting agency of this state or any other state of these United States; 
b.	Successful completion of at least 100 myomassitic classroom and/or actual therapy practice hours of instruction taught by and utilizing course materials and curriculum arranged by an instructor duly certified by and in good standing with the American Massage Therapy Association or International Myomassitic Federation; 
c.	The applicant is currently certified by and in good standing with the American Massage Therapy Association; 
d.	The applicant is currently certified by and in good standing with the International Myomassitic Federation; or 
e.	Possess a current certificate of myomassology from this state or any other state of these United States, or any school of massage. 
(7)	The applicant does not have a valid health certificate card issued pursuant to this article. 
(8)	The applicant and/or application does not meet all other requirements of this article.
(Ord. No. 120,  35, 3-10-1987; Ord. No. 120A,  8, 8-9-1988) 
Sec. 14-151. - Massager student's license. 
    The city clerk shall issue a massager student's license, or a temporary student's license as the case may be, within 60 days of receipt of the application unless the police chief finds that: 
(1)	The correct license fee has not been tendered to the city, and, in the case of a check or bank draft, honored with payment upon presentation. 
(2)	The applicant has been convicted of a felony or a crime involving a violation of laws relating to massages or health codes prior to the date of the application. 
(3)	The applicant has knowingly made any false, misleading, or fraudulent statements of fact in the license application or in any document required by the city in conjunction therewith. 
(4)	The applicant has had a massage establishment, massager's, massager student's license, or other similar license or permit revoked or suspended by this city, county or state, or any other city, county or state or local agency of these United States prior to the date of application. 
(5)	The applicant is not over the age of 18 years.
(6)	The massager student's license applicant does not satisfy any one of the following requirements: 
a.	Student enrolled in college curriculum:
1.	Applicant is enrolled in and is attending or shall register and attend at the next semester or term of a duly accredited institution of higher learning in a curriculum and be in the process of successfully completing with passing grades three semester hours each of human anatomy and physiology; such accreditation of the institution being by a recognized accrediting agency of this state or any other state of these United States; 
2.	As to subsection (6)a.1 of this section, the applicant shall submit written or documented proof of enrollment with the application for student's license or in the event that application for student's license under this article is made while semester is in progress then such proof shall be submitted within 30 days after the next registration opens at the institution of higher learning whereat the curriculum is being taught and student enrolled; further, proof of successful completion by way of transcript from the institution shall be submitted for the licensee's file within ten days after licensee's receipt thereof at the end of the semester; or 
b.	Student enrolled in other than college curriculum:
1.	Applicant is enrolled in and is attending, or shall enroll in within six months of making application for student's license under this article, and shall complete successfully at least 100 myomassitic classroom and/or actual massage therapy practice hours of institution utilizing course materials and curriculum arranged and taught by a myomassologist instructor duly certified by and in good standing with the American Massage Therapy Association or International Myomassitic Federation. 
2.	As to subsection (6)b.1 of this section, written proof and documentation of enrollment together with the teacher's name, address, phone number and certification, as defined in subsection (6)b.1 of this section together with syllabus of curriculum being taught by such teacher, shall be submitted with the application of the applicant; in the event application for student's license is made and the applicant is not enrolled in any such curriculum given by a teacher certified as required in this section, then a temporary student's license may be issued provided that the requirements of subsections (1) through (5), (7) and (8) of this section are satisfied and the requirements of this subsection (6)b. are satisfied within six months after making application under this article. If, at the end of the six-month period, the enrollment, teacher and syllabus requirements as defined in this subsection (6)b. are not satisfied, then the temporary student's license shall expire and shall not be renewed until the applicant can submit an application satisfying all requirements. However, the temporary student's license shall become a regular student's license which is renewable yearly (a student's license being renewable only twice) upon the applicant's submitting the required materials as to enrollment, teacher and syllabus within the six-month period; under this circumstance, the anniversary date for student's license renewal shall be the date when final documentation requirements under this section are submitted to the city clerk and time stamped into the applicant's file. 
(7)	The applicant does not have a valid health certificate card issued pursuant to this article. 
(8)	The applicant and/or application does not meet all other requirements of this article.
(Ord. No. 120A,  8, 8-9-1988) 
Sec. 14-152. - Fees. 
    The fee for a massage parlor or massage school license shall be established by resolution. The fee for a massager's license shall be established by resolution. The fee for a student's license shall be established by resolution. The fee for a nonlicensee employee shall be established by resolution. 
(Ord. No. 120,  36, 3-10-1987) 
Sec. 14-153. - Return of fee. 
    No portion of any fee collected under this article shall be returned after application for license has been made. 
(Ord. No. 120,  37, 3-10-1987) 
Sec. 14-154. - Term. 
    Each license issued under this article, unless otherwise specifically stated in this article, shall be valid for no more than one year from the date of its issuance as shown thereon. 
(Ord. No. 120,  39(1), 3-10-1987; Ord. No. 120A,  9, 8-9-1988) 
Sec. 14-155. - Renewal of licenses. 
    Any time after the expiration of 11 months of the term of a license required by this article, the licensee thereof may file with the city clerk a written application to renew such license on a form to be furnished by the city clerk. Such application shall contain the information required in this article for an original license to the extent that such information would not be duplicative and such application shall be accompanied by a tender of the correct fee as provided in this article. The city clerk shall renew such license unless the police chief finds that the requirements of this article for the reissuance of a license are not met. A student's license shall be renewed only twice. 
(Ord. No. 120,  40, 3-10-1987) 
Sec. 14-156. - Obtaining license by fraud. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to knowingly make any false, fraudulent or untruthful statement, either written or oral, or in any way knowingly to conceal any material fact, or to give or use any fictitious name in order to secure or aid in securing a license required by this article and any such license so secured shall be void. 
(Ord. No. 120,  41, 3-10-1987) 
Sec. 14-157. - Fraudulent use of license. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to fraudulently make use of, in any manner to his own or another's benefit, a massage parlor license, school of massage, student's or a massager's license which has not been duly issued to him in accordance with the provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. 120,  42, 3-10-1987) 
Sec. 14-158. - Display generally. 
(a)	A massage parlor or massage school license issued under this article shall be displayed at all times in an open and conspicuous place in the lobby of the massage parlor or school for which it was issued. 
(b)	It shall be unlawful for any massager or student to work in, on or about any establishment, unless there shall be displayed in an open and conspicuous place in the lobby of such establishment, a massager's or student's license issued to such massager or student respectively pursuant to this article. 
(Ord. No. 120,  6, 3-10-1987) 
Sec. 14-159. - Counterfeiting, changing, defacing license. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to counterfeit or forge, or to change, deface or alter a license required or issued under the provisions of this article. A photograph of the licensee massager shall be attached to his license on display. 
(Ord. No. 120,  39(2), 43, 3-10-1987) 
Sec. 14-160. - Transfer prohibited. 
    Massage parlor licenses, school of massage, massager's or student's licenses are not transferable, separable or divisible, and such authority as a license confers shall be conferred only on the licensee named therein. 
(Ord. No. 120,  38, 3-10-1987) 
Sec. 14-161. - Sale or transfer. 
(a)	Upon the sale or transfer of any interest in a massage parlor, massage school or similar business, the license shall be null and void. A new application shall be made by any person, firm or entity desiring to own or operate the massage parlor, massage school or similar business. The provisions of 14-146 and 14-147 shall apply to any person, firm or entity applying for a massage establishment license for premises previously used as such establishment. 
(b)	Any sale or transfer of any interest in an existing massage establishment or any application for an extension or expansion of the building or other place of business of the massage establishment shall require inspection and shall require compliance with this article. A fee in an amount as established by resolution of the common council shall be payable for each application involving extension or expansion of the building or other place of business of the massage establishment. 
(Ord. No. 120,  57, 3-10-1987) 
Sec. 14-162. - Name of business. 
    No person licensed under this article shall operate under any name or conduct his business under any designation not specified in the license. 
(Ord. No. 120,  59, 3-10-1987) 
Sec. 14-163. - Suspension. 
(a)	Any license issued under this article may be suspended for a period not to exceed 90 days by the city clerk upon the investigation, recommendation or approval of the police chief for a minor violation of this article by the licensee thereof. 
(b)	Any massage establishment license issued under this article may be suspended for a period not to exceed 90 days by the city clerk upon the investigation, recommendation or approval of the police chief for a violation of this article by an agent or employee of the massage establishment provided such violation occurred on the massage establishment premises. 
(c)	Such suspension shall be effective ten days after written notice thereof is given to the licensee. Such notice shall inform the licensee of the reason for such suspension, the duration of such suspension, the beginning of such suspension, and the right to appeal under the provisions of this article. 
(d)	Such notice may be given by delivering the notice to the licensee, by delivering the notice to the establishment, or by depositing the notice in the United States Mail, postage prepaid, certified or registered mail, return receipt requested, addressed to the licensee at the address stated on the license application and such notice shall be deemed given upon deposit of the notice in the United States Mail as provided in this subsection. 
(e)	This section is cumulative of all other rules, regulations and laws. An appeal, as provided in this article, from any suspension under this article, shall automatically stay such suspension pending such appeal: 
(1)	After the effective date of the suspension and if an appeal is not made; or
(2)	If an appeal is made and the suspension is upheld in whole or in part, then and in either of those events, the police chief shall have the authority to take possession of the license wheresoever it may be found and hold the license until the suspension period has expired. 
(Ord. No. 120,  44, 3-10-1987) 
Sec. 14-164. - Revocation. 
    Any license issued under this article may be revoked by the city clerk upon the investigation, recommendation or approval of the police chief for a significant violation of this article or should the licensee no longer qualify for a license as an original applicant, or the licensee's license has been suspended three times within a ten-year period, or has misrepresented or withheld information on his original or renewal application. Any establishment license issued under this article may be revoked by the city clerk upon the investigation, recommendation or approval of the police chief for a significant violation of this article by an agent or employee of the establishment provided such violation occurred on the establishment premises. 
(a)	Such revocation shall be effective immediately after written notice thereof is given to the licensee. Such notice shall inform the licensee of the reason for such revocation and the right to appeal under the provisions of this article.
