ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 18-1-18-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - DOWNTOWN DEVELOPMENT AUTHORITY 

FOOTNOTE(S):
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Boards and commissions,  2-231 et seq. (Back)
State Law reference- Downtown development authority, MCL 125.1651 et seq. (Back)
Sec. 18-31. - Definitions. 
    The terms used in this article shall have the same meaning as given to them in Public Act No. 197 of 1975 (MCL 125.1651 et seq.) or as hereinafter in this section provided unless the context clearly indicates to the contrary. As used in this article: 
    Authority means the downtown development authority of the city created by this article. 
    Board and board of directors mean the board of directors of the authority, the governing body of the authority. 
    Chief executive officer means the mayor of the city. 
    Downtown district means the downtown district designated by this article as now existing or hereafter amended. 
(Ord. No. 124,  2, 8-8-????) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally,  1-2. 
Sec. 18-32. - Determination of necessity. 
    The common council hereby determines that it is necessary for the best interests of the city to halt property value deterioration and increase property tax valuation where possible in the business district of the city, to eliminate the causes of that deterioration and to promote economic growth by establishing a downtown development authority pursuant to Public Act No. 197 of 1975 (MCL 125.1651 et seq.). 
(Ord. No. 124,  3, 8-8-1989) 
Sec. 18-33. - Creation of authority. 
    There is hereby created pursuant to Public Act No. 197 of 1975 (MCL 125.1651 et seq.) a downtown development authority for the city. The downtown development authority shall be a public body corporate and shall be known and exercise its powers under the title of "Downtown Development Authority of the City of Utica." The downtown development authority may adopt a seal, may sue and be sued in any court of this state and shall possess all of the powers necessary to carry out the purpose of its incorporation as provided by this article and Public Act No. 197 of 1975 (MCL 125.1651 et seq.). The enumeration of a power in this article or in Public Act No. 197 of 1975 (MCL 125.1651 et seq.) shall not be construed as a limitation upon the general powers of the downtown development authority. 
(Ord. No. 124,  4, 8-8-1989) 
State law reference- Authority to establish downtown development authority, MCL 125.1652. 
Sec. 18-34. - Description of downtown district. 
    The downtown district in which the authority shall exercise its powers as provided by Public Act No. 197 of 1975 (MCL 125.1651 et seq.) shall consist of the described territory in the city, subject to this article and Public Act No. 197 of 1975 (MCL 125.1651 et seq.), as set forth in Exhibit A to Ordinance No. 124, attached hereto and made a part hereof. 
(Ord. No. 124,  5, 8-8-1989) 
Sec. 18-35. - Board of directors. 
    The downtown development authority shall be under the supervision and control of the board of directors consisting of the chief executive officer of the city and not less than eight or more than 12 members as determined by the city. The members of the board of directors shall be appointed by the chief executive officer of the city, subject to the approval by the common council. Not less than a majority of the members of the board of directors shall be persons having an interest in property located in the downtown district. Not less than one of the members of the board of directors shall be a resident of the downtown district, if the downtown district has 100 or more persons residing with it. Of the members of the board of directors first appointed, an equal number, as near as is practical, shall be appointed for one year, two years, three years, and four years. Members of the board of directors shall hold office until the members' successor is appointed. Thereafter, each member shall serve for a term of four years. An appointment to fill a vacancy shall be made by the chief executive officer of the city for the unexpired term only. Members of the board of directors shall serve without compensation, but shall be reimbursed for actual and necessary expenses. 
(Ord. No. 124,  6, 8-8-1989) 
Cross reference- Boards and commissions,  2-231 et seq. 
State law reference- Board of directors, MCL 125.1654. 
Sec. 18-36. - Powers of authority. 
    The downtown development authority shall have all powers enumerated or implied by law in Public Act No. 197 of 1975 (MCL 125.1651 et seq.). 
(Ord. No. 124,  7, 8-8-1989) 
Sec. 18-37. - Fiscal year; adoption of budget. 
(a)	The fiscal year of the downtown development authority shall begin on January 1 of each year and end on December 31 of that same year, or such other fiscal year as may hereafter be adopted by the city. 
(b)	The board of directors shall annually prepare a budget and shall submit it to the common council on the same date that the proposed budget for the city is required by law to be submitted to the common council. The board of directors shall not finally adopt a budget for any fiscal year until the budget has been approved by the common council. The board of directors may, however, temporarily adopt a budget in connection with the operation of any improvements which have been financed by revenue bonds where required to do so by the ordinance authorizing the revenue bonds. 
(c)	The downtown development authority shall submit financial reports to the common council at the same time and on the same basis as departments of the city are required to submit reports. The downtown development authority shall be audited annually by the same independent auditors auditing the city and copies of the audit report shall be filed with the city. 
(Ord. No. 124,  8, 8-8-1989) 
State law reference- Budget, MCL 125.1678. 
Secs. 18-38-18-60. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - DOWNTOWN DEVELOPMENT PLAN AND TAX INCREMENT FINANCING PLAN 

FOOTNOTE(S):
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference- Taxation, ch. 70. (Back)
Sec. 18-61. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Captured assessed value means the amount in any one year by which the current assessed value as finally equalized of all taxable property in the development area exceeds the initial assessed value, as more fully described in the development plan and tax increment financing plan. 
    Development area means the area within the boundaries of the city downtown development authority district, as described in Exhibit A to ordinance 124, and as illustrated in the downtown development authority development plan and tax increment financing plan. 
    Development plan means the development plan for the downtown development authority district, illustrated in the downtown development authority development plan and tax increment financing plan. 
    Downtown development authority means the city development authority as established by article II of this chapter. 
    Initial assessed value means the most recently assessed value, as finally equalized by the state board of equalization, of all taxable property within the boundaries of the downtown development authority district at the time of adoption of the ordinance from which this article is derived, as more fully described in the downtown authority development plan and tax increment financing plan. 
    Tax increment means that portion of the tax levy of all taxing jurisdictions paid each year on real and personal property in the downtown development authority district on the captured assessed value, as more fully described in the downtown development authority development plan and tax increment financing plan. 
    Tax increment financing plan means the "Tax Increment Financing Plan for the City of Utica Downtown Development Authority District," including the development plan, as transmitted to the city board of trustees by the downtown development authority for public hearing, and as confirmed by this article, copies of which are on file in the office of the city clerk. 
    Taxing jurisdiction means each unit of government levying an ad valorem property tax on property in the downtown development authority district. 
(Ord. No. 127,  1, 5-14-1991) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally,  1-2. 
Sec. 18-62. - Approval and adoption of plan. 
(a)	Pursuant to section 19(1) of Act 197, the common council hereby finds and determines in accordance with section 19(1) of Public Act No. 197 of 1975 (MCL 125.1669(1)) as follows: 
(1)	That the development plan and tax increment financing plan constitutes and embodies a public purpose of the city; 
(2)	That the development plan and tax increment financing plan meets the requirements set forth in sections 14(2) and 17(2) of Public Act No. 197 of 1975 (MCL 125.1664(2), 125.1667(2); 
(3)	That the proposed method of financing the development activities described in the development plan and tax increment financing plan is feasible, and that the downtown development authority has the ability to arrange the financing; 
(4)	That the development activities described in the development plan and tax increment financing plan are reasonable and necessary to carry out the purposes of Public Act No. 197 of 1975 (MCL 125.1651 et seq.); 
(5)	That the land to be acquired within the downtown development authority district is reasonably necessary to carry out the purposes of the development plan and tax increment financing plan and the purposes of Public Act No. 197 of 1975 (MCL 125.1651 et seq.); 
(6)	That the development plan and tax increment financing plan is in reasonable accord with the approved master plan of the city; 
(7)	That public services, such as fire and police protection and utilities are, or will be, adequate to service the downtown development authority district; and 
(8)	That such changes in zoning, streets, street levels, intersections, and utilities as are contemplated by the development plan and tax increment financing plan are reasonably necessary for the project and for the city. 
(b)	In accordance with the considerations in subsection (a) of this section, the downtown development authority development plan and tax increment financing plan are hereby approved and adopted for all purposes of Public Act No. 197 of 1975 (MCL 125.1651 et seq.) consistent with such plans, with the following additions, modifications and/or conditions: 
(1)	Delete Ruby Street closing from the project plan list.
(2)	Amend the parking study project to include parking lot improvement program and to advance this project in years. 
(3)	Include the plan rebate amount of $22,500.00.
(c)	A copy of the development plan and tax increment financing plan, and all respective amendments thereto, shall be maintained on file in the city clerk's office and cross-indexed to this article. 
(Ord. No. 127,  2, 5-14-1991) 
Sec. 18-63. - Boundaries of development area. 
    The boundaries of the development area are hereby adopted and confirmed. 
(Ord. No. 127,  3, 5-14-1991) 
State law reference- Development and tax increment financing plan, MCL 125.1664 et seq. 
Sec. 18-64. - Preparation of annual assessment roll. 
    Each year within 15 days following the final equalization of property in the development district, the city assessor shall prepare an updated annual assessment roll. The annual assessment roll shall show the information required in the base year assessment roll and, in addition, the captured assessed value for that year. Copies of the annual assessment roll shall be transmitted by the assessor to the same persons as the base year assessment roll, together with a notice that it has been prepared in accordance with this article and the development plan and tax increment financing plan. 
(Ord. No. 127,  5, 5-14-1991) 
Sec. 18-65. - Account status report. 
    Annually, the downtown development authority shall submit to the governing body of the municipality and the state tax commission a report on the status of the tax increment financing account. The report shall include: 
(1)	The amount and source of revenue in the account;
(2)	The amount and purpose of expenditures from the account;
(3)	The amount of principle and interest on any outstanding bonded indebtedness;
(4)	The initial assessed value of the project area;
(5)	The captured assessed value retained by the authority;
(6)	The tax increments received; and
(7)	Any additional information the governing body or the state tax commission considers necessary. 
The report shall be published in a newspaper of general circulation in the city. 
(Ord. No. 127,  6, 5-14-1991) 
Sec. 18-66. - Implementation. 
    All tax increments shall be transmitted by the city treasurer into an account of the downtown development authority at the earliest practicable date. All tax increments, so received by the downtown development authority, shall be disbursed in accordance with the provisions of the development plan and tax increment financing plan and the requisitions of the downtown development authority. Surplus funds shall revert proportionately to the respective taxing bodies. For the purpose of segregation and transfer of such funds, the city treasurer shall maintain a separate fund which shall be kept in a depository bank account or accounts in a bank or banks approved by the common council, to be designated downtown development authority project fund. All amounts payable to the downtown development authority shall, subject to the foregoing, be deposited directly in the downtown development authority project fund. 
(Ord. No. 127,  7, 5-14-1991) 
Sec. 18-67. - Duration of tax increment financing plan. 
    The tax increment financing plan will continue in effect until all purposes of the development plan and tax increment financing plan have been fulfilled. 
(Ord. No. 127,  8, 5-14-1991) 
Chapter 22 - EMERGENCY SERVICES AND EMERGENCY MANAGEMENT 
FOOTNOTE(S):
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Businesses, ch. 14; fire prevention and protection, ch. 30; law enforcement, ch. 42. (Back)
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 22-1. - Ambulance service. 
(a)	The city, under the direction of the fire department, shall operate an ambulance for emergency service. 
(b)	All charges for emergency ambulance service shall be collected and kept in a separate account to be maintained and the funds thus collected may be used to pay costs of operation and the replacement/maintenance of fire and ambulance equipment. 
(Ord. No. 82,  1-3, 6-9-1969; Ord. No. 82A, 1-11-1971; Ord. No. 82B, 10-12-1976; Ord. No. 82C, 1-14-1992; Ord. No. 82D, 6-8-1992; Ord. No. 82E, 3-11-2008) 
Secs. 22-2-22-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - EMERGENCY MANAGEMENT 

FOOTNOTE(S):
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Emergency management, MCL 30.401 et seq.; local emergency management, MCL 30.410. (Back)
Sec. 22-31. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Coordinator means a person appointed to coordinate emergency planning and services within the city or as prescribed in this article. In the absence of an appointed person, the term "coordinator" shall mean the mayor. 
    Deputy coordinator means the person appointed to provide liaison services between the city and the county office of emergency services. 
    Disaster means an occurrence or threat of widespread or severe damage, injury, or loss of life or property resulting from a natural or manmade cause, including, but not limited to, fire, flood, snowstorm, ice storm, tornado, windstorm, wave action, oil spill, water contamination, utility failure, hazardous peacetime radiological incident, major transportation accident, hazardous materials incident, epidemic, air contamination, blight, drought, infestation, explosion, or hostile military action or paramilitary action, or similar occurrences resulting from terrorist activities, riots, or civil disorders. 
    District coordinator means the state police district emergency services coordinator or his authorized representative. 
    Emergency operations plan means the city emergency operations plan which has been prepared under subsection 22-35(a) to coordinate disaster response and recovery within the city. 
    Emergency services shall have a broad meaning to include preparations for, and relief from, the effects of natural and manmade disasters as defined in this section, and to include civil defense. 
    Emergency services forces means all disaster relief forces; all agencies of the municipal government, private and volunteer personnel, public officers and employees; and all other persons or groups of persons having duties or responsibilities under this article or pursuant to a lawful order or directive authorized by this article. 
    Emergency services volunteer means any person duly registered and appointed by the coordinator and assigned to participate in the emergency services activity. 
    Emergency situation means any situation confronting a community requiring emergency actions of a lesser nature than a disaster, as defined in this section, to include, but not limited to, civil disturbances, labor strikes, visits by national or international dignitaries, and buildup activities prior to an actual disaster. 
    State of disaster means a declaration by executive order or proclamation by the governor under the provisions of Public Act No. 390 of 1976 (MCL 30.401 et seq.), which activities the disaster response and recovery aspects of state, local, and interjurisdictional disaster emergency plans and authorizes the deployment and use of any forces to which the plan or plans apply. 
    State of emergency means a declaration by the mayor pursuant to this article which activates the disaster response and recovery aspects of the city emergency operations plan and authorizes the deployment and use of any municipal forces to which the plan applies. 
(Ord. No. 115, art. 2, 8-10-1982) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally,  1-2. 
Sec. 22-32. - Intent and purpose. 
    It is the intent and purpose of this article to establish the position of deputy emergency services coordinators to provide liaison between this municipality and the county and to ensure complete and efficient utilization of all resources during periods of emergency. 
(Ord. No. 115, art. 1, 8-10-1982) 
Sec. 22-33. - Emergency services coordinator. 
    The emergency services coordinator of the county, in accordance with Public Act No. 390 of 1976 (MCL 30.401 et seq.) and the county emergency services resolution, is the coordinator of emergency services activities in the political subdivisions within the county. 
(Ord. No. 115, art. 1,  2, 8-10-1982) 
Cross reference- Officers and employees,  2-61 et seq. 
Sec. 22-34. - Responsibilities of elected officials; work of volunteer agencies. 
    This article will not relieve any elected official or municipal department of the normal responsibilities or authority given by general law or ordinance, nor will it affect the work of the American Red Cross or other volunteer agencies organized for relief in natural disaster. 
(Ord. No. 115, art. 1,  3, 8-10-1982) 
Sec. 22-35. - Organization for emergency services. 
(a)	The mayor, with the approval of the council, is hereby authorized and directed to prepare for community disasters, utilizing to the fullest extent existing agencies within the municipality. The mayor, as executive head of the municipal government, shall be responsible for the organization, administration and operation of the municipality's emergency services forces, if any, working through the county emergency services coordinator and the city deputy coordinator. 
(b)	The employees, equipment, and facilities of all municipal departments, boards, agencies, and commissions suitable for, or adaptable to emergency service activities may be designated as part of the total emergency services forces of the county. Such designations shall be made by the chair of the county board of commissioners with the approval of the common council. 
(Ord. No. 115, art. 3,  1, 2, 8-10-1982) 
Sec. 22-36. - Deputy emergency services coordinators. 
    The mayor, with the approval of the council, shall appoint deputy emergency services coordinators who shall be persons with the personal attributes and experience to provide liaison services to county officials and to coordinate the activities of certain designated municipal departments, boards, agencies, and commissioners to protect the public health, safety, and welfare during emergency situations or disasters. 
(Ord. No. 115, art. 4,  1, 8-10-1982) 
Cross reference- Officers and employees,  2-61 et seq. 
Secs. 22-37-22-60. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - INCIDENTS INVOLVING HAZARDOUS WASTES 

FOOTNOTE(S):
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference- Solid waste, ch. 54. (Back)
Sec. 22-61. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Act means any state or federal statute, or any rules or regulations adopted pursuant thereto, relating to hazardous substances. 
    Costs and expenses incurred means the actual labor costs of the city for full-time, part-time, or volunteer personnel together with costs and expenses for all fringe benefits, administrative overhead, materials, disposal costs, and an allocation of a reasonable market, rental rate for equipment. 
    Hazardous incident means an occurrence involving a hazardous substance whereby either or both of the following occurs: 
(1)	Person or persons are endangered, injured or killed;
(2)	Property is endangered, damaged or destroyed.
    Hazardous substance means one or more of the following: 
(1)	A chemical or other material which is or may become injurious to the public health, safety, or welfare or to the environment; 
(2)	"Hazardous substance" as defined in the comprehensive environmental response, compensation, and liability act of 1980, Public Law 96-510, 94 Stat. 2767. 
(3)	"Hazardous waste" as defined in section 11103 of the Natural Resources and Environmental Protection Act (MCL 324.11103). 
(4)	Petroleum which means a regulated substance as defined in section 21303 of the Natural Resources and Environmental Protection Act (MCL 324.21303). 
    Hazardous substance emergency means that persons or property are in imminent danger of injury, death, or destruction from a hazardous substance. 
(Ord. No. 126,  1, 3-12-1991) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally,  1-2. 
Sec. 22-62. - Liability. 
(a)	Any person that causes a hazardous incident shall be strictly liable for all costs and expenses incurred by the city to contain, remove, investigate and abate the hazardous incident. 
(b)	Any person that deliberately sets or causes any fire, explosion or other destructive force for the injury or destruction of property shall be liable for all costs and expenses incurred by the city to contain, remove, investigate and abate the fire, explosion, or destructive force. 
(c)	The owner, operator, employer, contractor, or lessor of a person causing a hazardous incident is vicariously and jointly liable for all costs and expenses incurred by the city. 
(Ord. No. 126,  2, 3-12-1991) 
Sec. 22-63. - Enforcement. 
    The mayor is authorized to enforce any liability imposed by this article or by any law by the appropriate means, including civil litigation. 
(Ord. No. 126,  3, 3-12-1991) 
Secs. 22-64-22-90. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - ALARM SYSTEMS 
FOOTNOTE(S):
--- (4) --- 
State Law reference- Alarm systems, MCL 338.1051 et seq. (Back)
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 22-91. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Alarm system means any mechanical or electrical device, or any assembly of equipment and devices, which when activated, signal the presence of a hazard or condition requiring urgent attention and to which police officers, fire department or EMS personnel may be summoned, directly or indirectly, and are expected to respond to. The term "alarm system" in this chapter, shall include: "hold-up alarm system," "burglar alarm system," "intrusion alarm system," "panic alarm system," "personal emergency response system," "temperature fire alarm system," "manual fire alarm system," "fire alarm system," "automatic sprinkler and/or water flow alarm system." Alarm systems on motor vehicles shall be excluded from the definition and operation of this article unless the motor vehicle alarm is connected to the alarm system at the premises owned and/or leased by the user/subscriber. Also excluded are internal alarm systems designed solely to alert or signal person(s) within the premises in which the alarm system is located of an unauthorized intrusion or the presence of a hazard within the premises. If such an internal system, however, also employs an audible or visual signal designed to signal persons outside the premises, such an alarm system is within the provision of this section. 
    Automatic telephone dialing alarm system means a device, equipment or a combination thereof that will, upon activation, either mechanically, electronically or by other means initiate the automatic calling or dialing or connection to any telephone number assigned to any police department, fire department or public service utility by a public telephone company for the purpose of delivering a recorded message. 
    False alarm means any alarm condition which is registered at or reported to the city police department, fire department or elsewhere through mechanical failure, malfunction, improper installation, or negligence or mistake of the owner or user/subscriber or their agent or employee. Also included is any alarm condition registered at or reported to the police department, fire department or elsewhere not resulting from criminal activity or for which the alarm was intended, or in the case of a fire alarm, any alarm condition not resulting from a fire or potential fire condition, or for the need of medical attention. The term "false alarms" shall not include: 
(1)	Severe storm conditions;
(2)	Utility pole accidents;
(3)	Testing of the alarm system when prior notification has been received by the police and/or fire department; 
(4)	False alarms activated by disruption or disturbance of Michigan Bell lines or facilities;
(5)	Documented extenuating circumstances beyond the reasonable control of user provided no prior similar circumstances applied to the user. 
    User/subscriber means any person, firm, corporation who is the owner, jointly or severally, with any person, firm, or corporation who is a tenant or occupant of premises in which an alarm system is installed and maintained; or a person, firm or corporation who is a tenant or occupant of premises, in which an alarm system is installed and maintained, and who has complied with the registration and permit provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. 134,  2.01, 4-11-1995) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally,  1-2. 
Sec. 22-92. - Violations declared misdemeanor. 
    Except as otherwise provided by law or as otherwise stated in this article, violations of this article are a misdemeanor. As a condition of sentence, the court may order restitution to the city of any false alarm fees or other fees provided in this article. 
(Ord. No. 134,  13.01, 4-11-1995) 
Sec. 22-93. - Exception for single-family residential structures. 
    This article shall not apply to single-family residential structures. 
(Ord. No. 134,  2.01(E), 4-11-1995) 
Sec. 22-94. - Effective date; liability for violations. 
    Any person using, owning, leasing, or occupying a premises in which an alarm system exists on the effective date of Ordinance No. 134 shall comply with the requirements of this article by July 1, 1995, and shall be jointly and severally liable for violations of this article. Failure to comply with this section would result in a $50.00 fine. 
(Ord. No. 134,  11.01, 4-11-1995) 
Sec. 22-95. - Automatic telephone dialing alarm system prohibited. 
    No person shall sell, install, operate, adjust, arrange for, or contract to provide a device which upon activation, either mechanically, electronically or by any other means, initiates the automatic calling or dialing of, or makes a connection directly to a telephone assigned to any police department, fire department or public service utility for the purpose of delivering a recorded message. 
(Ord. No. 134,  3.01, 4-11-1995) 
Sec. 22-96. - Licensing of contractors required. 
(a)	No person shall engage in the business of providing for the installation, operation and/or maintenance of an alarm system and/or a combined alarm monitoring sales facility unless properly licensed by the state pursuant to Public Act No. 330 of 1968 (MCL 338.1051 et seq.) and such other statutes or regulations applicable to alarm systems. 
(b)	It shall be unlawful for any person who is an alarm contractor, or it's agent or employee, to knowingly misrepresent any services rendered to an alarm user/subscriber. 
(Ord. No. 134,  5.01, 5.02, 4-11-1995) 
Sec. 22-97. - Separate systems required. 
    Buildings having more than one occupant who utilize separate entrances for access to their individual units shall have separate alarm systems for each unit. This section shall not be construed to require the installation of alarm systems, but only to require separate systems for separate units when installed. 
(Ord. No. 134,  7.01, 4-11-1995) 
State law reference- Fire alarm contractors, MCL 338.883f et seq. 
Sec. 22-98. - Audible and/or visual alarms. 
(a)	No person shall maintain an alarm system which, when activated, causes an audible and/or visual signal which can be heard or seen outside the premises and which is disturbing to the peace and quiet of the surrounding area, unless that person, firm or corporation has first provided the city police department and/or fire department with the following: their name, telephone number, address of the alarmed premises, and the names and telephone numbers of other persons who, having access to the alarmed premises, can be contacted at any time and can respond within 30 minutes to deactivate the audible and/or visible signal. 
(b)	No person shall use, install, or direct to be installed any audible security alarm system which emits a sound alarm for a period longer than 15 minutes from the time of the initial sounding of the device. 
(Ord. No. 134,  6.01, 6.02, 4-11-1995) 
Sec. 22-99. - Defective alarms. 
    An alarm system signaling more than five false alarms within a calendar year is presumed to be defective. Upon written notice, the user/subscriber of the building or residence shall have the alarm system inspected by a licensed alarm system contractor within ten days and shall forward to the city police department and/or fire department the contractor's report of the probable cause of the false alarms and the measures instituted to eliminate the false alarms. 
(Ord. No. 134,  9.01, 4-11-1995) 
State law reference- Correction of systems giving false alarms, MCL 38.1085. 
Secs. 22-100-22-115. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - PERMIT 

Sec. 22-116. - Required. 
(a)	No person shall install, possess, operate or maintain or take possession of any premises equipped with an alarm system, after the effective date of the ordinance from which this article is derived without first obtaining a permit from the city. 
(b)	A permit shall be issued by the city upon the completion and approval of the alarm user registration form and payment of the required fee. 
(Ord. No. 134,  4.01, 4-11-1995) 
Sec. 22-117. - Registration. 
(a)	The alarm user registration form must be completed and signed by both the owner, tenant or occupant, if any, of the premises on which the alarm system is maintained. 
(b)	The alarm user registration form shall include the following:
(1)	Address and telephone number of the premises on which the alarm system is maintained;
(2)	Name, address and telephone number of the owner of the premises;
(3)	Name, address and telephone number of the tenant or occupant, if any, of the premises;
(4)	Name, address and telephone number of the person, firm or corporation responsible for the installation and/or service of the alarm system; 
(5)	Names, addresses and telephone numbers of all persons responsible for the deactivation or resetting of the alarm system or device, checking the premises or responding to notices from the police department, fire department or public service utility of an activation of the alarm system; 
(6)	Description of the alarm system;
(7)	Any additional information as the police department and fire department may deem necessary.
(c)	All applicants registering an alarm system shall be furnished a copy of this article along with the registration form. Receipt of this article by the applicant shall constitute notice to such applicant of his obligations and liabilities under this article. 
(d)	The registration form shall contain a statement, signed by the alarm user/subscriber who is applying for a permit under these sections, that such applicant has read the copy of the ordinance provided and is signing the application with full knowledge and understanding of the provisions of this article and their duties and liabilities under this article. 
(e)	Upon issuance of the permit, the holder thereof shall notify the police department and/or fire department immediately of any changes to the information provided in the application for the permit. Failure to notify the department shall constitute a violation of this article and be subject to the penalty provided in section 22-92 and, in the case of a nonmandatory alarm system, a revocation of the permit. 
(Ord. No. 134,  4.02, 4-11-1995) 
Sec. 22-118. - Fees. 
(a)	A permit fee in the amount established by resolution shall be assessed to new registrations. The permit shall be issued by the city clerk upon the recommendation of the police chief or fire chief. 
(b)	There shall be no prorating of charges or refunds for voluntary cancellation or revocation for a violation of this article. 
(c)	The tenant or occupant of the premises may obtain an alarm system permit without the owner's signature by depositing a cash bond in the amount established by resolution with the city treasurer's office. 
(1)	The cash bond may be applied against any delinquent charges, penalties, fees or costs and the use of such cash bond for such charges, penalties, fees or costs shall not affect any rights of the police department and/or fire department to revoke an alarm system permit, or otherwise enforce the provisions of this article. 
(2)	Such cash bond shall always be maintained at the required amount. Failure of an alarm user/subscriber who has posted such bond to restore the deposit to that amount after the deduction of any penalties, charges, fees or costs within 30 days from the date of notice of such deficiency is mailed, shall, without further action, cancel and render void the alarm system permit. 
(3)	No such cash bond shall bear interest and such bond, or any remaining balance thereof, shall be returned to the tenant or occupant depositing the bond when he shall disconnect the alarm system and present satisfactory proof to the police department and/or fire department that the alarm system has been disconnected. The cash bond for a mandatory alarm system shall not be returned until such time as the new owner, tenant or occupant has posted a bond, or proof is presented to demonstrate that the future use of the structure does not require a mandatory alarm system. 
(Ord. No. 134,  4.03, 4-11-1995) 
Sec. 22-119. - Display of permit. 
    The permit shall be kept on the premises to which it relates, and shall be available for production upon request of the police department or fire department. If the permit is damaged, lost destroyed or stolen, the permit holder shall notify the police department and/or fire department and request a replacement permit. 
(Ord. No. 134,  4.04, 4-11-1995) 
Sec. 22-120. - Replacement. 
    In the event of loss, destruction, damage or theft of the permit, a replacement permit will be issued at a charge in the amount established by resolution, upon written request that the original permit was lost, damaged, destroyed or stolen and that the permit requested will be used as a replacement only. 
(Ord. No. 134,  4.05, 4-11-1995) 
Sec. 22-121. - Illegal use. 
(a)	It shall be unlawful for any person to use a permit for any premises other than those identified on the application for the permit. 
(b)	It shall be unlawful for any person to cause an alarm system permit to be bought, sold or leased, contrary to the terms of this article. 
(c)	It shall be unlawful for any person to buy or otherwise acquire for value or use any alarm system permit, except as provided in this article. 
(d)	Upon conviction of any permit holder of a violation of subsections (b) or (c) of this section, the alarm system permit shall be void and must be surrendered to the police department and/or fire department. 
(Ord. No. 134,  4.06, 4-11-1995) 
Sec. 22-122. - Revocation. 
    An alarm system permit issued by the city may be revoked by the police chief and/or chief of the fire department upon occurrence of any of the following conditions: 
(1)	Furnishing of false or misleading information on the alarm user registration form, or failing to notify the department of any changes to the information provided in the registration form. 
(2)	A violation of section 22-121 
(3)	Failure of the alarm system user/subscriber or the person responsible for deactivation or resetting the alarm system as identified on the alarm user registration form, to respond within 30 minutes of notification by the police department of a response by the department to an activation of the alarm system. 
(4)	Failure to repair or replace an alarm system that is defective after notification by the police department. 
(5)	Any other violation of this article, which in the determination of the police chief and/or chief of the fire department, warrants revocation. 
(Ord. No. 134,  10.01, 4-11-1995) 
Secs. 22-123-22-140. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - FALSE ALARM FEES 

Sec. 22-141. - Generally. 
(a)	Notwithstanding any penalties provided for upon conviction for any violation of this article, and notwithstanding the fact that prosecution for violations of this article has or has not commenced, any person operating an alarm system which signals more than two false alarms as defined in section 22-91 within a one-year period, such period shall be from January 1 through December 31, and shall pay to the city a false alarm fee in order to defray a portion of the cost of response to false alarms. 
(b)	Notwithstanding any penalties provided for upon conviction for any violation of this article, and notwithstanding the fact that prosecution for violations of this article has or has not commenced, any person performing work for the owner or occupant of any property equipped with an alarm system as a contractor, licensed professional or other laborer shall take all steps necessary to properly protect any fire detection or fire suppression system from emitting any false alarm. Such steps shall include at a minimum placing the system in test mode with notification to the alarm company. Such person(s) shall use due care and caution in the performance of their work so as to not cause any false alarm. A violation of this section shall result in liabilities for a false alarm fee for the first and/or subsequent violation. 
(c)	The schedule of false alarm fees shall be as established by the fee schedule adopted by the Macomb County Fire Chief's Association. 
(d)	False alarm fees shall be credited to the applicable departmental equipment reserve.
(Ord. No. 134,  8.01, 4-11-1995; Ord. No. 134-A, 6-21-2006) 
Sec. 22-142. - Police and/or fire department procedures. 
(a)	The police and fire departments shall keep a record of the receipt of false alarms including the date and time of such alarms and the user/subscriber of such alarms. 
(b)	The chief of the respective department or his representative shall, within a reasonable time, upon receipt of a false alarm report, notify the user/subscriber of such false alarm by sending or causing to be sent, by regular mail, an alarm notification form. This form shall inform the user/subscriber of the date and time of the alarm, the results of the responding officers investigation, the applicable provisions of this article and the number of false alarms responded to in the current calendar year. 
(c)	On the occasion of the third false alarm and subsequent false alarms, the chief of the applicable department shall request the issuance of an invoice from the city treasurer's office to the user/subscriber of such alarm, in the appropriate amount, to be mailed with the alarm notification form by regular mail. The mailing of such notice will be prima facie evidence of the receipt of such notice. 
(Ord. No. 134,  8.02, 4-11-1995) 
Sec. 22-143. - User/subscriber procedures. 
(a)	Within 21 days of receipt of the alarm notification form, the alarm system user/subscriber shall return the completed alarm notification form to the police and/or fire department. Failure by the alarm system user/subscriber to return the alarm notification form shall cause an automatic billing of the false alarm fee to be sent to the alarm system user/subscriber by the city treasurer, if indicated. 
(b)	If, upon receiving a false alarm fee invoice, the alarm system user/subscriber wishes to request a waiver of the assessment of the fee due to extenuating circumstances, they may do so in writing within ten working days of the assessment date. The waiver request to the police and/or fire department shall contain documentation of the extenuating circumstances involved. Within ten working days of the receipt of the request for waiver by the applicable department, the chief of such department or his designee shall make a determination on the waiver request and shall notify the alarm system user/subscriber of the decision in writing. 
(c)	In the event that the alarm system user/subscriber is not satisfied with the decision rendered by the chief of the applicable department or his designee, an additional written request for waiver may be filed within ten working days with the mayor. Within ten working days of the receipt of the waiver request and documentation of the extenuating circumstances, the mayor or his designee shall review the request, make a determination on the waiver, and shall notify the alarm system user/subscriber in writing of the decision. An appeal to the common council may be taken within 30 days with council's decision being final. 
(d)	In the event the specified fees are not paid, then all such fees and penalties shall become a lien upon the land where the alarm system is located and may be collected by the addition of the lien to the tax rolls or assessments imposed by the city on the subject property. The owner of record per the tax rolls shall be personally liable in a civil action for such fees together with all costs of collection including reasonable attorney fees. 
(Ord. No. 134,  8.03, 4-11-1995) 
Secs. 22-144-22-160. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - EMERGENCY FEES RECOVERY 

Sec. 22-161. - Short title. 
    This article shall be known as the Emergency Fees Recovery Ordinance. 
(Ord. 155,  1, 9-12-2006) 
Sec. 22-162. - Definitions. 
    Unless the context specifically indicates otherwise, the meaning of the terms used in this ordinance shall be as follows: 
    Assessable fees mean those fees for services incurred by the city in connection with providing emergency services at an emergency incident, including, but not limited to, the actual labor and material costs of the city (including, without limitation, employee wages, operation, costs of materials, costs of transportation, costs of equipment, costs of backup of emergency services., costs of equipment operation, costs of materials, costs of transportation, costs of material disposal and costs of contracted labor) whether or not the services are provided by the city or by a third party on behalf of the city; service charges and interest; attorneys' fees litigation costs and any costs, charges, fines or penalties to the city imposed by any court or state or federal governmental entities. 
    Dangerous materials mean those elements, substances, wastes or by-products, that may include, but not limited to, combustible liquid, flammable gas, explosives, flammables, poisons, organic peroxides, oxidizers, pyrophorics, unstable reactive matter, water reactive matter, petroleum products, anti-freeze, polychlorinated biphenyls and asbestos, which are or are potentially harmful to the environment or human or animal life, or which pose an unreasonable or imminent risk to life, health or safety or persons or property, or to the ecological balance of the environment as determined by the fire chief or the senior fire official of the city in charge at the scene. 
    Dangerous material incident or emergency means any occurrence, incident, activity, accident or emergency where a release of dangerous materials occurs or is reasonably imminent and where the fire chief or his or her designee has so declared such activity, accident or emergency a dangerous material incident or emergency. 
    Emergency incident means (i) motor vehicle accident, or any other event where a motor vehicle or pedestrian, requires emergency services, (ii) a dangerous material incident or emergency, (iii) an illegal fire, (iv) a structure demolition, (v) a utility line failure, or (vi) a railway crossing or line failure. 
    Emergency service means emergency police, fire, ambulance or inhalator services. 
    Hazardous materials means those elements, substances, wastes or by-products regulated by NREPA, MCL 324.20101, et seq, as amended. 
    Hazardous material incident or emergency means any occurrence, incident, activity, accident or emergency where a release of hazardous materials occurs or is reasonably imminent and where the fire chief or his or her designee has so declared such activity, accident or emergency a hazardous material incident or emergency. 
    Illegal fire means a fire set or determined to have been set in violation of a federal, state or local law and shall include an arson fire and a fire set in violation of a "no burning" ban or order. An illegal fire does not include an unintentional fire or fire caused by an act or God, i.e., a lightning storm. 
    Motor vehicle means any self-propelled or towed vehicle designed or used on the public streets, roads and highways to transport passengers or property which is required to be registered for use upon such public streets, roads and highways and for the purposes hereof all trailers or appurtenances attached to any motor vehicle. Motor vehicle also includes motorized farm or construction equipment being operated on a public right of way. 
    NREPA means the Natural Resources and Environmental Protection Act, MCL 324.20101 et seq., as amended. 
    Railway crossing or line failure means the disabling of any railway crossing or railway line so as to pose a danger to the public unless police or fire personnel remain on site to eliminate such danger if the owner or party(s) responsible for the maintenance of such railway crossing or line does not respond within one hour to a request to repair or correct such failure. 
    Release means any actual or threatened spilling, leaking, pumping, pouring, emitting, emptying, discharging, injecting, leaching, dumping or disposing into the environment, including, but not limited, the air, soil, groundwater and surface water. 
    Responsible party means any individual, firm, corporation, association, partnership, commercial entity, consortium, joint venture, government entity or any other legal entity that receives emergency services for an emergency incident or any owner, tenant, occupant or party in control of real and personal property from which, onto which or related to an emergency incident and their heirs, estates, successors and assigns. 
    Structure demolition means the tearing down of a structure damaged by fire which must in the opinion of the fire chief or his or her designee be promptly demolished following the fire to protect public safety. 
    Utility line failure means the disabling of any transmission or service line, cable, conduit, pipeline, wire or the like used to provide, collect or transport electricity, natural gas, communication or electronic signals (including, but not limited to, telephone, computer, cable television and stereo signals or electronic impulses), water or sanitary or storm sewage if the owner or party responsible for the maintenance of such utility line does not respond within one hour to a request to repair or correct such failure. 
(Ord. 155,  2, 9-12-2006) 
Sec. 22-163. - Cost recovery for hazardous materials, incident or emergency. 
    The city shall recover all assessable fees in connection with a hazardous material incident or emergency pursuant to the requirements of NREPA. The fire or police chief, or their designate, shall determine total assessable fees. 
(Ord. 155,  3, 9-12-2006) 
Sec. 22-164. - Fees recovery authorization and procedure, for emergency incidents. 
(a)	The city shall recover all assessable fees in connection with an emergency incident from any and all responsible parties jointly or severally. 
(b)	The fire or police chief or his or her designee shall determine the total assessable fees. 
(Ord. 155,  4, 9-12-2006) 
Sec. 22-165. - Billing and collection of assessable fees. 
    After determining to assess assessable fees against a responsible party, the city treasurer shall mail an itemized invoice to the responsible party at its last known address. Such invoice shall be due and payable within 30 days of the date of mailing and any amounts unpaid after such date shall bear a late payment fee equal to one percent per month or fraction thereof that the amount due and any previously imposed late payment fee remains unpaid. If a responsible party shall appeal assessable fees pursuant to section 22-166 hereof, such fees, if upheld, in whole or in part, shall be due and payable 30 days from the date of determination of the appeal and any late payment fees shall apply thereafter. 
(Ord. 155,  5, 9-12-2006) 
Sec. 22-166. - Procedure for appealing assessable costs. 
    Any responsible party who receives an invoice for assessable fees shall have the right of an appeal to the mayor or his or her designee to request a modification of assessable fees. The responsible party shall request in writing such appeal within 14 calendar days of the date of the invoice assessing the assessable fees. Any appeal shall be in writing and shall specifically identify and explain all reasons why the responsible party believes the assessed fees should be modified. Any reason, basis or argument for modification of assessable fees not set forth in the request to appeal shall be deemed waived by the responsible party. Failure to timely file a written request to appeal shall constitute a waiver of the responsible party's right to appeal and shall further constitute the responsible party's agreement to pay the assessable fees invoiced. Upon receipt of an appeal of assessable fees, the mayor or his or her designate will schedule a hearing no later than 21 days from receipt of the appeal. A notice of hearing will be sent to the responsible party and the official that compiled the assessable fees stating the time and place where the hearing will be held. The mayor or his or her designate may combine for hearing appeals involving the same incident. The mayor or his or her designate shall determine whether to confirm, modify or void the payment of assessable fees invoiced and notify the interested parties immediately or within seven days of the results of the appeal. 
(Ord. 155,  6, 9-12-2006) 
Sec. 22-167. - Assessable fees a lien upon property. 
    Assessable fees assessed against a responsible party not paid when due, including late payment fees, shall constitute a lien upon the real property of the responsible party in the City of Utica, if the emergency incident involved such real property. Such lien shall be of the same character and effect as the lien created for city real property taxes and shall include accrued interest and penalties. The city treasurer shall, prior to March 1 of each year, certify to the city assessor the fact that such assessable fees are delinquent and unpaid. The city assessor shall then enter the delinquent amount on the next general ad valorem tax roll as a charge against the affected property, and the lien thereon shall be enforced in the same manner as provided and allowed by law for delinquent and unpaid real property taxes. 
(Ord. 155,  7, 9-12-2006) 
Sec. 22-168. - Other remedies. 
    In addition to the remedy set forth in section 22-167 above, the city shall be entitled to pursue any other remedy or may institute any appropriate action or proceeding in a court of competent jurisdiction as permitted by law to collect assessable fees from a responsible party. 
(Ord. 155,  8, 9-12-2006) 
Sec. 22-169. - No limitation of liabality. 
    The recovery of assessable costs pursuant hereto does not limit the liability of a responsible party under applicable local, state or federal law. 
(Ord. 155,  9, 9-12-2006) 
Sec. 22-170. - Fee sechedule. 
(a)	Personnel fees:Personnel fees shall be charged at the actual hourly rate paid to the employee, or, if not paid hourly then at the actual estimated effective hourly rate, which includes indirect costs (full/time 45 percent and part/time 11 percent). Personnel fees shall be based upon the time actually spent by the employee and shall be computed to the nearest one-tenth of an hour. Personnel fees shall be computed upon the applicable labor, contract, administrative resolution or the fiscal budget. Personnel fees shall include overtime or premium rates when applicable. 
(b)	Vehicles and equipment fees (computed to the nearest tenth 1/10th of an hour): 
(1)	Police vehicles at the rate of $75.00 per hour.
(2)	Fire and EMS vehicle shall be charged at the rate provided in the fire department's Macomb County Mutual Aid Pact Apparatus and Personnel Charges as updated June 4, 2006, attached hereto. 
(3)	Other vehicles and equipment shall be charged at the rate provided in MDOT Schedule "C" Report 375, Equipment Rental Rates, effective January 1 to December 31, 2006, attached hereto. 
(c)	Other fees: 
(1)	Blood tests: As charged by provider.
(2)	Breathalyzer vials: As charged by provider.
(3)	Rented equipment: As charged by provider.
(4)	Material purchases: As charged by provider.
(5)	Transportation services: As charged by provider.
(6)	Material disposal: As charged by provider.
(7)	Contracted labor: As charged by provider.
(8)	Service charges and interest: As charged by provider.
(9)	Attorney's fees: As charged by provider.
(10)	Litigation: As charged by provider.
(11)	Court/government charges/penalties: As charged by provider.
(12)	External specialists: As charged by provider.
(Ord. 155,  App. A, 9-12-2006) 
Editor's note- 
The Macomb County Mutual Aid Pact Apparatus and Personnel Charges as updated June 4, 2006, and MDOT Schedule "C" Report 375, Equipment Rental Rates, effective January 1 to December 31, 2006, are not set out herein but are available in the office of the city clerk. 
Chapter 26 - ENVIRONMENT 
FOOTNOTE(S):
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Animals, ch. 6; buildings and building regulations, ch. 10; community development, ch. 18; floods, ch. 34; historic preservation, ch. 38; parks and recreation, ch. 50; solid waste, ch. 54; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 62; subdivisions and other divisions of land, ch. 66; utilities, ch. 82; vegetation, ch. 86; preservation of environmental quality, app. A,  1420; zoning, app. A; zoning districts and maps, app. A,  300 et seq. (Back)
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 26-1. - Cleanliness of premises. 
    Every parcel of property including buildings, vacant or occupied and every part thereof, shall be kept clean and shall be kept free from any accumulation of dirt, filth, rubbish, garbage or other matter in or on the property, or in the yards, courts, passages, area of alleys connected therewith or belonging to the property. The owner of every dwelling shall be responsible for keeping the entire building free from vermin. The owner shall also be responsible for complying with the provisions of this section except that the tenants shall be responsible for the cleanliness of those parts of the premises which they occupy and control. Any hazardous places that are necessary during construction must be fenced or boarded up. Property owners and or occupants shall be held responsible for the condition, cleanliness and maintenance of the areas, between their lot lines and the adjoining streets and curbs, where existing. Violations of this section are a misdemeanor. 
(Ord. No. 85,  1, 10-15-1970) 
Sec. 26-2. - Dead animals. 
    No person shall suffer or permit any dead animal or animals to remain on the surface of the ground, or partly buried, on any lot or premises owned or occupied by him. Violation of this section is a misdemeanor. 
(Ord. No. 5,  4) 
Cross reference- Animals, ch. 6; solid waste, ch. 54. 
Secs. 26-3-26-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - BLIGHT 

FOOTNOTE(S):
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Solid waste, ch. 54. (Back)
Sec. 26-31. - Purpose. 
    It is the purpose of this article to prevent, reduce or eliminate blight or potential blight in the city by the prevention or elimination of certain environmental causes of blight or blighting factors which exist or which may in the future exist in the city. 
(Ord. No. 74,  1, 7-11-1967) 
Sec. 26-32. - Violations declared misdemeanor. 
    Except as otherwise provided by law or as otherwise stated in this article, violations of this article are a misdemeanor. 
Sec. 26-33. - Causes of blight or blighting factors. 
    It is hereby determined that the following uses, structures and activities are causes of blight or blighting factors which, if allowed to exist, will tend to result in blighted and undesirable neighborhoods. On and after the effective date of the ordinance from which this article is derived, no person shall maintain or permit to be maintained any of these causes of blight or blighting factors upon any property in the city owned, leased, rented or occupied by such person: 
(1)	In any area zoned for residential purposes, the storage upon any property of junk automobiles, except in a completely enclosed building. For the purpose of this article, the term "junk automobiles" shall include any motor vehicle which is not licensed for use upon the highways of the state for a period in excess of 60 days, and shall also include, whether so licensed or not, any motor vehicle which is inoperative for any reason for a period in excess of 60 days. 
(2)	In any area zoned for residential purposes, the storage upon any property of building materials unless there is in force a valid building permit issued by the city for construction upon such property and such materials are intended for use in connection with such construction. Building materials shall include but not be limited to lumber, bricks, concrete or cinder blocks, plumbing materials, electrical wiring or equipment, heating ducts or equipment, shingles, mortar, concrete or cement, nails, screws, or any other materials used in constructing any structure. 
(3)	In any area zoned for residential purposes, the storage or accumulation of junk, trash, rubbish or refuse of any kind, except domestic refuse stored in such a manner as not to create a nuisance for a period not to exceed 30 days. The term "junk" shall include parts of machinery or motor vehicles, unused stoves or other appliances stored in the open, remnants of woods, metal or any other material or other castoff material of any kind whether or not such material could be put to any reasonable use. 
(4)	In any area, the existence of any structure or part of any structure which because of fire, wind or other natural disaster, or physical deterioration is no longer habitable, if a dwelling, nor useful or any other purpose for which it may have been intended. 
(5)	In any area zoned for residential purposes, the existence of any vacant dwelling, garage or other outbuilding unless such buildings are kept securely locked, windows kept glazed or neatly boarded up and otherwise protected to prevent entrance thereto by vandals. 
(6)	In any area, the existence of any partially completed structure unless such structure is in the course of construction in accordance with a valid and subsisting building permit issued by the city and unless such construction is completed within a reasonable time. 
(Ord. No. 74,  2, 7-11-1967) 
Sec. 26-34. - Enforcement. 
(a)	This article shall be enforced by such persons who shall be so designated by the common council. 
(b)	The owner, if possible, and the occupant of any property upon which any of the causes of blight or blighting factors set forth in section 26-33 is found to exist shall be notified in writing to remove or eliminate such causes of blight or blighting factors from such property within ten days after service of the notice upon him. Such notice may be served personally or by registered mail, return receipt requested. Additional time may be granted by the enforcement officer where bona fide efforts to remove or eliminate such causes of blight or blighting factors are in progress. 
(c)	Failure to comply with such notice within the time allowed by the owner and/or occupant shall constitute a violation of this article. 
(Ord. No. 74,  3, 7-11-1967) 
Chapter 30 - FIRE PREVENTION AND PROTECTION 
FOOTNOTE(S):

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 30-1-30-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - FIRE SAFETY 
FOOTNOTE(S):
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- State fire prevention code, MCL 29.1 et seq. (Back)
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 30-31. - Violations declared misdemeanor. 
    Except as otherwise provided by law or as otherwise stated in this article, violations of this article are a misdemeanor. 
Sec. 30-32. - Enforcement. 
    Enforcement of this article may be made by the city fire chief, fire inspectors, and the city police department. Such enforcement officers shall have the authority to issue appearance citations pursuant to Public Act No. 175 of 1927 (MCL 760.1 et seq.) for violations of this section. 
(Ord. No. 147,  3(I), 3-13-2001; Ord. No. 151,  3(I), 3-11-2003; Ord. No. 157,  3, 2-12-2008) 
Sec. 30-33. - Authority at fires and other emergencies. 
(a)	Fire chief. The fire chief or his duly authorized representative, as may be in charge at the scene of a fire or other emergency involving the protection of life and/or property, is empowered to direct such operations as may be necessary to extinguish or control any suspected or reported fires, gas leaks, or other hazardous conditions or situations, or of taking any other action necessary in the reasonable performance of their duty. 
(b)	Police or fire officials. A police or fire official depending on who is in charge of a particular emergency situation: 
(1)	May prohibit any person, vehicle, or object from approaching the scene;
(2)	May remove or cause to be removed from the scene any person, vehicle, or object from approaching the scene; and 
(3)	May remove or cause to be removed from the scene any person, vehicle, or object which may impede or interfere with the operations of the fire department. 
(c)	Fire officials. The fire official may remove or cause to be removed any person, vehicle, or object from a hazardous area and any such person, vehicle, or object shall do so immediately and shall not reenter the area until authorized to do so by the fire official. 
(Ord. No. 147,  3(A), 3-13-2001; Ord. No. 151,  3(A), 3-11-2003; Ord. No. 157,  3, 2-12-2008) 
Sec. 30-34. - Interference with department operations. 
    It shall be unlawful to interfere with, attempt to interfere with, conspire to interfere with, obstruct or restrict the mobility of, or block the path of travel of any fire department emergency vehicle in any way, or to interfere with, attempt to interfere with, conspire to interfere with, obstruct or tamper any fire department operation. 
(Ord. No. 147,  3(B), 3-13-2001; Ord. No. 151,  3(B), 3-11-2003; Ord. No. 157,  3, 2-12-2008) 
Sec. 30-35. - Compliance with orders. 
    A person shall not willfully fail or refuse to comply with any lawful order or direction of the fire official or to interfere with the compliance attempts of another individual. 
(Ord. No. 147,  3(C), 3-13-2001; Ord. No. 151,  3(C), 3-11-2003; Ord. No. 157,  3, 2-12-2008) 
Sec. 30-36. - Fire suppression equipment. 
(a)	Maintenance of. A person shall not obstruct, remove, tamper with or otherwise disturb any fire hydrant or fire appliance required to be installed or maintained under the provisions of the fire prevention code, adopted in division 2 of this article, except for the purpose of extinguishing fire, training or testing purposes, recharging, or making necessary repairs, or when permitted by the fire official. 
(b)	Immediate replacement. 
(1)	After permitted use. Whenever a fire appliance is removed as permitted in this section, it shall be replaced or reinstalled as soon as the purpose for which it was removed has been accomplished. 
(2)	Defective/nonapproved. Defective and nonapproved fire appliances or equipment shall be replaced or repaired as directed by the fire official. 
(Ord. No. 147,  3(H), 3-13-2001; Ord. No. 151,  3(H), 3-11-2003; Ord. No. 157,  3, 2-12-2008) 
Sec. 30-37. - Authorized emergency vehicles/equipment. 
(a)	Defined. Authorized emergency vehicles shall be restricted to those, which are defined and authorized under the laws of the State of Michigan. 
(b)	Yielding Right-of-Way. Upon the approach of any authorized emergency vehicle, giving audible and visual signal, the operator of every other vehicle shall immediately drive the same to the position as near as possible and parallel to the right-hand edge or curb of the street or roadway, clear of any intersection, and shall have passed, unless otherwise directed by a police or fire official. 
(c)	Following prohibited. It shall be unlawful for the operator of any vehicle, other than one on official business, to follow closer than 500 feet from any fire apparatus traveling in response to a fire alarm, or to drive any vehicle within the block or immediate area where fire apparatus has stopped in answer to a fire alarm. 
(d)	Unlawful boarding or tampering. A person shall not without proper authorization from the fire official in charge of said fire department emergency equipment, cling to, attach himself to, to climb upon or into, board, or swing upon any fire department emergency vehicle, whether the same is in motion or at rest, or sound the siren, horn, bell, or other sound producing device thereon, or to manipulate or tamper with any levers, valves, switches, starting devices, breaks, pumps, or any equipment or protective clothing on or a part of any fire department emergency vehicle. 
(e)	Driving over fire hoses. A vehicle shall not be driven or propelled over any unprotected fire hose of the fire department when laid down on any street, alley-way, private drive or any other vehicular roadway without the consent of the fire official in command of said operations. 
(Ord. No. 147,  3(D)(4), 3-13-2001; Ord. No. 151,  3(D)(4), 3-11-2003; Ord. No. 157,  3, 2-12-2008) 
Sec. 30-38. - Damage or injury to equipment/personnel. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to damage or deface, or attempt or conspire to damage or deface any fire department emergency vehicle at any time, or to injure, or attempt to injure fire department personnel while performing departmental duties. 
(Ord. No. 147,  3(E), 3-13-2001; Ord. No. 151,  3(E), 3-11-2003;Ord. No. 157,  3, 2-12-2008) 
State law reference- Injury to fire department equipment, MCL 750.377b. 
Sec. 30-39. - Hydrant and department connections. 
(a)	Restriction access unlawful. It shall be unlawful to obscure from view, damage, deface or obstruct or restrict the access to any fire hydrant or any fire department connection for the pressurization of fire suppression systems, including fire hydrants and fire department connections that are located on public or private streets and access lanes, or on private property. 
(b)	Violations. 
(1)	Removal after notification. If, upon the expiration of the time mentioned in a notice of violation, obstructions or encroachments are not removed, the code official shall proceed to remove the obstructions or encroachments. 
(2)	Cost. Cost incurred in the performance of necessary work shall be paid from the municipal treasury on certificate of the fire official and with the approval of the chief administrative official and the city, shall institute appropriate action for the recovery of such costs. 
(3)	Location and placement. At the time of development of commercial, industrial and multiple-family properties, fire hydrants shall be located not more than 300 feet apart, measured along paved streets or driveways. Hydrants shall also be located at each intersection, subject to the exception that the code official may suspend hydrant spacing requirements for premises protected by a fire suppression system. 
(4)	Use approval required. A person shall not use or operate any fire hydrant intended for the use of the fire department for fire suppression purposes unless such person first secures a permission for such use from the department of public works after approval from the fire department. The code official may order the disconnection from any fire hydrant if it is necessary for firefighting purposes, or if there is any unauthorized device, vehicle or equipment connected to a fire hydrant. 
(Ord. No. 147,  3(G), 3-13-2001; Ord. No. 151,  3(G), 3-11-2003; Ord. No. 157,  3, 2-12-2008) 
Cross reference- Utilities, ch. 82. 
Secs. 30-40-30-54. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - FIRE PREVENTION CODE 

FOOTNOTE(S):
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference- Buildings and building regulations, ch. 10. (Back)
Sec. 30-55. - Purpose. 
    A fire prevention code prescribing regulations governing conditions hazardous to life and property from fire or explosion is hereby adopted, and other fire regulations are established. 
(Ord. No. 151,  1, 3-11-2003; Ord. No. 157,  1, 2-12-2008) 
Sec. 30-56. - Fire prevention code adopted. 
    There is hereby adopted by the city for the purpose of prescribing regulations governing conditions hazardous to life and property from fire or explosion, that certain code known as the International Fire Code, 2000 edition, published by the International Code Council thereof, copy of such code shall be maintained on file in the office of the city clerk, and such code is hereby adopted and incorporated in this section, as if set out at length in this section. From the date on which the ordinance from which this section is derived shall take effect, the provisions of such code, with any modifications in this division, shall be controlling within the limits of the city. 
(Ord. No. 147,  2(A), 3-13-2001; Ord. No. 151,  2(A), 3-11-2003; Ord. No. 157,  1, 2-12-2008) 
State law reference- Adoption by reference, MCL 117.4(k). 
Sec. 30-57. - Amendments to Code. 
    The International Fire Code, 2000 edition, shall be amended as set forth in the following subsections of this section:
