(Ord. No. 140,  1(15), 2-11-1997) 
Sec. 74-36. - Unauthorized tapping, tampering or connecting prohibited. 
    No person shall tap, tamper with or connect, or cause to be tapped, tampered with or connected, any wire or device, whether physically, electrically, acoustically, inductively or otherwise, to any wire, cable, conduit, apparatus or equipment of a cable television company without authorization from the cable television company owning or controlling such wire, cable, conduit, apparatus or equipment. Notwithstanding any other provision of this article or any franchise agreement entered into pursuant to subsection 74-57(a), a cable television company may discontinue service to any person who is violating this section. The provisions of this section shall be enforced by the city police department. 
(Ord. No. 140,  1(19)-(21), 2-11-1997) 
State law reference- Tampering with utility property, MCL 750.383a. 
Secs. 74-37-74-55. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - FRANCHISE 

FOOTNOTE(S):
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Businesses, ch. 14. (Back)
Sec. 74-56. - Required. 
(a)	No person shall construct, install, maintain or operate a cable television system in the city nor shall any person provide a cable television service or acquire ownership or control of a cable television company in the city without such person having first obtained a franchise therefor from the city in the form of a franchise agreement between the city and the cable television company, which franchise agreement shall include, at a minimum, compliance with the specifications of this article, except as otherwise set forth in such agreement. 
(b)	No person shall use, occupy or traverse the right-of-way or any extensions thereof or additions thereto, whether on, above, or under the surface of the ground, for the purposes of installing, constructing, maintaining or operating a cable television system or facilities therefor or for the purpose of furnishing a cable television service without such person having first obtained a franchise therefor from the city in the form of a franchise agreement between the city and the cable television company, which franchise agreement shall include, at a minimum, compliance with all the specifications of this article, except as otherwise set forth in such agreement. 
(Ord. No. 140,  1(4)(a), (b), 2-11-1997) 
Sec. 74-57. - Initial request for franchise; contents; fees; issuance; transfer. 
(a)	The request for an initial franchise to install, construct, maintain or operate a cable television system in the city or to furnish a cable television service shall be made in writing to the common council in such form as may be prescribed. The request shall be accompanied by a fee of $5,000.00 which fee shall be used to cover expenses, direct or indirect, incurred by the city in the preparation of this article, amendments to this article, development of proposal solicitation documents and any amendments, and reviewing, investigating and evaluating the proposals submitted. 
(b)	Upon the filing of such a request and the payment of the fee as prescribed, the common council shall consider the request and may seek such additional information as it may deem necessary to establish the legal, financial, technical and other qualifications of the applicant to provide a cable television service in the city. 
(c)	If the council determines that the applicant possesses the necessary qualifications, legal, financial, technical and otherwise to reasonably ensure the applicant's ability to satisfactorily install, construct, maintain and operate a cable television system or to furnish a cable television service to the public in the city, the common council may issue a nonexclusive franchise therefor in the city. No franchise shall be issued until the council has held a public hearing on such request after due notice of the time and place of such hearing has been given to the public. 
(d)	In determining whether such a franchise shall be issued, the council shall take into consideration, among other things, the applicant's technical qualifications; financial responsibility and ability to perform efficiently the service for which the franchise is requested, including the prior experience, if any, in providing cable television systems or furnishing cable television service; the proposed rate schedule; the nature and scope of the proposed system; and the timetables for development of the proposed system. 
(e)	Neither a franchise nor a cable system shall be sold, assigned or transferred except in accordance with this section. 
(1)	In the event of a change of control of the cable television company ("change of control" includes a change in ownership of a majority interest), the parties to the sale or transfer shall make a written request to the city for its approval of sale or transfer. The written request shall be accompanied by information required by Federal Communications Commission rules and shall be presented on a form as prescribed by Federal Communications Commission rules. 
(2)	In accordance with federal law, the city shall have 120 days from receipt of the information referred to in subsection (e)(1) of this section to act upon the request for approval. If the city fails to render a final decision on the request within that time, the request shall be deemed granted unless the cable television company and the city agree to an extension of the time. 
(3)	During the review period described in subsection (e)(2) of this section, the city may advise the cable television company that a public hearing is deemed necessary. In such event, the cable television company shall have written notice of the hearing, and of the opportunity to participate fully in it, as far in advance as possible and in no event less than 14 days before the start of the hearing. 
(4)	A decision of the city upon a request pursuant to this section shall be in writing and subject to review and appeal as provided in the federal law. 
(f)	In reviewing a request for sale or transfer, the city may inquire into the technical, legal and financial qualifications of the prospective controlling party, and the cable television company shall assist the city in so inquiring. The city shall not unreasonably withhold its approval. In no event shall a transfer or assignment of ownership or control be approved without the transferee becoming a signatory to the franchise. 
(g)	Notwithstanding anything to the contrary, no consent or approval by the city shall be required for a transfer or assignment to any person or entity controlling, controlled by or under the same common control as the cable television company, or for any sale, transfer or assignment other than a transfer requiring approval. 
(Ord. No. 140,  1(5), 2-11-1997) 
Sec. 74-58. - Franchises nonexclusive; term. 
    Any franchise issued pursuant to this article shall be a nonexclusive franchise for a term of years, not to exceed 15 years, as the common council may approve. 
(Ord. No. 140,  1(6), 2-11-1997) 
Sec. 74-59. - Fees; reporting; records. 
(a)	During the term of any franchise granted pursuant to this article, the person granted such franchise shall pay to the city for the use of its right-of-way, as well as the maintenance, improvements, and supervision thereof, and for the regulation activities required by virtue of the franchise, an amount to be determined by agreement between the city and the person granted such franchise but the amount shall not be less than five percent of the gross revenues. The city shall be furnished with a statement with each payment, certified as correct by the cable television company, and an annual statement for the entire year. The cable television company shall provide to the city, upon request, only those records and reports which pertain specifically to the cable television company's system under this agreement and only the financial records of the revenues earned by the cable television company from the operation of its cable system within the city. 
(b)	Such fee shall be paid as provided in the franchise at the office of the treasurer of the city during regular business hours. If the city treasurer's office is closed on the due date, then payment may be made during regular business hours on the next following day on which the office is open for business. 
(c)	The city shall have the right, at its expense and upon 30 days' written notice, to inspect the cable television company's records showing the gross revenues from which its franchise payments are computed. The right of audit within two years and recomputation of any and all amounts paid under this franchise shall be always accorded to the city at city expense. A grantee shall pay the city's expenses if an underpayment of five percent or more is discovered for any calendar quarter. Except as otherwise provided by law, no acceptance of any payment by the city shall be construed as a release of or an accord and satisfaction of any claim the city might have for further or additional sums payable or for any other performance or obligation of the cable television company. Acceptance of any payment shall be final upon completion of any audit. Under no circumstances shall the city be permitted to conduct an audit of any fiscal year more than two calendar years prior to the calendar year in which the audit occurs. The books and records shall be made available to the city in the city. 
(Ord. No. 140,  1(7), 2-11-1997) 
Sec. 74-60. - Construction of facilities; right to use right-of-way; restrictions; disposal; duties. 
(a)	A franchise granted pursuant to this article shall confer upon the grantee the nonexclusive right to erect, install, construct, reconstruct, replace, remove, repair, maintain and operate in or upon, under, above and across the right-of-way as existing as of the date of the grant of such franchise and all subsequent extensions thereof and additions thereto, in and belonging to the city, all necessary towers, poles, wires, cables, coaxial cables, transformers, amplifiers, underground conduits, manholes, and other television and/or radio conductors, equipment and fixtures for the installation, construction, maintenance and operation of a cable television system, including audio, video and radio signals, or the furnishing of a cable television service. 
(b)	Prior to the erection or installation of any towers, poles, guys, anchors, underground conduits, manholes, or fixtures for use in connection with the installation, construction, maintenance or operation of a cable television system under a franchise granted pursuant to this article, the cable television company of a franchise under this article desiring to erect or install such facilities for use in connection with its cable television system shall first submit to the city engineer for review and approval a concise description of the facilities proposed to be erected or installed, including engineering drawings, if requested or required, together with a map indicating the proposed location of such facilities. No erection or installation of any tower, pole, guy, anchor, underground conduit, manhole, or fixture for use in a cable television system shall be commenced by any person until approval has been received from the city engineer. 
(c)	Absent renewal, the franchisee shall have a period of 12 months from the date of termination or revocation to remove its towers, poles, wires, aerial or nonburied cables, fixtures or other facilities from the right-of-way; provided, however, that the cable television company shall not disturb any underground conduits, manholes or other facilities constructed underground. At the expiration of such 12-month period, any property not removed by the cable television company shall become the property of the city to do with as it may choose. Any cost to the city in removing such property from the right-of-way shall be reimbursed to the city by the cable television company. 
(d)	In areas or portions of the city where transmission or distribution facilities of public utilities providing telephone service and electric service are underground, any person granted a franchise pursuant to this article shall likewise install, construct, maintain and operate its transmission and distribution facilities in like manner underground to the maximum extent feasible and permitted by existing technology and conditions, subject to the approval of the city engineer as provided in subsection (b) of this section. 
(e)	All construction, installation, maintenance and operation of any cable television system or of any facilities employed in connection therewith shall, except where inconsistent with city ordinances, rules, regulations, standards and specifications, be in compliance with the provisions of the National Electrical Safety Code as prepared by the National Bureau of Standards, the National Electrical Code of the National Board of Fire Underwriters, any standards issued by the Federal Communications Commission or other federal or state regulatory agencies in relation thereto, and applicable regulations of public utilities operating in the city. Every cable television system installed, constructed, maintained or operated in the city shall be so designed, constructed, installed, maintained and operated as not to endanger or interfere with the safety of persons or property in the city. 
(f)	Any opening or obstruction in, disturbance of or damage to the right-of-way by any person in the exercise of any right granted pursuant to this article shall be properly guarded by adequate barriers, lights, signals and warnings as to prevent danger to any person or vehicle using such right-of-way and shall be properly and promptly repaired, all in a manner specified and approved by the city engineer, at such person's expense. 
(g)	Any person owning or maintaining a cable television system or facilities therefor in or on the right-of-way in the city shall, at its expense and without reimbursement from the city, upon request of the city, protect, support, temporarily disconnect, relocate or remove from the right-of-way, any property of such person when required by reason of traffic conditions, public safety, street vacation, freeway or street construction, change or establishment of street grade, installation of sewers, drains, water pipes, power lines, signal lines, tracks, the construction or change of the transmission or distribution facilities of any telephone or electric public utility or other public improvements. Any such person shall also, at the request of any private party holding an appropriate permit issued by the city, temporarily raise or lower its cable television transmission or distribution wires or cables to permit the moving of any building or other structure, provided that the actual expense of such temporary raising or lowering shall be paid in full by the party requesting the temporary raising or lowering. 
(h)	If any person shall fail to commence, pursue or complete any work required by law or by the provisions of this article as set forth in this article to be done in any right-of-way as designated by the engineer of the city, the city engineer may cause such work to be done and such person shall pay to the city the cost thereof within 30 days of the receipt of an itemized statement of such cost. 
(i)	Any person operating a cable system shall, in addition to all other requirements of this article, within 30 days of the execution of a franchise, file with the city, a construction bond with a company authorized to do business in the state and reasonably acceptable to the city, in the amount of $10,000.00. The purpose of the construction bond is to guarantee the timely construction and full activation of the cable system. The construction bond shall be for the purpose of allowing recovery by the city of any and all damages, losses or costs suffered by the city resulting from the failure of the cable television company to satisfactorily complete and fully activate the cable system throughout the city, pursuant to the terms and conditions of this article. 
(j)	When the cable system is completed to the reasonable satisfaction of the city, the construction bond need no longer be maintained. 
(k)	The construction bond shall contain the following endorsement:
"It is understood and agreed that this bond may not be canceled by the surety nor may the intention not to renew be exercised by the surety until 30 days after receipt by the city, by registered mail, of a written notice of such intent to cancel or not to renew." 
(Ord. No. 140,  1(8), 2-11-1997) 
Sec. 74-61. - Termination, revocation or surrender of franchise. 
(a)	Any initial franchise granted pursuant to this article shall expire without further proceedings ten months after its effective date in the event the person granted such franchise has not commenced construction of a cable television system within such period, unless prior to such date, such person shall have applied to the common council and the council shall have, for good cause shown, granted an extension of the construction periods set forth in the franchise agreement. 
(b)	If any person granted a franchise pursuant to this article fails to provide cable television service within and throughout any area as required under the terms of its franchise agreement, such franchise shall, on the anniversary of the effective date of such franchise next following the ten-month period during which cable television service has not been extended as required under the terms of the franchise agreement, be deemed revoked without the necessity of council action, unless prior to such date, such person shall have applied to the common council and the council shall have, for good cause shown, granted an extension of the construction of service periods set forth in the franchise agreement. 
(c)	Any franchise granted pursuant to this article may be terminated and canceled without further proceedings 120 days after the appointment of a receiver or trustee to take over and conduct the business of a cable television company, whether in receivership, reorganization, bankruptcy or other action or proceedings unless such receivership or trusteeship shall have been vacated prior to the expiration of such period; provided, however, that such receiver or trustee may apply for a transfer or assignment of such franchise, as provided in subsection 74-57(e) if duly approved by the court having jurisdiction in the premises, and provided further, in case of a foreclosure or other judicial sale of the plant, property or facilities of a cable television company, with or without the appointment of a receiver or trustee, including or excluding the franchise granted under this article, such franchise as granted may be terminated and canceled upon 30 days' written notice of termination served upon the cable television company and the purchaser thereof, unless within such 30-day period, the purchaser shall apply to the city for a transfer or assignment to it of the franchise as provided in subsection 74-57(e). 
(d)	Any franchise granted pursuant to this article, unless otherwise allowed by law, is revocable prior to its expiration for cause as provided in this subsection. Any franchise granted pursuant to this article is revocable for cause by the common council prior to its expiration where the cable television company has failed substantially to comply with any material provision or requirement of this article, or the provisions of its franchise agreement. The council shall give a written notice containing full particulars as to the provision or requirement with which compliance is claimed deficient and allow such cable television company 60 days to comply. At the expiration of such 60 days, the common council may hold a public hearing upon ten days' notice to the person granted a franchise. Such hearing shall be public with the cable television company being permitted to fully participate therein including the right to introduce testimony and exhibits and to examine and cross examine witnesses. The hearing shall be recorded and at the conclusion thereof, the council, if it reasonably finds that the cable television company has not substantially complied with any material provision or requirement of this article or its franchise agreement, may terminate and revoke the franchise. 
(e)	Any person granted a franchise pursuant to this article may surrender it by written notice of intent to surrender its franchise filed with the city clerk not less than 60 days prior to the surrender date. On the surrender date specified in such notice, all rights, privileges and authority under such franchise shall terminate; provided, however, that such person shall have a period of 12 months thereafter to remove its towers, poles, wires, aerial or nonburied cables, fixtures or other facilities from the streets, alleys, public rights-of-way or public places, subject to the rights of the city as set forth in subsection 74-60(d). At the expiration of such 12-month period, any property not removed by such person shall become the property of the city to do with as it may choose. Any cost to the city in removing such property from the streets, alleys, public rights-of-way or public places shall be claimed against such person under the performance bond or irrevocable bank letter of credit required under subsection 74-83(a). 
(f)	In the event a cable television company elects to overbuild, rebuild, modify or sell the system, or the common council terminates or revokes or fails to renew this franchise, the cable television company shall do everything in its power to ensure that all subscribers receive continuous uninterrupted service. In the event of a change of cable television company, the current cable television company shall cooperate with the city to operate the system for a reasonable period in maintaining continuity of service to all subscribers. 
(Ord. No. 140,  1(12), 2-11-1997) 
Secs. 74-62-74-80. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - SERVICE, SYSTEM AND OPERATING REQUIREMENTS 
Subdivision I. - In General 

Sec. 74-81. - Standard of service. 
(a)	Any person granted a franchise pursuant to this article shall install, construct, maintain and operate its cable television system in accordance with the accepted standards of the industry, in conformity with the standards of operation or maintenance for a cable television system which may be lawfully established by the Federal Communications Commission. 
(b)	Every cable television system franchised under this article, at a minimum, shall make available the following: 
(1)	At least one specifically designated noncommercial public access channel for production and programming on this channel. 
(2)	At least one specifically designated channel for noncommercial governmental use by the city. 
(3)	One channel for noncommercial educational use by the city community schools within its boundary. 
(c)	Every cable television system franchised under this article shall maintain and have available for public, educational and governmental (PEG) use the necessary equipment and facilities for the production of programming on the access channels specified in this article, which equipment and facilities, at a minimum, shall include one operational studio for the production of public, educational and governmental access programs and one mobile studio facility with all necessary equipment needed for the production of such programming or in lieu thereof make a financial commitment for public, educational and governmental (PEG) programming deemed sufficient by the city under this subsection. 
(d)	Every cable television company shall install as part of its cable system, and shall operate through the term, an emergency alert system (EAS) or the successor to that system in accordance with all requirements imposed from time to time by the Federal Communications Commission, including, without limitation, the requirements that cable television systems transmit a visual emergency alert system message on at least one channel (47 CFR 11.51(g)(3)) and that cable systems also provide video interruption and an audit emergency alert system message on all channels, with the audio message further stating which channel is carrying the visual message (47 CFR 11.51(g)(2)). In establishing the cable television company's emergency alert system pursuant to this section, the cable television company shall: 
(1)	Designate a channel, which may be the government channel, which will be used for emergency broadcasts of both audio and video; 
(2)	Inform customers of the designated emergency channel at least daily on at least one channel, which may be the government channel, of the multichannel system; 
(3)	Maintain all channel video blanking capability able to be activated remotely by security measures deemed mutually agreeable by the city and the cable television company; 
(4)	Test the emergency override system not less than every three months;
(5)	Cooperate with the city on the use and operation of the emergency alert override system; and 
(6)	Maintain the capacity to permit the city in time of emergency to activate the system consistent with federal regulations as stated in 47 CFR 11.55. 
(e)	Every cable television system franchised under this article shall maintain such capacity, capability and technical standards as will enable it to interconnect with any other cable television system located within the city and in any adjacent community. 
(Ord. No. 140,  1(9), 2-11-1997) 
Sec. 74-82. - Rates; discrimination; filing schedules; maximum rates; increase in rates; procedures. 
(a)	No rates or charges for cable television service provided in the city, which the city regulates in accordance with federal law, shall be effective until the rates and charges are filed with the clerk of the city. 
(b)	The city shall comply with rules of the Federal Communications Commission set forth in Subpart N (Cable Rate Regulation) of Part 76 (Cable Television Service) of Chapter I of Title 47 of the Code of Federal Regulations 47 CFR chapter I, part 76, subpart N regarding the regulation of cable television rates for basic service and associated equipment, as amended. 
(c)	If, subject to rate regulations, after a company submits for review its existing rates for the basic service tier and associated equipment costs or a proposed increase in these rates, the clerk shall publish a public notice of the rates and costs giving interested parties, including the company, a reasonable opportunity to file written comments which shall be available in the office of the city clerk for public inspection and copying during normal business hours. 
(d)	The city shall comply with procedures set forth in 47 CFR 0.459 regarding confidential business information submitted by the company in a rate regulation proceeding. 
(e)	A cable operator which willfully or repeatedly fails to comply with a rate decision or refund order directed specifically at the cable operator shall be subject to a monetary forfeiture as determined by the common council following the procedures set forth in 47 USC 503 
(f)	In the event of a conflict between this article and a cable television franchise, the provisions of this article shall prevail. 
(Ord. No. 131,  1-5, 10-12-1993; Ord. No. 140,  1(10), 2-11-1997) 
Sec. 74-83. - Indemnity; proof of insurance; effective date of franchise. 
(a)	Every cable television company, prior to the execution of the franchise agreement, shall file with the city and at all times thereafter maintain in full force and effect for the term of the franchise, at its expense, a performance bond or irrevocable bank letter of credit from a bank approved by the city, in the amount of $10,000.00 conditioned upon the faithful performance by such cable television company of its obligations under its franchise, and upon the further condition that if such cable television company shall fail to comply with any one or more provisions of this article, or cable television agreement with the city, after following the procedure, if any, in the franchise agreement, there shall be recoverable any damages or loss suffered by the city, as a result thereof, including the full amount of any compensation, indemnification, or cost of removal of any property of such cable television company as provided in this article plus attorney fees and costs, up to the full amount of the performance bond or letter of credit, such condition to be a continuing obligation for the duration of any franchise granted under this article and any renewal thereof and thereafter until such cable television company has liquidated all of its obligations with the city which may have arisen under the franchise or from the exercise of any privilege or right granted. 
(b)	No franchise under this article shall be effective until the provisions of subsection (a) of this section has been fully complied with and the failure to file with the city clerk within 90 days after tender by the city of the franchise agreement, the letter of credit, indemnity agreement, proof of general comprehensive insurance or any other documents and materials as required by subsection (a) of this section or any other provisions of this article or the city may revoke the franchise in accordance with procedures set forth in the franchise agreement. 
(c)	The cable television company and any contractor hired by the cable television company to install, maintain, improve, restore or remove a cable television system within the city shall not commence work under this agreement until they have obtained the insurance required within this section. All insurance coverage shall be with insurance carriers reasonably acceptable to the city. If any insurance is written with a deductible or self-insured retention, the cable television company or contractor shall be solely responsible for such deductible or self-insured retention. The purchase of insurance and the furnishing of a certificate of insurance shall not be a satisfaction of the cable television company's indemnification of the city. The cable television company is responsible to meet all MIOSHA requirements for on-the-job safety. The cable television company and any contractor hired by the cable television company shall procure and maintain during the life of this contract the following coverage: 
(1)	Workers' compensation insurance in accordance with all applicable statutes of the state. Coverage shall include employer's liability coverage. 
(2)	Commercial general liability insurance on an "occurrence" basis with limits of liability not less than $2,000,000.00 per occurrence for bodily injury and personal injury, and $1,000,000.00 per occurrence for property damage. Coverage shall include the following extensions: 
a.	Contractual liability.
b.	Products and completed operations.
c.	Independent contractors coverage.
d.	Broad form general liability extensions or equivalent.
e.	Coverage for X, C and U hazards.
(3)	Motor vehicle liability coverage, including state no-fault coverage for all vehicles used in the performance of the contract. Limits of liability shall not be less than $1,000,000.00 per occurrence combined single limit bodily injury and property damage. 
(4)	Commercial general liability insurance and automobile liability insurance as described in this section shall include an endorsement stating the following shall be an additional named insured: 
"The city, including all elected and appointed officials, boards, commissions, officers and employees." 
(5)	Workers' compensation insurance, commercial general liability insurance, and motor vehicle liability insurance as described in this section shall include an endorsement stating the following: 
"It is understood and agreed that this insurance policy may not be canceled by the insurer nor the intention not to renew be stated by the insurer until 30 days after receipt by the city, by registered mail, of a written notice of such intention to cancel or not renew." 
Such notice shall be sent to: 
City of Utica 
Attention: City Clerk 
7550 Auburn Road 
Utica, MI 48317 
(d)	If so requested by the city, cable television company and any contractor hired by cable television company shall within 60 days of such request supply a copy of the insurance policy of any of the insurance coverage required under this section. 
(Ord. No. 140,  1(11), 2-11-1997) 
Sec. 74-84. - Hearing and determination of complaints; procedure; local office. 
(a)	The common council, or any person or department designated by it, shall, upon its own motion or upon complaint of any person or subscriber of a cable television company, have authority to hear and determine all complaints concerning the rates, charges, rules, regulations, practices, quality or service rendered or refused to be rendered, equipment furnished or refused to be furnished, or any other matter relating to the service or operation of the cable television system or any person franchised under the terms of this article. 
(b)	Upon the filing of any complaint against any person pursuant to the preceding subsection, the common council shall give such person at least 20 days notice of the time and place of a hearing to be given such person upon the matters alleged in the complaint subject to state and federal laws. 
(c)	To aid in the analysis and resolution of any disputed matters relative to the franchise, the city and cable television company may, by mutual agreement (both as to whether to hire and whom to hire), employ the services of technical, financial or legal consultants, as arbitrators. All reasonable fees of the consultants shall be borne equally. 
(d)	Every person granted a franchise pursuant to this article shall:
(1)	Maintain a reasonably convenient bill payment location which shall be open during all usual business hours; and 
(2)	Have a publicly listed local telephone number or toll-free number which will be so operated to receive subscriber complaints and requests for repairs or adjustments on a 24-hour basis. 
The company shall render efficient service, make repairs promptly, and interrupt service only for good cause and for the shortest time possible. Such interruptions, insofar as possible, shall be preceded by notice and shall occur during periods of minimum use of the system. A written log shall be maintained listing all complaints resulting in service calls, their disposition, and all service interruptions. 
(e)	The company shall maintain a suitable repair force of technicians in order to respond to subscriber complaints or requests for service within 24 hours after receipt of the complaint or request. The company shall establish to the satisfaction of the city a complaint procedure in order to settle disputes between the company and subscribers. 
(Ord. No. 140,  1(13), 2-11-1997) 
Sec. 74-85. - Reports. 
    Upon request, every cable television company shall file annually with the city clerk a current map showing the location of the transmission and distribution facilities and equipment in the city used by it in providing cable television service. 
(Ord. No. 140,  1(14), 2-11-1997) 
Sec. 74-86. - Rights of individuals. 
(a)	A cable television company shall not deny service, deny access, nor otherwise discriminate against subscribers, channel users or general citizens on the basis of race, color, religion, national origin or sex. The cable television company shall comply at all times with all other applicable federal, state and local laws. 
(b)	A cable television company shall not refuse to hire or employ, nor bar or discharge from employment, nor discriminate against any person in compensation or in terms, conditions or privileges of employment because of age, race, creed, color, national origin or sex. 
(c)	Neither the cable television company, the city nor any other person shall tape or monitor or arrange for the taping or monitoring, or permit, either expressly or impliedly, any other person to tape or monitor any cable, line, signal input device, or subscriber outlet or receiver for any purpose whatsoever, without the express written permission of the subscriber; provided, however, that the cable television company shall be entitled to conduct systemwide or individually addressed "sweeps" for the purpose of verifying system integrity, controlling return-path transmission, or billing for pay services. 
(d)	A cable television company, or any of its agents, affiliates or employees, shall not, without the specific written authorization of the subscriber involved, sell or otherwise make available to any party: 
(1)	Lists of the names and addresses of such subscribers, which identifies by name subscriber viewing; or 
(2)	Any list which identifies the viewing habits of subscribers, except as such list is necessary for the construction, marketing and maintenance of a cable television company's facilities and services under this article and the concomitant billing of subscribers for such services. A cable television company shall not provide information concerning the viewing habits of identifiable individual subscribers to any party for any purpose whatsoever. 
The cable television company shall not utilize the two-way television capability of the system for unauthorized surveillance of any kind. 
(e)	Liability for obscenity, defamation or invasion of privacy on any access channels shall rest with the person, group of persons or any organization or corporation utilizing such access channels. 
(Ord. No. 140,  1(16), 2-11-1997) 
Secs. 74-87-74-105. - Reserved. 
Subdivision II. - Customer Service Standards 

Sec. 74-106. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this subdivision, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Normal business hours means 9:00 a.m. to 5:00 p.m., Monday to Friday and 9:00 a.m. to 12:00 noon on Saturday, excluding holidays. 
    Normal operating conditions means those service conditions which are within the control of the company. Those conditions which are not within the control of the company include, but are not limited to, natural disasters, civil disturbances, power outages, telephone network outages and severe or unusual weather conditions. Those conditions which are ordinarily within the control of the company include, but are not limited to, special promotions, pay-per-view events, rate increases, regular peak or seasonal demand periods and maintenance or upgrade of the cable system. 
    Service interruption means the loss of picture or sound on one or more cable channels. 
(Ord. No. 140,  1(22), 2-11-1997) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally,  1-2. 
Sec. 74-107. - Exceptions. 
    Nothing in this subdivision is intended to prevent or prohibit: 
(1)	The city and a company from agreeing to customer service requirements that exceed the standards set forth in this article; 
(2)	The city from enacting or enforcing any consumer protection law; or
(3)	The establishment or enforcement of any ordinance or regulation concerning customer service that imposes customer service requirements that exceed or address matters not addressed by the standards set forth in this article. 
(Ord. No. 140,  1(23), 2-11-1997) 
Sec. 74-108. - Customer service standards. 
    A company is subject to the following customer service standards certified quarterly by the company: 
(1)	The company will maintain a local, toll-free or collect call telephone access line which will be available to subscribers 24 hours a day, seven days a week. 
(2)	Trained company representatives shall be available to respond to customer telephone inquiries 9:00 a.m. to 12:00 midnight, seven days a week. From 12:00 midnight to 9:00 a.m., the access line may be answered by a service or an automated response system, including an answering machine. Inquiries received from 12:00 midnight to 9:00 a.m., shall be responded to by a trained company representative on the next business day. 
(3)	Under normal operating conditions, telephone answer time by a company representative, including wait time, shall not exceed 30 seconds when the connection is made. If the call needs to be transferred, transfer time shall not exceed 30 seconds. These standards shall be met no less than 90 percent of the time under normal operating conditions measured on a quarterly basis. 
(4)	Under normal operating conditions, the customers may receive a busy signal less than three percent of the time measured on a quarterly basis. 
(5)	A reasonably convenient bill payment location will be open at least during normal business hours. 
(6)	Under normal operating conditions, each of the following five standards must be met no less than 95 percent of the time measured on a quarterly basis: 
a.	Standard installations will be performed seven business days after an order has been placed. Standard installations are those that are located not more than 125 feet from the existing distribution system. 
b.	Excluding conditions beyond the control of the operator, a company shall begin working on service interruptions promptly and in no event later than 24 hours after the interruption becomes known. The company must begin actions to correct other service problems the next business day after notification of the service problem. 
c.	The appointment window for installations, service calls, and other installation activities will be either a specific time or, at maximum, a four-hour block during normal business hours. The operator may schedule service calls and other installation activities outside of normal business hours for the express convenience of the customer. 
d.	A company may not cancel an appointment with a customer after the close of business on the business day prior to the scheduled appointment. 
e.	If a company representative is running late for an appointment and will not be able to keep the appointment as scheduled, the customer will be contacted, the appointment rescheduled, as necessary, at a time which is convenient for the customer. 
(7)	The company shall provide written information on each of the following areas at the time of installation of service, at least annually to all subscribers, and at any time upon request: 
a.	Products and services offered;
b.	Prices and options for programming services and conditions of subscription to programming and other services; 
c.	Installation and service maintenance policies;
d.	Instructions on how to use the cable service;
e.	Channel positions of programming carried on the system; and
f.	Billing and complaint procedures, including the business address and telephone number of the company and of the city. 
(8)	Except with respect to a change in rates which is the result of a regulatory fee, franchise fee and any other fee, tax, assessment or charge of any kind imposed by federal, state or local government, customers will be notified of any changes in rates, programming services or channel positions as soon as possible by any reasonable means. Notice must be given to subscribers a minimum of 30 days in advance of such changes if the change is within the control of the company. In addition, the company shall notify subscribers 30 days in advance of any significant changes in the other information required by the subsection (7) of this section. 
(9)	Bills shall be clear, concise and understandable. Bills must be fully itemized with itemizations including, but not limited to, basic and premium service charges and equipment charges. Bills shall clearly delineate all activity during the billing period, including operational charges, rebates and credits. In case of a billing dispute, a company must respond to a written complaint from a subscriber within 30 days. 
(10)	Refund checks shall be issued promptly, but not later than:
a.	The customer's next billing cycle following resolution of the request or 30 days, whichever is earlier; or 
b.	The return of the equipment supplied by the company if service is terminated by the company. 
(11)	Credits will be issued no later than the customer's next billing cycle following the determination that a credit is warranted. 
(Ord. No. 140,  1(24), 2-11-1997) 
Sec. 74-109. - Enforcement. 
(a)	A company shall file with the city clerk a notarized statement signed by an officer or employee certifying compliance with the customer service standards under this subsection on an annual basis. 
(b)	Failing to file a certificate shall subject a company to pay a civil fine to the city of up to $500.00 per day. 
(c)	A company in noncompliance shall on a quarterly basis file a statement specifying areas of noncompliance along with a remedial plan. Failing to file a noncompliance statement and remedial plan shall subject the company to pay a civil fine to the city of up to $500.00 per day. 
(Ord. No. 140,  1(25), 2-11-1997) 
Chapter 78 - TRAFFIC AND VEHICLES 
FOOTNOTE(S):
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Any ordinance prescribing traffic regulations for specific locations not codified in this Code saved from repeal,  1-11(15)a; any ordinance ordering, requiring or authorizing the erection or installation of traffic control signs, signals, devices or markings not codified in this Code saved from repeal,  1-11(15)b; law enforcement, ch. 42; offenses and miscellaneous provisions, ch. 46; malicious mischief with motor vehicles,  46-112; motor vehicles and off-the-road vehicles in parks,  50-45; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 62; off-street loading and unloading, app. A,  1411; recreational vehicle storage, app. A,  1413. (Back)
State Law reference- Michigan Vehicle Code, MCL 257.1 et seq. (Back)
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 78-1. - Interpretation. 
    In the event of a conflict between the Uniform Traffic Code for Cities, Townships and Villages as adopted in this chapter and this chapter, the provisions of this chapter shall control. In the event of a conflict between the provisions of this chapter and the Michigan Vehicle Code (MCL 257.1 et seq.), the Michigan Vehicle Code shall control. In the event of conflict between the Uniform Traffic Code for Cities, Townships and Villages as adopted in this chapter and the Michigan Vehicle Code (MCL 257.1 et seq.), the Michigan Vehicle Code shall control. 
Sec. 78-2. - Enforcement. 
    The provisions of this chapter shall be enforced in accordance with the Uniform Traffic Code for Cities, Townships and Villages as adopted in this chapter and the Michigan Vehicle Code (MCL 257.1 et seq.). 
Sec. 78-3. - Michigan Vehicle Code adopted. 
(a)	The Michigan Vehicle Code, 1949 PA 300, MCL 257.1 to 257.923, and all future amendments and revisions to the Michigan Vehicle Code when they are effective in this state are incorporated and adopted by reference. 
(b)	References in the Uniform Michigan Vehicle Code to "local authorities" shall mean the City of Utica. 
(c)	The penalties provided by the Michigan Vehicle Code are adopted by reference, provided, however, that the city may not enforce any provision of the Michigan Vehicle Code for which the maximum period of imprisonment is greater than 93 days. 
(Ord. No. 153,  1-3, 2-11-2003; Ord. No. 153A,  1-3, 2-14-2006) 
State law reference- Authority to adopt Michigan Vehicle Code by reference, MCL 117.3(k). 
Sec. 78-4. - Uniform Traffic Code for Cities, Townships and Villages adopted. 
(a)	The Uniform Traffic Code for Cities, Townships and Villages promulgated by the department of state police is adopted by reference and all future amendments thereof. 
(b)	References in the Uniform Traffic Code for Cities, Townships and Villages to "governmental unit" shall mean this city. 
(Ord. No. 152,  1, 2, 2-11-2003) 
State law reference- Authority to adopt Uniform Traffic Code by reference, MCL 257.951. 
Sec. 78-5. - Motor carrier safety. 
    No person shall violate Ordinance No. 137, as amended. 
State law reference- Motor Carrier Safety Act of 1963, MCL 480.11 et seq. 
Sec. 78-6. - No passing zone. 
    Cass Avenue between Auburn Street and Ruby Street within the city shall be properly marked and signed to provide that there shall be no passing by a motor vehicle of another motor vehicle between such points on Cass Avenue within the city. 
(Ord. No. 67,  1, 5-11-1965) 
State law reference- No passing zones, MCL 257.60. 
Sec. 78-7. - Truck routes. 
(a)	All through truck traffic shall use only the following streets through the city, provided, however, in the case of hardship, upon application to the police chief, an alternate route may be designated by the police chief: 
Hall Road, being State Highway 59; Van Dyke Avenue; and any other street that may be marked by signs indicating that such streets may be used as a truck route. 
(b)	Trucks, trailers, semitrailers or other commercial vehicles shall not be operated on other streets in the city except for the purposes of business originating or terminating on such streets, and in such event, the operator of such vehicle shall use truck routes so far as may be practicable in traveling to and from such destination in residential areas in the city. 
(Ord. No. 39A,  1, 2, 9-13-1960; Ord. No. 39-B, 4-17-1973; Ord. No. 39-C, 11-12-1973) 
Sec. 78-8. - Livestock or slaughterhouse vehicles. 
(a)	The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Livestock vehicle means any truck, trailer, or motor vehicle, loaded or unloaded, used to transport, move, deliver or otherwise convey live animals or fowl for the purpose of being slaughtered. 
    Slaughterhouse means every place where live animals or fowl are slaughtered for human consumption. 
    Slaughterhouse vehicle means any truck, trailer or motor vehicle, loaded or unloaded, used to transport, move, deliver or otherwise convey the products, byproducts or waste products of a slaughterhouse. 
(b)	No livestock vehicle or slaughterhouse vehicle shall stand or park upon any street or highway in the city. It shall be presumed that the driver, operator or person in possession of any such motor vehicle was the person who parked or stopped such motor vehicle; provided further that as to any unattended motor vehicle, the registered owner of such vehicle shall be presumed to have parked or stopped such motor vehicle. 
(c)	No livestock vehicle or slaughterhouse vehicle shall drive or travel upon any street or highway in the city, except the following: 
(1)	M-59, also known as Hall Road.
(2)	M-53, also known as Van Dyke.
(3)	M-53, bypass expressway.
(4)	Cass Avenue
(d)	A truck or trailer is presumed, unless rebutted by competent evidence, to be used for a purpose consistent with any lettering, words or company designation contained on any such truck or trailer. 
(e)	No livestock vehicle or slaughterhouse vehicle shall drive or travel upon Cass Avenue between the hours of 7:00 p.m. and 5:00 a.m., Mondays through Saturdays, and at any time on Sundays or legal holidays. 
(f)	Violations of this section are a civil infraction.
(Ord. No. 39-E,  1-6, 9-9-1980) 
Secs. 78-9-78-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - ADMINISTRATION AND ENFORCEMENT 
FOOTNOTE(S):
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Administration, ch. 2. (Back)
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 78-31. - Reimbursement of city expenses in connection with arrests of persons for OWI or impaired driving. 
(a)	For the purpose of this section, the following terms shall be defined as follows:
(1)	Emergency response means the providing, sending and/or using police, firefighting and emergency medical services by the city to or at an accident involving a motor vehicle where one or more of the drivers were operating the motor vehicle while intoxicated, to wit: under the influence of an alcoholic beverage or controlled substance or the combined influence of an alcoholic beverage and controlled substance or with a blood alcohol content of 0.08 grams or more per 100 milliliters of blood, per 210 liters of breath, or per 67 milliliters of urine or while visibly impaired. 
(2)	Arrest means the making of a traffic stop and arrest by a police officer when the driver was operating the motor vehicle while intoxicated, to wit: under the influence of an alcoholic beverage or a controlled substance or the combined influence of an alcoholic beverage and controlled substance or with a blood alcohol content of 0.08grams or more per 100 milliliters of blood, per 210 liters of breath, or per 67 milliliters of urine or while visibly impaired. 
(3)	Reimbursable expense means the direct costs associated with the occurrence of an emergency response as set forth in subsection (a)(1) of this section or an arrest as set forth in subsection (a)(2) of this section, whichever is applicable. Reimbursable expenses shall include, but not be limited to, the costs connected with the administration and provision of an alcohol breath test and the videotaping of the driver, if applicable. These costs shall be established by resolution of the common council of the city and collected by the treasurer of the city. 
(b)	The city finds that a significant number of traffic arrests and traffic accidents in the city involve drivers who were operating a motor vehicle while under the influence of alcoholic beverages and/or a controlled substance or with a blood alcohol content of 0.08 grams or more per 100 milliliters of blood, per 210 liters of breath, or per 67 milliliters of urine or while visibly impaired. In addition, the city finds that in traffic accidents involving drivers who were operating a motor vehicle in such a condition there is a greater likelihood of personal injury and property damage. As a result of these determinations, a greater operational and/or financial burden is placed upon the city police department, fire department and emergency medical services by persons who are operating a motor vehicle in such a condition. 
(c)	Any person who, while intoxicated, to wit: under the influence of an alcoholic beverage or any controlled substance or the combined influence of an alcoholic beverage and any controlled substance or with a blood alcohol content of 0.08 grams per 100 milliliters of blood, per 210 liters of breath, or per 67 milliliters of urine or more or while visibly impaired, operates a motor vehicle which results in an emergency response and/or arrest as defined in subsection (a)(2) of this section shall be responsible and/or liable for the expenses of such emergency response and/or arrest. 
(d)	For purposes of this section, it shall be presumed that a person was operating a motor vehicle while intoxicated, to wit: under the influence of an alcoholic beverage or with a blood alcohol content of 0.08 grams per 100 milliliters of blood, per 210 liters of breath, or per 67 milliliters of urine or more or while visibly impaired 
(e)	The liability for expenses described in subsection (c) of this section shall be of a civil nature and shall not be construed to conflict, contravene, enlarge, or reduce any criminal liability or responsibility including fines and/or costs imposed by a judge or magistrate on a driver for operating a motor vehicle while intoxicated, to wit: under the influence of an alcoholic beverage and/or controlled substance or the combined influence of an alcoholic beverage and controlled substance or with a blood alcohol content of 0.08 grams per 100 milliliters of blood, per 210 liters of breath, or per 67 milliliters of urine or more or while visibly impaired. 
(f)	A finding of not guilty of OWI or impaired after trial shall relieve such person from civil liability established by this section. 
(Ord. No. 133,  1-4, 10-18-1994; Ord. of 12-8-2009) 
Secs. 78-32-78-50. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - PARKING VIOLATIONS BUREAU 

FOOTNOTE(S):
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Parking violations bureau, MCL 600.8395. (Back)
Sec. 78-51. - Police department to act as parking violations bureau. 
    The police department is hereby constituted and authorized to act as a parking violations bureau for parking violations under the authority established in this division. The police chief shall be in charge of the parking violations bureau and shall direct members of the police department to perform the duties under this division as he deems proper and necessary. 
(Ord. No. 88A,  1, 7-18-1984) 
Sec. 78-52. - Settlement of violations. 
    Any person charged with any violation of the parking ordinance or traffic control orders of the city, as specified in section 78-58, may, within ten days, if such person is a resident of this state, or if a nonresident, on or before the appearance date, settle such violation and pay the amount specified in section 78-58. Acceptance of the prescribed sanction shall be deemed complete satisfaction by the city. 
(Ord. No. 88A,  2, 7-18-1984) 
Sec. 78-53. - Responsibility for violation; acceptance. 
    The parking violations bureau shall have no discretion to determine the responsibility of any person cited, but may only accept the prescribed sanction in satisfaction of a parking violation notice. The payment of the prescribed sanction shall constitute a plea of responsibility which the parking violations bureau is hereby authorized to accept. 
(Ord. No. 88A,  3, 7-18-1984) 
Sec. 78-54. - Notice of violation. 
    If a violator of the restrictions on parking does not respond to a parking citation within a period of ten days, the parking violations bureau shall send the owner of the motor vehicle to which the notice was affixed a letter by first class mail informing him of the violation and warning him that failure to respond will cause the citation to be forwarded to the district court for prosecution as a civil infraction and an increase fine or sanction. The notice shall also advise the owner that failure to respond to a parking violation may result in the denial by the secretary of state to renew the violator's license in accordance with section 321a of Public Act No. 300 of 1949 (MCL 257.321a). 
(Ord. No. 88A,  4, 7-18-1984) 
Sec. 78-55. - Failure to comply with notice; filing of citation district court. 
    In the event any person fails to comply with the notice of the parking violations bureau as provided in this division, the police department shall forthwith file a parking citation with the district court with a copy of this citation being served by first class mail upon this registered owner of the vehicle at the owners last known address as provided by MCL 257.742. The citation filed with the court is a civil infraction and shall consist of a sworn complaint containing the allegations stated in the parking violation notice and shall fairly inform the defendant how to respond to the citation. The citation need not comply in all particulars with sections 727c and 743 of the Michigan Vehicle Code (MCL 257.727c and 257.743). The citation shall be processed in the same manner as a civil infraction issued in accordance with the Michigan Vehicle Code (MCL 257.742). 
(Ord. No. 88A,  5, 7-18-1984) 
Sec. 78-56. - Persons responsible for violations. 
(a)	Except as provided in this section, if a vehicle is stopped, standing, or parked in violation of a state statute, or an ordinance prohibiting or restricting the stopping, standing, or parking of a vehicle and the violation is a civil infraction, the person in whose name that vehicle is registered in this state or another state at the time of the violation is prima facie responsible for that violation. 
(b)	The owner of a vehicle cited for a stopping, standing, or parking violation pursuant to subsection (a) of this section may assert as an affirmative defense that the vehicle in question, at the time of the violation, was in the possession of a person whom the owner had not knowingly permitted to operate the vehicle. 
(c)	The lessee or renter of a motor vehicle and not the leased vehicle owner is liable for a violation of an ordinance or state statute relating to a standing or parked vehicle involving the motor vehicle if the leased vehicle owner furnishes proof that the vehicle described in the citation, complaint, warrant, or notice was in the possession of, custody of, or was being operated or used by the lessee or renter of the vehicle at the time of the violation. 
(d)	If a leased vehicle is leased or rented for 30 days or less, the leased vehicle owner may avoid liability for a violation described in subsection (c) of this section if the leased vehicle owner provides all of the following information to the clerk of the court or parking violations bureau issuing the violation not later than 30 days after the leased vehicle owner has received notice of the violation: 
(1)	The lessee's or renter's name, address, and operator's or chauffeur's license number.
(2)	A copy of the signed rental or lease agreement or an expedited rental agreement without signature as part of a master rental agreement, including proof of the date and time the possession of the vehicle was given to the lessee or renter and the date and time the vehicle was returned to the leased vehicle owner or the leased vehicle owner's authorized agent under the agreement. 
(e)	If a leased vehicle is leased or rented for 30 days or less, the leased vehicle owner is liable for a violation of an ordinance or state statute relating to a standing or parked vehicle if one more of the following occur: 
(1)	The leased vehicle owner does not provide the information described in subsection (d) of this section within the 30-day period specified in that subsection. 
(2)	The court or parking violations bureau issuing the violation proceeds against the lessee or renter of the vehicle and the lessee or renter of the vehicle is not convicted of or found responsible for the violation. 
(f)	As used in this section:
(1)	Affiliate means a person that directly or indirectly through one or more intermediaries controls, is controlled by, or is under common control with another person. 
(2)	Leased vehicle owner means a person in the business of renting or leasing leased vehicles or an affiliate of the person, if the person or the affiliate is the registered owner of a standing or parked leased vehicle involved in a violation of a local ordinance or state statute. 
(Ord. No. 88A,  6, 7-18-1984) 
State law reference- Similar provisions, MCL 600.675b, 600.675c. 
Sec. 78-57. - Payment of monies to city treasurer. 
    The parking violations bureau shall pay over to the city treasurer all monies collected and shall keep such other records and make such reports as may from time to time be required by the common council. 
(Ord. No. 88A,  7, 7-18-1984) 
Sec. 78-58. - Schedule of payments for parking violations. 
    All violations may be settled at the parking violations bureau upon payment of the sanction, for the specific violation as currently scheduled by the district court servicing the city for ordinance violations. 
(Ord. No. 88A,  8, 7-18-1984) 
Secs. 78-59-78-75. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - VEHICLE TOWING 

FOOTNOTE(S):
--- (4) --- 
State Law reference- Abandoned vehicles, MCL 257.252a et seq. (Back)
Sec. 78-76. - Authority of police department to contract for removal, impoundment and storage of motor vehicles. 
    The police department is hereby authorized to contract for the removal, impoundment and storage of motor vehicles or other items temporarily in the possession of the city. The person awarded the contract shall be designated as a contractor. 
(Ord. No. 114,  2, 3-9-1982; Ord. No. 114B,  2, 9-13-1994) 
Sec. 78-77. - Removal of vehicles generally. 
    Whenever any vehicle shall be found parked in a place where parking is not permitted, such vehicle may be removed and conveyed, by or under the direction of a member of the police department or fire department, by means of towing the vehicle or otherwise, to a place where parking is legal or permitted, or to facilities maintained for storage pursuant to a contract as provided in this division. 
(Ord. No. 114,  3, 3-9-1982; Ord. No. 114B,  3, 9-13-1994) 
Sec. 78-78. - Additional conditions for removal and impoundment of vehicle. 
    In addition to such places as are posted to prohibit parking or are prohibited by city ordinance or state statute, the following conditions are also prohibited and can be remedied by removal and/or impoundment, by the police department or fire department, of the vehicle and the contents thereof: 
(1)	Abandoned vehicles as defined by state statute.
(2)	Vehicles which obstruct or otherwise impede traffic on any county or state roadway.
(3)	Vehicles that are not in proper condition to be driven due to mechanical failure, flat tire, lack of fuel or as the result of an accident upon the streets of the city for a longer period than is necessary to remove such vehicle. 
(4)	Vehicles, whereby their presence constitute a material obstruction or a definite hazard to the movement of traffic. 
(5)	Vehicles upon a highway that are so disabled as to constitute an obstruction to traffic and the person in charge of the vehicle is by reason of physical injury incapacitated to such an extent as to be unable to provide for its custody or removal. 
(6)	Vehicles that would be left unattended because the driver of such vehicle has been taken into custody by the police department. 
(7)	Vehicles that are parked contrary to the interest of public safety because of fire, flood, or other emergency reason. 
(8)	Vehicles that the police department, fire department, or public works department, or a member thereof, required to be removed to properly perform a duty consistent with such department. 
(9)	Vehicles involved in the commission of a felony.
(10)	Vehicles that may be impounded or forfeited pursuant to city ordinance or state statute.
(Ord. No. 114,  4, 3-9-1982) 
Sec. 78-79. - Liens. 
    Any motor vehicle or item removed, impounded, or stored by the city shall be subject to an immediate lien for all charges associated with the removal, impoundment and storage. The amount of such charges shall be specified in the contract authorized in section 78-76. 
(Ord. No. 114,  5, 3-9-1982; Ord. No. 114A, 7-18-1988; Ord. No. 114B,  5, 9-13-1994) 
Sec. 78-80. - Minimum factors for award of towing contract. 
    The police chief shall oversee the contract process as authorized in section 78-76. The minimum factors to be considered for the award of a contract are: 
(1)	Cost of services.
(2)	Whether the full-time business of the person, firm, or corporation consist, in part, of towing, transporting or storage of motor vehicles. 
(3)	Ability to provide towing facilities at any time requested to do so.
(4)	Past experience in providing quick and efficient towing, transporting and storage services. 
(5)	Insurance and bonding criteria.
(Ord. No. 114,  6, 3-9-1982; Ord. No. 114B,  6, 9-13-1994) 
Sec. 78-81. - Procedure for disposition of articles stored by the city. 
    Where no other procedure is provided by law, the following procedure shall apply to the disposition of articles stored by the city: 
(1)	After any article has been stored for 30 days, it shall be considered abandoned and the police chief may cause such article to be sold. The police chief shall cause to be published in a newspaper a notice of public auction of such articles. Such notice shall state the time, place and purpose of the auction. The items to be sold need not be listed provided a list of such articles is made available at the police chief's office for inspection by any interested person. The auction shall be called for no sooner than 30 days nor longer than 45 days after publication. 
(2)	A public auction need not be called more frequently than annually.
(3)	Any excess of proceeds of such sale not necessary to satisfy liens shall be payable to the city for deposit to its general fund. 
(Ord. No. 114,  7, 3-9-1982; Ord. No. 114B,  7, 9-13-1994) 
Sec. 78-82. - Registration plate to constitute evidence of vehicle ownership. 
    In any proceedings pursuant to this division, either criminal or civil or administrative, the registration plate displayed on such motor vehicle shall constitute in evidence a prima facie presumption that the owner of such motor vehicle was the person who parked or placed such vehicle at the point where such act occurred. 
(Ord. No. 114,  9, 3-9-1982) 
Sec. 78-83. - Notification of circumstances of violation; protest; payment of fees to treasury; records. 
(a)	It shall be the duty of the person in charge of any impounded vehicle to inform the owner or person claiming an impounded vehicle of the nature and circumstances of the violation on account of which such vehicle has been impounded. In case protest is made against the payment of any impounding or storage fee, the person in charge of the vehicle pound shall mark upon the receipt evidencing payment of the impounding and storage fees the words "Paid Under Protest." In such case, it shall thereupon be the duty of the person having knowledge of the facts to forthwith institute the proper proceedings in the district court charging the owner or driver of such vehicle with that violation of the provision of this division or other city ordinance on account of which the vehicle was impounded. On the disposition of the cause in court, it shall be the duty of the treasurer to refund to such person the fees paid under protest, provided such person is acquitted of such charges. 
(b)	It shall be the duty of the public works department to account for all fees collected under this division and to pay the fees into the city treasury. The public works department shall also keep the names of all owners of vehicles impounded, the number of their state license tags, the nature and circumstances of each violation and the disposition of each case. 
(Ord. No. 114,  10, 3-9-1982) 
Secs. 78-84-78-110. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - STOPPING, STANDING AND PARKING 

FOOTNOTE(S):
--- (5) --- 
Cross reference- P-1, vehicular parking district, app. A,  1200 et seq.; off-street parking requirements, app. A,  1406; off-street parking space layout, standards, construction, and maintenance, app. A,  1407. (Back)
Sec. 78-111. - Violations as civil infractions. 
    Any person who shall cause his motor vehicle to be left, parked, standing or abandoned contrary to signs posted prohibiting such parking, standing or abandonment shall be responsible for a civil infraction. 
(Ord. No. 114,  8(B), 3-9-1982) 
Sec. 78-112. - Abandonment. 
    Any person who shall cause his motor vehicle to be left, parked, or abandoned under such circumstances as would give rise to removal, impoundment, or storage pursuant to article II, division 3 of this chapter, except as to subsection 78-78(5), (6), (7) or (8), shall be responsible for a civil infraction. 
(Ord. No. 114,  8(A), 3-9-1982) 
Sec. 78-113. - Parking of inoperable vehicle; permit. 
(a)	For the purpose of this section, the term "inoperable vehicle" means any motor vehicle which is currently not capable of being started and safely and properly operated on the highway and which does not bear a valid and current license plate. This section shall not apply to licensed junkyards or to licensed automotive dealers, gasoline stations and commercial garages engaged in the repair and maintenance of automobiles. 
(b)	It shall be unlawful to park or for an owner of property to permit any inoperable vehicle on any property within the city in a place or area not fully enclosed by a building or structure without a permit as provided in this section. 
(c)	Application shall be made to the police chief by appearance at the police station within 96 hours after the time when such parking has been commenced and by filing on a form furnished by the police chief a statement of the following: 
(1)	Address of the premises where the vehicle is to be parked;
(2)	Name and address of the owner or person in control of the premises, and a statement attesting to his permission for such vehicle to be parked and the date of such permission; 
(3)	Name and address of the registered owner of the inoperable vehicle for which the permit is sought; the registration or title shall be presented to the officer issuing the permit; 
(4)	Description of the inoperable vehicle for which a permit is sought as to the make, model, year of manufacture, last license issued and condition which rendered it inoperable; 
(5)	Estimated length of time, not to exceed 60 days, for which the permit is being requested in order to restore the vehicle to operating condition: 
(6)	The signature of the applicant.
(d)	At his discretion, the police chief or his delegated officers may issue a permit based on a proper application. Such permit shall be valid for a period not to exceed 60 days from the date of application. A copy of such permit shall be posted inside the vehicle for which it was issued by affixing to the windshield or window in such a manner as to be readily visible at all times. Any permit may be renewed at the discretion of the police chief upon filing of a new application. No permit shall be transferable to any other person. 
(e)	Every permit for storage of an inoperable vehicle on private property shall be subject to the conditions that: 
(1)	No nuisance or safety hazard shall be created or maintained;
(2)	All broken glass or partially detached parts shall be either removed and disposed of as rubbish or secured in a manner to prevent hazard; 
(3)	Trunk or storage compartment shall be kept locked or otherwise secured adequately to prevent possible entrapment of a child; 
(4)	Wheels or tires shall not be removed from the vehicle except for repairs;
(5)	The last issued license plates shall be kept on the vehicle;
(6)	The vehicle shall not be elevated or blocked in any unsafe manner;
(7)	All parts or components removed from the vehicle shall not be stored in the open;
(8)	No waste oil or other fluids shall be allowed to flow on the ground or pavement;
(9)	The vehicle may be parked only in the rear yard of residential property;
(10)	No violation of the zoning ordinance (appendix A to this Code) shall be created;
(11)	All information furnished by the applicant is essentially correct. The making of any false statement is a misdemeanor. 
(f)	Any permit issued under authority of this article may be revoked at the discretion of the police chief when, in his opinion, a violation of this section exists. Notice of such revocation shall be delivered to the permittee or posted conspicuously on the vehicle, along with a notice to cease storing such vehicle and remove it to a proper storage or disposal location. The permittee shall remove the vehicle within ten days after receiving such notice or after the notice is posted. The police chief shall collect a fee of $1.00 at the time of issuance of each permit for storage of inoperable vehicle or renewal thereof. No part of this fee shall be refundable. 
(g)	Any vehicle parked, stored or otherwise kept in violation of this section shall be removed and impounded in the city storage area. 
(h)	Any violation of this section shall constitute a misdemeanor.
(i)	The registered owner of the vehicle, owner of the property, and occupant of the property shall be equally guilty of a violation of this section. 
(1)	The person listed upon the tax rolls of the city shall be presumed to be the owner of the premises. A certificate from the city treasurer shall be admissable in evidence in any court of law to establish such ownership. 
(2)	The person regularly residing at, or doing business at, the premises involved shall be presumed to be the occupant thereof. 
(Ord. No. 114,  11, 3-9-1982) 
Sec. 78-114. - Municipal building parking lot. 
(a)	The parking area located adjacent to the Utica Municipal Building is hereby declared the municipal parking area and is subject to the provisions of this section. 
(b)	The police chief is hereby authorized to designate one parking space for each of the following persons in the municipal parking area: 
(1)	Mayor.
(2)	Mayor pro tem.
(3)	Treasurer.
(4)	Assessor.
(5)	Clerk.
(6)	Assistant clerk.
(7)	Police chief
(c)	The police chief is hereby authorized to designate an adequate number of parking spaces in the municipal parking area for the parking of police vehicles. The police chief is further authorized to designate restricted parking areas or spaces as deemed necessary to the performance of police functions or duties. 
(d)	Any person who parks a motor vehicle contrary to posted restrictions or designations in the municipal parking area is responsible for a civil infraction. 
(Ord. No. 106,  1-4, 7-18-1979) 
Sec. 78-115. - Parking in yards. 
(a)	It shall be unlawful for any person to encroach upon the required open space on residential properties as provided for in the zoning ordinance by parking of any vehicle which is not self-propelled or is disabled. 
(b)	It shall be lawful to park in a driveway, or other area provided for such purpose, vehicles owned by the property owner or his tenant or tenants legally occupying the property, or their visitors, provided that such vehicles are capable of being operated and, as provided for in this subsection, are not disabled. 
(c)	The provisions of this section in effect prohibit the parking of any vehicle, whether self-propelled or not, in the defined open spaces as provided for in the zoning ordinance of the city. There is no prohibition against parking of such vehicles in the rear of any residence provided there is no interference with the open spaces as defined. 
(Ord. No. 65,  1-3, 12-8-1965) 
Sec. 78-116. - Service or repair of motor vehicles on streets, highways and other public places. 
    It is a misdemeanor to service any motor vehicle, or make any repair to any motor vehicle, in or upon any of the streets, highways, alleys or other public places in the city, except minor repairs which may be necessary in an emergency to render such motor vehicle operative. 
(Ord. No. 114,  8(C), 3-9-1982) 
Cross reference- Streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 62. 
Sec. 78-117. - Parking of trucks on residential streets. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person or other owner of a truck to park the truck on the residential streets within the city except for loading and/or unloading in the normal course of business activities. 
(Ord. No. 68,  1, 5-11-1965) 
Cross reference- Streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 62. 
Secs. 78-118-78-140. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - VALET PARKING 

Sec. 78-141. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Badge means an emblem or device identifying an individual as being an employee of a valet parking service. 
    Parking means the halting of a motor vehicle, whether or not occupied, when not loading or unloading. 
    Pickup and dropoff point means a designated location where a valet parking attendant shall take possession of a motor vehicle and drive such motor vehicle to an area to be parked and to which such vehicle shall be returned to the owner or driver thereof. 
    Revocation means the termination of a valet parking license, which shall not be eligible to be renewed or restored. 
    Standing means halting of a motor vehicle other than for the purpose of and while actually receiving or discharging passengers. 
    Suspension means the temporary withdrawal of a valet parking license for a set period of time.
