    Valet parking attendant means an employee of a valet parking service who operates, drives and parks motor vehicles in the course of his employment. 
    Valet parking service means a person who provides motor vehicle pickup and dropoff services, using in part the public right-of-way, for the purpose of temporarily parking such vehicles, and receives payment therefor. 
(Ord. No. 144,  1, 5-16-2000) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally,  1-2. 
Sec. 78-142. - General requirements. 
    The valet parking service shall: 
(1)	Provide sufficient personnel to handle all requests for valet parking promptly and to prevent motor vehicle congestion at pickup and dropoff points. 
(2)	Provide insurance in at least the following minimum amounts with the city named as an additional insured on all insurance policies other than workers' compensation insurance: 
a.	Garage liability, $500,000.00/occurrence, $500,000.00/aggregate
b.	Workers' compensation, statutory.
Insurance certificates evidencing the required coverages shall be deposited with the city. Each of the insurance contracts described in the certificates shall contain a clause requiring ten-day notice of cancellation to the city prior to the cancellation of any insurance coverage. 
(3)	Hire and retain as valet parking attendants only personnel 18 years of age or older, with valid state driver's licenses and no more than six points on their driving record as a result of moving traffic violations. 
(Ord. No. 144,  2, 5-16-2000) 
Sec. 78-143. - Attendant requirements. 
    The valet parking attendant shall: 
(1)	Be subject to all state and city traffic laws applicable to motor vehicles.
(2)	Be 18 years of age or older.
(3)	Possess a valid state driver's license with no more than six points on his driving record as a result of moving traffic violations. 
(4)	Not operate during those days and times of day nor operated upon those streets, alleys of other public ways, or places prohibited by regulations promulgated by the police chief. 
(5)	Present upon request an identification badge with a photograph of the attendant and the number of the valet parking service's license. 
(Ord. No. 144,  3, 5-16-2000) 
Sec. 78-144. - Use of public right-of-way. 
(a)	No valet parking service or attendant shall erect or maintain any form of shelter, key box sign or other facilities, in the public right-of-way for the use of attendants or patrons of the service unless duly licensed by the city. 
(b)	The valet parking service may use such portions of the public right-of-way as may be designated in the license issued by common council under the terms, conditions, and restrictions imposed by common council. 
(Ord. No. 144,  4, 5-16-2000) 
Sec. 78-145. - Parking areas. 
    All vehicles parked by a valet parking attendant shall be legally parked in conformance with city ordinances. No attendant shall park a vehicle in a street parking area. 
(Ord. No. 144,  5, 5-16-2000) 
Sec. 78-146. - Duties of the police chief. 
(a)	The police chief shall from time to time designate areas as pickup and dropoff points. All licensees shall stop only at such designated areas to pick up and drop off vehicles. 
(b)	The police chief shall from time to time set operating times for valet parking services that are most acceptable in terms of the public health, safety and welfare. 
(c)	The police chief shall make such other rules and regulations he deems necessary for the safety and efficient operation of valet parking services and for the protection of the public health, safety and welfare. 
(d)	The police chief shall cause the enforcement of this article, and may revoke a valet license for a violation of this article, rules, regulations or the terms, conditions or restrictions of the valet license. 
(e)	Any aggrieved person may appeal the actions of the police chief by a hearing before the mayor, upon written request detailing the action reviewable and the reason for such review and appeal. The mayor shall issue a recommendation to the common council for final action. 
(Ord. No. 144,  6, 5-16-2000) 
Sec. 78-147. - License. 
(a)	No person, either as owner, agent or otherwise, shall operate, conduct, maintain, advertise or otherwise be engaged in the valet parking service business upon the streets, alleys or other public ways or places unless the owner holds a currently valid license for a valet parking service pursuant to this article. 
(b)	Application for valet parking service licenses under this article shall be made to the city clerk upon such forms prescribed by the city, with the accompanying licensee fee as established by resolution. 
(c)	The application shall be referred to the police chief, who shall have a reasonable time in which to investigate the application and the background of the applicant. Based upon such investigation, the police chief shall recommend the common council to approve or deny the license application. In making his determination under this section, the police chief shall consider: 
(1)	The proposed location of the pickup and dropoff point of valet parking service or services; 
(2)	The traffic patterns in the area;
(3)	The availability of parking in the area;
(4)	The proposed parking area for motor vehicles parked by the valet parking service or services; 
(5)	The proposed location of signs; and
(6)	Whether such person has previously operated in this city or state or another city or state under a valet parking license or permit and has had such license or permit revoked or suspended; and the reasons therefor. 
(d)	The common council has sole authority to issue a license for valet parking.
(Ord. No. 144,  7, 5-16-2000) 
Secs. 78-148-78-170. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - ROLLER SKATES, STREET SKATES, SKATEBOARDS, ROLLER BLADES, ETC. 

Sec. 78-171. - Intent and purpose. 
    This article is designed to define and regulate the use of roller skates, street skates, scooters, skate blades, roller blades, skateboards and other roller devices, upon public property and property open to the general public, to protect the health, safety and welfare of the citizens of the city and to provide penalties for violations of this article. 
(Ord. No. 150 (intro ), 7-9-2002) 
Sec. 78-172. - Definitions. 
    Roller skates and street skates mean a set or series of small wheels on the bottom of a shoe or frame, or that would attach to a shoe or frame which are used for gliding on a hard surface such as a floor, sidewalk, parking lot, etc. 
    Scooter means a multiwheeled device designed to be ridden by a person standing thereon. 
    Skate blades and roller blades mean shoes with a row of wheels attached thereto, either permanently or temporarily affixed to a shoe or frame. 
    Skateboard means a board or flat piece of material consisting of metal, fiberglass, plastic, wood, or other material which has wheels affixed thereto, and is designed to be ridden by a person standing thereon. 
    To roller skate, for purposes of this article, means to skate on any type of roller skates, street skates, scooter, skate blades, roller blades, or skateboard. 
(Ord. No. 150,  (A), 7-9-2002) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally,  1-2. 
Sec. 78-173. - Violations of article. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to roller skate, in violation of the following: 
(1)	Riding on sidewalks. Whenever any person is roller skating, upon a sidewalk or other paved surface intended for use by pedestrians, such person shall yield the right-of-way to any pedestrian and shall not approach, overtake or pass such pedestrian in a reckless or careless manner, and shall not pass such pedestrian, except in single file, if such person is roller skating with other skaters. 
(2)	Riding on certain devices or structures. It shall be unlawful to roller skate on any bench, table, planter, wall, retaining wall, or other device, or structure, which is not intended for pedestrian or vehicle traffic, or to jump or step on or off such devices or structures in the process of roller skating. 
(3)	Riding prohibited where posted. The police chief is hereby authorized, by traffic control order, to erect signs on any publicly owned parking area, street, sidewalk, parking structure, parking lot, or other publicly owned property prohibiting roller skating thereon. 
(4)	Reckless and/or dangerous roller skating. It shall be unlawful for any person to roller skate on any sidewalk or other paved surface intended for pedestrians in a reckless or careless manner, or in a manner which is likely to result in injury or harm to any person or property. 
(5)	Riding on private property without permission. It shall be unlawful for any person to roller skate on any private property without first obtaining and carrying on his person the written permission of the owner of such private property to allow such roller skating. Failure of a person who has been roller skating on private property to produce such written permission, upon the request of any police officer, shall constitute prima facie evidence that such person is in violation of this section. 
(6)	Roller skating while attached to vehicles. No person shall roller skate while either the roller skates or the person is attached to any vehicle upon any street or highway or any area open to the general public. 
(Ord. No. 150,  (B), 7-9-2002) 
Sec. 78-174. - Penalty for violation of article. 
    Any person who violates any provision or section of this article shall be responsible for a civil infraction and responsible for a civil fine of not more than $100.00 and any reasonable court costs. 
(Ord. No. 150,  (C), 7-9-2002) 
Chapter 82 - UTILITIES

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 82-1. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Department means the department of public works. 
Cross reference- Definitions generally,  1-2. 
(Ord. No. 111B, 7-8-2006) 
Sec. 82-2. - Cross connections. 
(a)	The city adopts by reference the Water Supply Cross Connection Rules of the Michigan Department of Environmental Quality R325.11401-R325.11407 of the Michigan Administrative Code. This section does not supersede the state of Michigan Plumbing Code, but is supplementary to it. 
(b)	It shall be the duty of the department of public works to cause inspections to be made of all properties served by the public water supply where cross connections with the public water supply is deemed possible. The frequency of inspections and reinspections based on potential health hazards involved shall be as established by the department of public works and as approved by the state department of environmental quality. 
(c)	The representative of the department of public works shall have the right to enter at any reasonable time any property served by a connection to the public water supply system of the city for the purpose of inspecting the piping system or systems thereof for cross connections. On request, the owner, lessees or occupants of any property so served shall furnish to the inspection agency any pertinent information regarding the piping system or systems on such property. The refusal of such information or refusal of access, when requested, shall be deemed evidence of the presence of cross connections. 
(d)	The department of public works shall discontinue water service after reasonable notice to any property wherein any connection in violation of this section exists, and to take such other precautionary measures deemed necessary to eliminate any danger of contamination of the public water supply system. Water service to such property shall not be restored until the cross connections has been eliminated in compliance with the provisions of this section. 
(e)	The potable water supply made available on the properties served by the public water supply shall be protected from possible contamination as specified by this section and by the State of Michigan Plumbing Code. Any water outlet which could be used for potable or domestic purposes and which is not supplied by the potable system must be labeled in a conspicuous manner as: 
WATER UNSAFE
FOR DRINKING 
(f)	All testable backflow prevention devices shall be tested upon installation to be sure that the device is working properly. Subsequent testing of devices shall be conducted on an annual basis as required by the city and in accordance with the Michigan Department of Environmental Quality requirements. Only individuals that are approved and State of Michigan certified shall be qualified to perform such testing. That individual(s) shall certify the results of his/her testing. 
(g)	The "Cross Connection Control Plan" as prepared by Hydro Designs, Inc. for the City of Utica is hereby adopted by reference as the cross connection control plan for the city. Copies are on file with the city clerk's office. 
(h)	Any person found guilty of violating any of the provisions of this section, or any written order of the department of public works, in pursuance thereof, shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Ord. No. 111A,  1-7, 2-11-1997; Ord. No. 111B, 7-8-2006) 
Secs. 82-3-82-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - WATER AND SEWER RATES AND CHARGES 

Sec. 82-31. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    System means the water or sewer system. 
Cross reference- Definitions generally,  1-2. 
Sec. 82-32. - Establishment of rates and charges. 
    All rates and charges for services rendered by the water and sewer system shall be established by resolution. 
(Ord. No. 60,  9, 11-23-1962) 
Sec. 82-33. - Adjustment of rates. 
    The water and sewer rates shall be periodically adjusted by the superintendent of the department of public works by the percentage of any increase or decrease, rounded to the next highest whole percentage point, in the event water and sewer service rates charged to the city by the board of water/sewer commissioners of the City of Detroit. 
(Ord. No. 60B,  9(F), 11-14-1995) 
Sec. 82-34. - No free service. 
    No free service shall be furnished by the system to any person, firm or corporation, public or private, or to any public agency or instrumentality. 
(Ord. No. 60,  10, 11-23-1962) 
Sec. 82-35. - Billing. 
    All metered customers of the system will be billed quarterly and all bills must be paid within 30 days from the date on the bill, and ten percent will be added to the amount of the bill if not paid within 30 days from the date of the bill. Water shall be shut off if not paid within 90 days of the date due. Water so shut off shall not be turned on again until a turn-on charge in the amount established by resolution, plus all sums due and owing are paid in full. 
(Ord. No. 60,  9, 11-23-1962; Ord. No. 60-69,  1(a), 4-23-1968) 
Sec. 82-36. - Enforcement. 
    The charges for water and sewer services which are under the provisions of section 21 of Public Act No. 94 of 1933 (MCL 141.121) are made a lien on all premises served thereby, unless notice is given that a tenant is responsible, are hereby recognized to constitute such lien and whenever any such charge against any piece of property shall be delinquent for six months, the city official or officials in charge of the collection thereof shall certify annually, on May 1 of each year, to the tax-assessing officer of the city, the fact of such delinquency, whereupon such charge shall be by him entered upon the next tax roll as a charge against such premises and shall be collected and the lien thereof enforced in the same manner as general city taxes against such premises are collected, and the lien thereof enforced. Provided, however, where notice is given that a tenant is responsible for such charges and service as provided by section 21 (MCL 141.121), no further service shall be rendered such premises until a cash deposit in the amount established by resolution shall have been made as security for payment of such charges and service. 
(Ord. No. 60,  9, 11-23-1962; Ord. No. 60-69,  1, 4-23-1968) 
State law reference- Lien, MCL 141.121. 
Secs. 82-37-82-60. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - WATER SYSTEM 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 82-61. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Box (meter) means any approved box or vault for housing of water meters. 
    Consumer and customer mean the corporation, association, or individual being served by legally using water supplied by the city. 
    Consumer's installation means all pipes, valves, stops, plumbing and contrivances of every kind and nature used in connection with, or forming a part of, the consumer's installation for utilizing water for any purpose, connected directly or indirectly with the corporation stop at the main, whether such installation is owned outright or used under lease or otherwise, by the consumer. 
    Corporation stop means a valve which is inserted into the main for the connection of the water supply service pipes in sizes up to and including two inches in diameter. 
    Curb stop means a valve for insertion in the service pipes, in size of three-quarter inch to two inches, inclusive, in diameter, at or near the curbline. 
    Curb stop box means a box or metal housing which encloses, protects, and provides access to the curb stop. 
    Mains, municipal water, means the system of water pipes, valves, fittings and equipment use to distribute water throughout the area served by the municipal water system. Mains are located on public property or on private property over which easements have been provided. 
    Main (private) means any system of water pipes, valves, fittings, and equipment use to distribute water within the area served by the municipal water system but owned privately by a person or persons. 
    Plumber is licensed by the city in accordance with the city ordinances. 
    Premises means a property which cannot be completely divided in its present utilitarian condition through sale. That is: 
(1)	A building under one roof owned, leased, or occupied by one party as one business or residence; 
(2)	A combination of residential buildings, or of commercial buildings, leased or occupied by one party in one common enclosure; 
(3)	The one side of a double house having a solid vertical partition wall; or
(4)	A building owned by one party having more than one internal division, such as apartments, offices, stores, etc., and which may have a common or separate entrance. 
    Service control valve means a valve for installation in water service pipes, located at or near the main. 
    Service control valve box means a box or metal housing which encloses, protects, and provides access to the service control valve. 
    Sewage works means all facilities for collecting, pumping, treating, and disposing of sewage. 
    Stop and waste valve means a valve installed at the termination of the water supply service pipe of three-quarter-inch and one-inch sizes, and at the beginning of the consumer's plumbing system. Gate type. 
    Tap means the drilling and threading of an opening in a main for insertion of a corporation stop. 
(Ord. No. 39(1), art. I, 7-12-1960) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally,  1-2. 
Sec. 82-62. - Violations declared misdemeanor. 
    Any person who violates, disobeys, omits, neglects or refuses to comply with, or resists the enforcement of any provision of this article shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Ord. No. 39(1),  301, 7-12-1960) 
Sec. 82-63. - Withholding water from premises for violations. 
    A supply of water may be withheld from the premises when the ordinances of the city applying to water supply or rules and regulations of the common council have in any manner been violated. 
(Ord. No. 39(1),  224, 7-12-1960) 
Sec. 82-64. - Plumber to make connections. 
    No person shall make any attachment to or connection with the service pipes of the department unless registered as a master plumber with the department, or employed as a licensed journeyman plumber by a master plumber so registered. 
(Ord. No. 39(1),  220, 7-12-1960) 
Sec. 82-65. - Requirements for master plumbers. 
    Master plumbers must be residents of the state and at least 21 years of age. Master plumbers must be regularly educated artisans, masters of their trade. Master plumbers must have established places of business and proper signs thereon, or employed by business firms so established. Each master plumber must register with this department annually during the month of April, for which registration there is no charge, at the time he must present his state license and his board of health registration. No master plumber shall allow his name to be used by any other party, directly or indirectly, for the purpose of doing work or making the application of service connection. 
(Ord. No. 39(1),  221, 7-12-1960) 
Sec. 82-66. - Checkvalves and safety valves. 
    In private houses or buildings used for residence purposes only, it shall be of the option and risk of the owner whether he shall use checkvalves or not on feed pipes entering range boilers. A safety valve must be used wherever a checkvalve is set. 
(Ord. No. 39(1),  238, 7-12-1960) 
Sec. 82-67. - Use of fire hydrants; permit. 
(a)	No person shall, except authorized city personnel, use or take any water from any fire hydrant without having obtained a permit. The superintendent of the department of public works shall issue a permit upon the following conditions: 
(1)	The applicant files for a hydrant usage permit in such form and format as the superintendent may designate; 
(2)	Payment of a permit fee and deposit in the amount established by resolution;
(3)	Water usage shall be metered and the permittee shall pay the amount established by resolution for such usage; 
(4)	Permits shall expire after 30 days. Additional usage beyond 30 days may be authorized if processed as an original application with the full payment of new application fees and all charges due under the prior permit. 
(b)	The superintendent may adopt such rules and regulations as may be necessary to implement this section. 
(c)	The permittee is responsible for any costs, expenses or damages beyond water usage, which amounts may be deducted from the security deposit. 
(Ord. No. 60B,  9(G), 11-14-1995) 
Cross reference- Fire prevention and protection, ch. 30. 
Sec. 82-68. - Temporary emergency sprinkling restrictions. 
(a)	Whenever the mayor receives notification from the Detroit Water and Sewerage Department in conjunction with the water and radiological protection division of the state department of environmental quality that the supply or pressure demand for water cannot be accommodated and general welfare is likely to be endangered, or conditions within the water system of the city are likely to endanger the general welfare of the city, the mayor shall determine that a state of emergency exists and prescribe the following emergency shall apply in the city for all properties connected to the city water system. In such event, sprinkling of lawns and landscaping and all outdoor water use shall be only allowed for properties with even-numbered addresses on even-numbered dates within a month and for properties with odd-numbered addresses on odd-numbered dates within a month. 
(b)	Whenever the mayor receives notification from the Detroit Water and Sewerage Department in conjunction with the drinking water and radiological protection division of the state department of environmental quality that provisions in subsection (a) of this section are not sufficient, or conditions within the water system of the city are likely to endanger the general welfare of the city for all properties connected to the city water system, sprinkling of lawns and landscaping and all outdoor water use shall not be allowed. 
(c)	The city and the Detroit Water and Sewerage Department shall, within 24 hours of notification, cause these regulations to be posted at the city office and publicly announced by means of broadcasts or telecasts by the stations with a normal operating range covering the city and may cause such announcement to be further declared in newspapers of general circulation when feasible. The regulations shall become effective immediately after notice of enforcement of the ordinance as posted at the city offices. Upon notification from the Detroit Water and Sewerage Department in conjunction with the drinking water and radiological protection division of the state department of environmental quality that the emergency regulations are no longer necessary, the city shall cause a public announcement lifting the water restrictions. 
(Ord. No. 139,  1, 6-11-1996) 
Secs. 82-69-82-85. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - CONNECTIONS 

Sec. 82-86. - Application for service connections. 
    Applications for the installation of service connections shall be made by a registered master plumber at the city after the owner of the property or his authorized agent has made application for water service and has paid necessary fees. 
(Ord. No. 39(1),  201, 7-12-1960) 
Sec. 82-87. - Water connections to new buildings or structures; testing. 
    Within the limits of the city, no person shall install or cause to be installed, in any new building or structure located within the limits of the city, any plumbing required to be tested with water supplied by the city unless an application for water connection from the city water lines to the service has been issued by the city. 
(Ord. No. 39(1),  202, 7-12-1960) 
Sec. 82-88. - Information to be supplied to city. 
    Applicants must state, in detail, the purpose for which the supply is required, giving a legal description of the property to be served, side of street and between streets desired location of the service entry, other such information as required on printed forms supplied by the city. 
(Ord. No. 39(1),  203, 7-12-1960) 
Sec. 82-89. - Execution of applications for connections; expenses for incorrect installations. 
    Applicants will be held responsible for the proper execution of the applications for the water service and service connections. All expense incurred by reason of incorrect installation shall be charged to and paid for by the applicant. 
(Ord. No. 39(1),  204, 7-12-1960) 
Sec. 82-90. - Service connections; tapping water main. 
    All service connections and pipes from the water mains to the lot line shall be furnished and installed by the department. This work shall consist of tapping the main; inserting the corporation cock with proper couplings, laying of service pipe and providing a curb stop with the approved type of stop box, and cover marked "water." Copper must be installed before the tap is made. 
(Ord. No. 39(1),  205, 7-12-1960) 
Sec. 82-91. - Installation of water service connection. 
    The water service connection shall consist of the tap to the water main, the extension of the water service pipe to the curb stop and curb stop box or service control value and service control value box/service control valve gate well, whichever is applicable. The water service connection shall be installed completely within the street right-of-way or public easement provided. The person for whose benefit the connection is made shall, on behalf of himself, his heirs, executors, administrators or assigns, hold the city harmless for any loss or damage that may in any way be occasioned by the making of such connection. 
(Ord. No. 60B,  9(B), 11-14-1995) 
Sec. 82-92. - Obstructions to service connection; charges. 
    No service connection will be installed when the section the service line installed by the plumber is in the line with the driveway, tree, fire hydrant, catchbasin or other obstruction. The charge for each such water connection as established by the department as well as any other fees must be paid at the time of application. 
(Ord. No. 39(1),  206, 7-12-1960) 
Sec. 82-93. - Unusual circumstances; special permission. 
    In all cases where any unusual circumstances, relating to services or meters, make it necessary to deviate from the regular rules, special permission must be received from the department. 
(Ord. No. 39(1),  207, 7-12-1960) 
Sec. 82-94. - Specifications for new service pipe connections. 
    All new service pipes connecting with the distribution main shall be of lead, copper, or cast iron or such other material as has been approved by the department, and shall have an inside diameter of at least three-quarter of an inch. In no case will use of galvanized or wrought iron pipe be permitted. All risers under the sink and meter boxes must be lead or copper pipe. Galvanized pipe will not be accepted. 
(Ord. No. 39(1),  208, 7-12-1960) 
Sec. 82-95. - Copper pipe specifications. 
    The copper pipe used must be extra heavy, soft and meet the following specifications: The weight of copper pipe shall not vary more than five percent from the weight specified. All thickness and inside diameter shall not vary more than plus or minus 0.003 inches from the specifications given in this section. Copper tubes shall be seamless drawn or rolled kneeled for flanging purposes, and contain 99.94 percent pure copper, Type K. Joints between lengths of copper tubing shall be well-made, watertight, and develop the full strength of the copper tube. Joints between lengths of copper tubing shall be of the type ordinarily accepted by the department for underground work. 
(Ord. No. 39(1),  209, 7-12-1960) 
Sec. 82-96. - Curb valves. 
    Curb valves shall be used on all lead and copper connections up to and including two inches in diameter and must be the inverted type, round way, T-handled stopcock. All control valves on cast iron service connections, three inches or larger in diameter, shall be of the left hand key type, nonrising, stem with a two-inch square head to be constructed with a cast body of all brass. 
(Ord. No. 39(1),  210, 7-12-1960) 
Sec. 82-97. - Depth and installation of service pipes. 
    The top of all service pipes shall be at least five feet below the pavement grade and on paved streets where the final grades are not known, six feet below the surface of the earth. The five-foot depth applies to services extending into a building where there is no basement and where a meter pit is used. All service connections must be installed at least three feet from the existing gas service. Before installing water connection, the plumber must check the location of gas service. Service pipes must be uniform in size in their entirety. 
(Ord. No. 39(1),  211, 7-12-1960) 
Sec. 82-98. - Extension of service pipes to cellar or basement. 
    When premises have a cellar or basement, service pipes must be extended into the cellar or basement, and no branches taken therefrom except in the cellar or basement, and on the outlet side of the meter. 
(Ord. No. 39(1),  212, 7-12-1960) 
Sec. 82-99. - Installations vulnerable to frost or freezing. 
    It is expressly forbidden for any plumber to lay a service pipe inside of a building, along the outside wall, or in any position where there is danger of frost; also, to make new connections, or to install any new attachments or fixtures to old connections that shall require a running stream to prevent freezing. 
(Ord. No. 39(1),  213, 7-12-1960) 
Sec. 82-100. - Separate building connections. 
    On future installations, there shall be individual services; provided the common council may permit one service for conditions of use, occupancy, or ownership so warrant. Each building must have a separate connection with the street main, except in cases where there is more than one building located on a single lot or registered unit of land or on a group of adjacent land units used as a single piece of property such as a factory site, provided such lot or lots or parcels of land are held in undivided ownership. In such cases, the several buildings so located may be served by one connection with the main provided the service is of sufficient size to meet all requirements. Where two or more buildings are on one service and ownership is subsequently divided, individual service must then be installed. Unusual conditions not specifically contemplated here shall be reported to the department for disposition and the ruling of the department thereon shall be final. 
(Ord. No. 39(1),  214, 7-12-1960) 
Sec. 82-101. - Manifold services. 
    Manifold services will not be permitted on public property but may be installed on private property in basements or meter pits. 
(Ord. No. 39(1),  215, 7-12-1960) 
Sec. 82-102. - Permission required to cross street or alleys. 
    Water lines shall not be allowed to cross public streets or alleys without permission of the department and the municipal agency governing the roads or alleys. 
(Ord. No. 39(1),  216, 7-12-1960) 
Sec. 82-103. - Properties supplied by more than one service main. 
    Where properties are supplied by more than one service from different mains and connected inside the property, all services so connected must be provided with a meter and checkvalve properly maintained to prevent cross feeds, with waste crock on bottom of pipe, each side of check so as to drain pipes and meters. 
(Ord. No. 39(1),  217, 7-12-1960) 
Sec. 82-104. - Disconnection of unused service connections. 
    When a new service line is required, the owner of the property must have all unused service connections entering the property disconnected at the street main. When a new building is erected upon a property and existing service line is used, all unused lines entering such property must be disconnected at the street main. Plumbers will therefore, acquaint themselves as to the existence of old service lines, which information can be obtained from the records of the department. Charges for disconnecting all services except those in the same trench as the new service and of the screw type, shall be borne by the parties applying for the disconnection. 
(Ord. No. 39(1),  218, 7-12-1960) 
Sec. 82-105. - Cross connection prohibited; color coding of water pipes. 
(a)	Any connection between water pipes receiving their supply from the city mains or pipes carrying water from underground storage tanks or other sources is expressly forbidden. 
(b)	When properties with water from other sources than city mains is used, water service must be equipped with a physical break or air gap with test cocks on the meter in accordance with the state and county health department regulations. 
(c)	Systems using water from any other source than city mains must paint or color-code all pipes carrying the city water in light blue and all lines carrying water from the other sources shall be painted brown except in plants where color-codes have already been adopted, and these codes provide different colors for water and other water. Such codes will be accepted providing charts depicting the various colors are prominently displayed in the plant. Failure to comply with section 82-104 shall deem to be sufficient cause to discontinue the water supply to any plant or district where the violation occurs. 
(Ord. No. 39(1),  219, 7-12-1960) 
Sec. 82-106. - Inspection of underground service piping. 
    All underground service piping must be inspected by the department before it is covered. Twenty-four hours' notice is required for such inspection. Any part of the plumber's work which does not comply with the regulations and requirements of the department will be rejected and must be changed to meet these requirements. 
(Ord. No. 39(1),  222, 7-12-1960) 
Sec. 82-107. - Refusal to accept incorrect installations. 
    The department may refuse to accept applications for installation of service connection from any plumber whose outstanding work has not been installed according to the rules and regulations of the department. 
(Ord. No. 39(1),  223, 7-12-1960) 
Sec. 82-108. - City to tap or connect mains, insert service cock. 
    No persons shall tap or connect any water main or insert a service cock within except the employees of the department duly authorized to do so. 
(Ord. No. 39(1),  225, 7-12-1960) 
Sec. 82-109. - Temporary taps. 
    Applications for temporary taps must state the length of time for which the connection is to be used. If a temporary tap is to be used for a longer period than originally requested, an extension of time must be obtained from the office of the department. 
(Ord. No. 39(1),  226, 7-12-1960) 
Secs. 82-110-82-125. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - METERS 

Sec. 82-126. - Required. 
(a)	All connections with the water mains must be prepared for the use of water through a meter. 
(b)	The department reserves the right to read, service and install meters and their appurtenances including remote meter installations. 
(c)	The department must be allowed an entrance to the property including the building in which a water meter is installed to accomplish the activity set forth in subsection (a) of this section. 
(d)	Upon failure to comply with the requirements of subsections (a) and (b) of this section, the owner or occupier of the premises, after a ten-day registered notice, shall be subject to section 82-63 
(Ord. No. 39(1),  227, 7-12-1960) 
Sec. 82-127. - Meters for multiple units. 
    A block of store buildings, a terrace building, or apartment house may have a single meter for all or separate meters for each unit, depending upon the arrangement of the service line. 
(Ord. No. 39(1),  228, 7-12-1960) 
Sec. 82-128. - Water meters. 
(a)	The department will furnish meters as follows:
(1)	Single dwellings: Five-eighth inch or three-quarter inch.
(2)	Two-family apartments: Three-quarter inch or one inch.
(3)	Four-family or larger apartments: One inch.
(b)	When larger meters are needed, the applicant will be required to pay the difference between the price of the meter furnished by the department in the place of the meter required. 
(c)	All properties under a combination of residential and commercial shall be classified as commercial. 
(d)	In all residential, combination residential-commercial properties and apartment hotels, where meter requires three inches or larger, it must be of the compound type. 
(e)	The department will furnish only one meter for a service. All meters in addition to the one paid for by the board must be paid for by the owner. Should more than one meter be placed in a single line, an agreement must be signed by the property owner, protecting the city in treating the property in its entirety should enforcement of the rules and regulations necessitate a shutoff. 
(Ord. No. 39(1),  229, 7-12-1960) 
Sec. 82-129. - Purchase of meter by customers outside city limits. 
    Outside the city limits where the city collects from individual suburban customers if such exist, meters must be purchased by the owner or occupant of the premises. 
(Ord. No. 39(1),  230, 7-12-1960) 
Sec. 82-130. - Meter required before occupancy. 
    The meter must be set before the property becomes occupied on new homes. 
(Ord. No. 39(1),  231, 7-12-1960) 
Sec. 82-131. - Additional trip charges. 
    When, due to faulty work, it is necessary to make more than one trip to set a meter, a charge in an amount established by resolution will be made for each additional trip. 
(Ord. No. 39(1),  232, 7-12-1960) 
Sec. 82-132. - Interference or removal of meter; permission required. 
    All persons are forbidden to interfere with or remove a water meter from any service connection without first receiving permission from the department. Whenever the meter is removed by permission, it must be immediately returned to the department under penalty of having the water shut off and/or his plumber's registration revoked. 
(Ord. No. 39(1),  233, 7-12-1960) 
Sec. 82-133. - Access to meters. 
    Meters and their valves will not be allowed in closets or departments that are kept locked, in coal bins, under buildings, porches, or any location where there is difficulty of access. Meters and their valves will be allowed in lavatories, and under show windows only as follows: A meter may be set in a lavatory of a gas station provided meter is set in a clean, sanitary location, easily accessible for removal or reading. The meter may be set under show windows only when set within eight inches off the floor, at least 24 inches wide and 24 inches high with the couplings at least four inches above the floor with 18 inches clearance above the meter coupling to allow for meter reading. The meter shall be set opposite the center of the doorway. 
(Ord. No. 39(1),  234, 7-12-1960) 
Sec. 82-134. - Conditions for setting meter. 
    All meters shall be set horizontally and dry, clean, sanitary, perfectly accessible with valves on both sides and where a small leak in the flowage of water will do no damage. A shutoff will not be accepted in place of a valve. 
(Ord. No. 39(1),  235, 7-12-1960) 
Sec. 82-135. - Services requiring "T" valve. 
    All meters 11/2 inches or larger must have a "T" between the meter and outlet valves to be used for testing the meter without its removal. The size of the side opening of the "T" shall be 11/2 inches, for 11/2 service, and two inches for all service pipe up to four inches and three inches for larger service pipe, according to plans which can be had upon application to the city. Side opening of such "T" shall be plugged. Any service larger than 11/2 inches must be equipped with a valved bypass. The department shall install all meters after preparation for their reception has been made by the plumber except detector checks used on file lines, in which case the plumber will have to call for detector checks and install it on their line. 
(Ord. No. 39(1),  236, 7-12-1960) 
Sec. 82-136. - Setting meters below grade. 
    Meters can be set below grade line, in a brick or cement wall, cellar or basement, under kitchen sink or on the first floor. A run, not to exceed 130 feet, will be allowed between the lot line nearest the street main and the meter. 
(Ord. No. 39(1),  237, 7-12-1960) 
Sec. 82-137. - Lawn sprinkler cleaning or auto washing connections. 
(a)	In this section:
    Area maintenance means uses for water outside of a building or structure that: 
(1)	Does not deposit such water into a sanitary system by other than accidental absorption;
(2)	Is generally and traditionally associated with uses such as:
a.	Watering lawns;
b.	Cleaning outside structures;
c.	Washing automobiles and other personal property; and
(3)	Is used solely upon and at the property where the area maintenance meter is located.
(b)	The owner of any premises using metered water may, upon application, preinspection, signing an agreement as provided for in this section, obtaining a permit, and paying such fees as required by resolution, install a separate water meter for metering the use of water for area maintenance. 
(c)	The cost of the area maintenance meter and its installation shall be paid by the property owner. The area maintenance meter shall be connected on the water line coming into the building from the public water supply immediately before the regular meter for the premises. Only lines approved by the department shall be connected at the area maintenance meter. There shall be no connections, or use of water directly from the area maintenance meter, for other than approved outdoor area maintenance. 
(d)	An owner shall enter into an agreement with the city before receiving a permit for an area maintenance meter. The agreement shall conform to Exhibit A to Ordinance No. 113A, or as it is modified by resolution. Proof of ownership of the subject property shall be required prior to any approval. The superintendent of the department, building inspector or city clerk is authorized to execute the agreement on behalf of the city. 
(e)	The charge for water billed through an area maintenance meter shall be the same rate charged for all water usage in the city, however, no sewer charge or sewer surcharge shall be added thereto. Charges shall be billed and paid semiannually. A penalty of ten percent shall be added to any bill not paid within 30 days. Charges shall constitute a lien upon the property as provided in this article. 
(f)	The department and the building department shall, at any reasonable hour, have the right to enter any building wherein there is an area maintenance meter to inspect the meter and piping system to see that there are no violations respecting the area maintenance meter. The refusal of entry, upon request, shall be unlawful. 
(g)	A violation of this section shall constitute a misdemeanor. Upon there appearing to be a violation of the provisions of this section, the city may, at its option, do any or all of the following: 
(1)	Disconnect the area maintenance meter;
(2)	Suspend water service to the premises;
(3)	Add the sewer charge and, if applicable, the surcharge for water used by the area maintenance meter; 
(4)	Institute court proceedings;
(5)	Assess actual costs necessary to enforce this section, including legal fees associated with court action. 
(Ord. No. 113A,  1-6, 11-14-1995) 
Secs. 82-138-82-160. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - SEWERS AND SEWAGE DISPOSAL 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 82-161. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    BOD (biochemical oxygen demand) means the quantity of oxygen utilized in the biochemical oxidation of organic matter under standard laboratory procedure in five days at 20 degrees Celsius, expressed in parts per million by weight. 
    Building drain means that part of the lowest horizontal piping of a drainage system which receives the discharge from soil, waste, and other drainage pipes inside the walls of the building and conveys it to the building sewer, beginning five feet outside the inner face of the building wall. 
    Building sewer means the extension from the building drain to the public sewer or other place of disposal. 
    Combined sewer means a sewer receiving both surface runoff and sewage. 
    Garbage means solid wastes from the preparation, cooking and dispensing of food, and from the handling, storage and sale of produce. 
    Industrial wastes means the liquid wastes from industrial processes as distinct from sanitary sewerage. 
    Natural outlet means any outlet into a watercourse, pond, ditch, lake or other body of surface water or groundwater. 
    pH means the logarithm of the reciprocal of the weight of hydrogen ions in grams per liter of solution. 
    Properly shredded garbage means the wastes from the preparation, cooking and dispensing of food that have been shredded to such degree that all particles will be carried freely under the flow conditions normally prevailing in public sewers, with no particle greater than one-half inch in any diameter. 
    Public sewer means a sewer in which all owners of abutting properties have equal rights, and is controlled by public authority. 
    Sanitary sewer means a sewer which carries sewage and to which stormwater, surface water, and groundwater are not intentionally admitted. 
    Sewage means a combination of the water-carried wastes from residences, business buildings, institutions, and industrial establishments, together with such groundwaters, surface water, and stormwater as may be present. 
    Sewage treatment plant means any arrangement of devices and structures used for treating sewage. 
    Sewage works means all facilities for collecting, pumping, treating, and disposing of sewage. 
    Sewer means a pipe or conduit for carrying a sewage. 
    Storm sewer and storm drain mean a sewer which carries stormwater and surface water and drainage, but excludes sewage and polluted industrial wastes. 
    Superintendent means the superintendent of the department or his authorized deputy, agent, or representative. 
    Suspended solids means the solids that either float on the surface of, or are in suspension in water, sewage, or other liquids; and which are removable by laboratory filtering. 
    Watercourse means a channel in which a flow of water occurs, either continuously or intermittently. 
(Ord. No. 39(2),  101-119, 7-12-1960) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally,  1-2. 
Sec. 82-162. - Violations. 
(a)	Any person, firm, corporation or other organization which violates, disobeys, omits, neglects or refuses to comply with, or resists the enforcement of any provisions of this article, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(b)	Any person, firm, corporation or other organization which violates, disobeys, omits, neglects or refuses to comply with, or resists the enforcement of any of the provisions of this article shall be responsible to the city for all costs, expenses or other damages occasioned by such conduct. Such liability may be enforced in addition to any criminal penalty by an appropriate civil action. 
(Ord. No. 39(2),  1101, 7-12-1960; Ord. No. 39-3, 3-18-1980) 
Sec. 82-163. - Powers and authority of inspectors. 
    The superintendent and other duly authorized employees of the city bearing proper credentials and identification shall be permitted to enter upon all properties for the purposes of inspection, observation, measurement, sampling, and testing, in accordance with the provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. 39(2),  601, 7-12-1960) 
Sec. 82-164. - Use of public sewers required. 
(a)	It shall be unlawful for any person to place, deposit, or permit to be placed or deposited in an unsanitary manner upon public or private property within the city or in any area under the jurisdiction of the city any human or animal excrement, garbage, or other objectionable waste. 
(b)	It shall be unlawful to discharge to any natural outlet within the city or in any area under the jurisdiction of the city any sanitary sewage, industrial wastes, or other polluted waters, except where suitable treatment has been provided in accordance with subsequent provisions of this article. 
(c)	Except as provided in this article, it shall be unlawful to construct or maintain any privy, privy vault, septic tank, cesspool, or other facility intended or used for the disposal of sewage. 
(d)	The owner of all houses, buildings or properties used for human occupancy, employment, recreation, or other purpose situated with the city and abutting on any street, alley or right-of-way in which there is now located or may in the future be located a public sanitary or combined sewer of the city is hereby required at his expense to install suitable toilet facilities therein, and to connect such facilities directly with the proper public sewer in accordance with the provisions of this article within 90 days after date of official notice to do so, provided that the public sewer is within 100 feet of the property line. 
(Ord. No. 39(2),  201-204, 7-12-1960) 
Sec. 82-165. - Filling of septic tanks. 
    All septic tanks within the city which cease to be used by the premises shall be filled with a suitable material determined by the building inspector. Property owners of the premises having unused septic tanks as of November 11, 1975, shall be given a notice by the building inspector that they shall have 90 days from the date of such notice to comply with the provisions of this article. Applicants for sewer taps be advised that upon completion of the connection to the sanitary sewer shall have 30 days to comply with the requirement of filling their unused septic tanks. 
(Ord. No. 101,  1-3, 11-11-1975) 
Sec. 82-166. - Damaging or tampering sewage works. 
    No unauthorized person shall maliciously, willfully, or negligently break, damage, destroy, uncover, deface or tamper with any structure, appurtenance, or equipment which is a part of the municipal sewage works. 
(Ord. No. 39(2),  501, 7-12-1960) 
Sec. 82-167. - Registration and licensing of persons installing or repairing sewer system. 
(a)	No person shall lay, alter, or repair any house drain or sewer work, or make any connections whatever with any sewer or house or building belonging to the sanitary sewer system, or do any kind of work connected with the laying of house drains or house sewers or making any repairs, additions or alterations of any drain or sewer connected, or designed to be connected with the sanitary sewer system, unless regularly registered by the city. Any person doing such work without such registration shall be deemed guilty of a violation of this article and shall be subject to penalties as provided in this article. 
(b)	Any person desiring to do business as a sewer builder and to construct house drains connecting with the sewer system of the city shall file in the office of the city clerk a petition giving the name of the individual, firm or corporation, together with his place of business and such other information as may be required by the city and asking to be registered by the city clerk as a sewer builder. Such petition must show that such person is experienced in his trade and willing to be governed in all respects by the rules and regulations which are or may be adopted by the common council. Each applicant shall at the time of making his application pay an annual registration fee established by resolution and the application shall contain an agreement on the part of the applicant that if licensed he will indemnify and save harmless the city from all accidents and damages caused by any negligence in protecting his work, or by any unfaithful, imperfect, inadequate, careless or unskilled work done by him, and that he will also promptly and at a proper time replace and restore sidewalk, pavement or street surface or any opening he may have made to as good a state and condition as he found previous to opening the sidewalk, pavement or street surface, and keep and maintain the sidewalk, pavement or street surface in good order to the satisfaction of the municipal authority having jurisdiction for the period of one year next thereafter. On receiving his license, the city clerk shall make a record thereof and of the actual place of business, the name under which the business is transacted, and the licensee shall immediately notify the city clerk of any change in either thereafter. No license shall be granted for more than. one year and all licenses shall be granted to expire on May 1 next succeeding their issue. The contractor shall provide bond as required by the city. 
(Ord. No. 39(2),  1001, 1002, 7-12-1960) 
Sec. 82-168. - Sewer taps and permits. 
(a)	The builder will be held responsible and shall take steps necessary to prevent sand, mud, and water from entering the sanitary sewer. A sewer tapping permit will be issued for each house at the time the building permit is issued. At this time, a deposit in the amount established by resolution will be made. The deposit will be held in escrow by the city for one year or until such time as the city engineer and the superintendent are satisfied that the sewers are functioning properly. 
(b)	If the sewer in the street has to be cleaned due to sand and debris entering the sewer, it will be cleaned and amount of cleaning deducted on a pro rata basis from the escrowed monies of all houses involved. If a builder takes out five or more permits in the block, the deposit will be reduced in the amount established by resolution. The inspection fee remains the same. 
(Ord. No. 39(2),  801, 7-12-1960) 
Sec. 82-169. - Sewer tap charge. 
    No tap (sewer connection) charges except for inspection shall be made when sewer risers and sewer leads are installed by the property owner at the property owner's cost or when sewer risers and sewer leads are installed by the city and the cost has been included in a special assessment against the property owner. 
(Ord. No. 60B,  9(D), 11-14-1995) 
Sec. 82-170. - Roof water and surface water drainage. 
(a)	It shall be unlawful for any person, firm, builder or contractor to construct or permit to be constructed, or permit the continuation of use of any drain for roof water or surface water in such a manner that roof water or surface water will drain into the sanitary sewer system of the city. 
(b)	The city engineer shall, within 30 days after November 6, 1951, furnish the city clerk with a list of any and all locations within the city where a violation of the provisions of this section occur. The city clerk shall immediately notify each person violating this section, by depositing a notice regarding such violation in the United States Mail, registered, return receipt requested, and such notice shall advise of the mailing of such notice, then that person will be prosecuted for violation of this section. 
(Ord. No. 22,  A, B, 11-6-1951) 
Secs. 82-171-82-185. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - BUILDING SEWERS AND CONNECTIONS 

FOOTNOTE(S):
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Buildings and building regulations, ch. 10. (Back)
Sec. 82-186. - Permit. 
(a)	No unauthorized person shall uncover, make any connections with or opening into, use, alter, or disturb any public sewer or appurtenances thereof without first obtaining a written permit from the city. 
(b)	There shall be two classes of building sewer permits:
(1)	For residential and commercial service; and
(2)	For service to establishments producing industrial wastes.
In either case, the owner or his agent shall make application on a special form furnished by the city. The permit application shall be supplemented by any plans, specifications, or other information considered pertinent in the judgement of the superintendent. A permit and inspection fee as established by resolution for a residential or commercial building sewer permit and a fee as established by resolution for an industrial building sewer permit shall be paid to the city at the time the application is filed. 
(Ord. No. 39(2),  301, 302, 7-12-1960) 
Sec. 82-187. - Responsibility for costs and expenses. 
    All costs and expenses incident to the installation and connection of the building sewer shall be borne by the owner. The owner shall indemnify the city from any loss or damage that may directly or indirectly be occasioned by the installation of the building sewer. 
(Ord. No. 39(2),  303, 7-12-1960) 
Sec. 82-188. - Separate building sewers. 
    A separate and independent building sewer shall be provided for every building; except where one building stands at the rear of another on an interior lot and no private sewer is available or can be constructed to the rear building through an adjoining alley, court, yard, or driveway, the building sewer from the front building may be extended to the rear building and the whole considered as one building sewer. 
(Ord. No. 39(2),  304, 7-12-1960) 
Sec. 82-189. - Old building sewers. 
    Old building sewers may be used in connection with new buildings only when they are found, on examination and test by the city, to meet all requirements of this article. 
(Ord. No. 39(2),  305, 7-12-1960) 
Sec. 82-190. - Specifications. 
    The building sewer shall be cast iron soil pipe, slip seal type vitrified clay sewer pipe, or other suitable material approved by the city. Joints shall be tight and waterproof. Any part of the building sewer that is located within five feet of a water service pipe shall be constructed of cast iron soil pipe with leaded joints. Cast iron pipe with leaded joints may be required by the city where the building sewer is exposed to damage by tree roots. If installed in filled or unstable ground, the building sewer shall be of cast iron soil pipe, except that nonmetallic material may be accepted if laid on suitable concrete bed or cradle as approved by the city. 
(Ord. No. 39(2),  306, 7-12-1960) 
Sec. 82-191. - Size and slope. 
    The size and slope of the building sewer shall be subject to the approval of the city, but in no event shall the diameter be less than six inches. The slope of such six-inch pipe shall be not less than one-eighth inch per foot. 
(Ord. No. 39(2),  307, 7-12-1960) 
Sec. 82-192. - Elevation. 
    Whenever possible, the building sewer shall be brought to the building at an elevation below the basement floor. No building sewer shall be laid parallel to or within three feet of any bearing wall, which might thereby be weakened. The depth shall be sufficient to afford protection from frost. The building sewer shall be laid at uniform grade and in straight alignment insofar as possible. Changes in direction shall be made only with properly curved pipe and fittings. 
(Ord. No. 39(2),  308, 7-12-1960) 
Sec. 82-193. - Low drains. 
    In all buildings in which any building drain is too low to permit gravity flow to the public sewer, sanitary sewage carried by such drain shall be lifted by approved artificial means and discharged to the building sewer. 
(Ord. No. 39(2),  309, 7-12-1960) 
Sec. 82-194. - Trench work; specifications. 
    All excavations required for the installation of a building sewer shall be open trench work unless otherwise approved by the city. Pipe laying and backfill shall be performed in accordance with ASTM specification C-12-19 except that no backfill shall be placed until the work has been inspected. 
(Ord. No. 39(2),  310, 7-12-1960) 
Sec. 82-195. - Joints and connections. 
(a)	All joints and connections shall be made gastight and watertight. Cast iron pipe joints shall be firmly packed with oakum or hemp and filled with molten lead, Federal Specification 00-L-156, not less than one inch deep. Lead shall be run in one pouring and caulked tight. No paint, varnish, or other coatings shall be permitted on the jointing material until after the joint has been tested and approved. 
(b)	All joints in vitrified clay pipe or between such pipe and metals shall be made with approved hot-poured jointing material or cement mortar as specified in subsection (c) of this section. 
(c)	Material for hot-poured joints shall not soften sufficiently to destroy the effectiveness of the joint when subjected to a temperature of 160 degrees Fahrenheit, nor be soluble in any of the wastes carried by the drainage system. The joint shall first be caulked tight with jute, hemp, or similar approved material. 
(d)	Cement joints wall be made by packing a closely twisted jute or oakum gasket, or suitable size to fill partly the annular space between the pipes. The remaining space shall be filled and firmly compacted with mortar composed of one part Portland cement and three parts mortar sand. The material shall be mixed dry; only sufficient water shall be added to make the mixture workable. Mortar which has begun to set shall not be used or retempered. Lime putty or hydrated lime may be substituted to the extent of not more than 25 percent of the volume of the Portland cement that may be added. 
(e)	Other jointing materials and methods may be used only by approval of the city.
(Ord. No. 39(3),  311, 7-12-1960) 
Sec. 82-196. - Connection to building sewer. 
    The connection of the building sewer into the public sewer shall be made at the "Y" branch, if such branch is available at a suitable location. If the public sewer is less than 12 inches in diameter, and no properly located "Y" branch is available, a neat hole may be cut into the public sewer to receive the building sewer, with entry in the downstream direction at an angle of about 45 degrees. A saddle or 45-degree ell may be used to make such connection, with the spigot end cut so as not to extend past the inner surface of the public sewer. The invert of the building sewer at the point of connection shall be at the same or at a higher elevation than the invert of the public sewer. A smooth, neat joint shall be made, and the connection made secure and watertight by encasement in concrete. Special fittings may be used for the connection only when approved by the city. 
(Ord. No. 39(3),  312, 7-12-1960) 
Sec. 82-197. - Notification for inspection; supervision of connection. 
    The applicant for the building sewer permit shall notify the city 24 hours prior to the time inspection is required and connection to the public sewer. The connection shall be made under the supervision of the superintendent or his representative. 
(Ord. No. 39(3),  313, 7-12-1960) 
Sec. 82-198. - Barricading and lighting of excavations. 
    All excavations for building sewer installation shall be adequately guarded with barricades and lights so as to protect the public from hazard. Streets, sidewalks, parkways and other public property disturbed in the course of the work shall be restored in a manner satisfactory to the city or other municipal authority having jurisdiction. 
(Ord. No. 39(3),  314, 7-12-1960) 
Secs. 82-199-82-215. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - HOUSE LEADS AND CONNECTIONS 

Sec. 82-216. - Plugging of laterals. 
    The sewer contractor shall plug all laterals from the sewer with a solid disc cemented into the end of the pipe. 
(Ord. No. 39(9),  901, 7-12-1960) 
Sec. 82-217. - Plugging of house lead; connection of weep tile or sump pump to sewer prohibited. 
    The house lead when laid to the house shall be plugged with a solid disc cemented in. This plug shall not be removed until such time as the cast iron is installed. The openings in the cast iron house lead shall be plugged with a metal plug, either a cast iron plug or a galvanized iron disc and cemented with mastic to prevent water from entering sewer. Weep tile shall be connected to an internal or external sump and discharged by adequate piping or tubing to a ditch or storm sewer. Neither weep tiles nor sump pumps shall be connected to a sanitary sewer. Sump pumps shall not be discharged into a sanitary sewer. 
(Ord. No. 39(9),  902, 7-12-1960; Ord. No. 39-3, 3-18-1980) 
Sec. 82-218. - Notification prior to connection of building sewer and weep tile. 
    The builder shall notify the city at least 24 hours prior to connection of the building sewer and again 24 hours before connection of the weep tile. 
(Ord. No. 39(9),  903, 7-12-1960) 
Sec. 82-219. - Requirements to pass inspection. 
    Requirements to pass inspection, as provided in this article, are as follows: Immediately prior to calling for inspection of not more than two days prior thereto, the trench leading to the sanitary sewer must have been properly excavated to the depth and grade, and be in readiness for laying the sewer service line in the making of connection to the sanitary sewer. Between that time the trench is open, it will be the building contractor's responsibility to maintain in proper position the plug at the end of the pipe leading to the lot line from the sanitary sewer. 
(Ord. No. 39(9),  904, 7-12-1960) 
Sec. 82-220. - Issuance of permit; approval of service line and connection; backfilling. 
    When the city shall have found all conditions to exist as required by this article, the city shall issue to the building contractor the permit to lay the service line to make the connection with the sanitary sewer, and to backfill all basement walls, footings or foundations to grade so that all rainwaters will flow away from the house or building. After such service line has been laid, and the connection made to the sanitary sewer, and before the service line and connection are covered, the approval of the city shall be required before the trench and the service line shall be backfilled. The city shall have the full right and the authority to require such changes and modifications to the laying of such service line and/or its connection to the sanitary sewer as are in accordance with safe practice and the provisions of any county or state sanitary regulations or laws relating thereto. Upon such approval being obtained, the building contractor shall, within 24 hours thereafter, backfill the trench containing service line connection to the sanitary sewer, providing sufficient backfill then and thereafter to maintain a grade over the trench, not lower than the proper grade of the lot at the sidelines of the trench. The cost of the two inspections provided for are included in the fee provided in section 82-168, but further additional inspection shall be at the rate established by resolution, which sum or sums shall be paid to the city clerk before such additional inspection is made. At the time of the connection of this service line to the sanitary sewer, the contractor will effectively and permanently plug such sewer connection; including plugging of outlet from perimeter tiles and maintain such plugs or plug until the rough carpentry of the house or building has been substantially completed, and the roof is in place and fully completed. At such time, all such plugs may be removed by the building contractor upon the approval of the city. 
(Ord. No. 39(9),  905, 7-12-1960) 
Sec. 82-221. - Other drainage. 
    Up to the time the service connection is made to the sanitary sewer, as provided here and after, the building contractor shall so conduct his operations that all drainage required in the basement excavation, inside and outside, and all drainage of other sorts required as a result of building operations must have been effected and realized by some other means other than by use of the sanitary sewer. 
(Ord. No. 39(9),  906, 7-12-1960) 
Sec. 82-222. - Pumping of accumulated water. 
    In the digging of each and every basement excavation, the building contractor shall provide a sump toward which the entire excavation shall be sloped, and from which accumulated water may be pumped. The building contractor shall provide in each building area one or more pumps of sufficient capacity to pump and remove such accumulated water, and the building contractor shall pump and remove such accumulated water into the roadside ditches or drainage ditches existing in the area. 
(Ord. No. 39(9),  907, 7-12-1960) 
Sec. 82-223. - Grade and slope around houses and buildings during building operations. 
    During all building operations, and after backfill and after sanitary sewer connection has been made, the building contractor and/or owner shall maintain a grade away from each house or building so that all surface water and rainwaters shall flow away from the house or building. 
(Ord. No. 39(9),  908, 7-12-1960) 
Sec. 82-224. - Gutters and downspouts. 
    In all houses or buildings the design of which provides for eave gutters and downspouts, all such downspouts shall be connected to the storm sewers, if available, or shall be fitted with elbows and conductor pipe not less than 16 inches from the elbow, and in such cases, the building contractor shall provide concrete splashblocks at the time such downspouts are installed, which shall carry the water a minimum of four feet away from the basement wall to a point where surface drainage will carry the water away from the house. Depositing of the roof waters, by the use of gutters and downspouts, upon the graded side of the house or building within four feet of the house or building or by any other means allowing roof waters to enter the sanitary sewer system, is hereby specifically prohibited. 
(Ord. No. 39(9),  909, 7-12-1960) 
Sec. 82-225. - Maintenance of slope or grade. 
    After occupancy of any house or building has been granted, where such house or building is connected to sanitary sewer, the owner thereof shall be responsible for maintaining such slope or grade away from the house or building so that all surface water will flow away from the house or building, and shall maintain his roof conductors, downspouts and splashblocks in such a manner as will prevent surface water or roof water from infiltrating around the basement wall or foundation footings as provided in this article. 
(Ord. No. 39(9),  910, 7-12-1960) 
Sec. 82-226. - Maintenance of house lead. 
    The owner is responsible for maintaining the house lead up to the municipal sewer main in the street. If any excavation is necessary in the public right-of-way, permission must be obtained from the public authority having jurisdiction. 
(Ord. No. 39(9),  911, 7-12-1960) 
Sec. 82-227. - Demonstration of clear sewer lead. 
    Prior to final building inspection and issuance of occupancy permit, the building contractor or owner may be required to show the superintendent that the sewer lead is clear from the house to the main. 
(Ord. No. 39(9),  912, 7-12-1960) 
Secs. 82-228-82-245. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - USE RESTRICTIONS 

Sec. 82-246. - City of Detroit sewage treatment ordinance. 
    The provisions of Ord. No. 125B are hereby adopted by reference. 
(Ord. No. 125B, 12-13-2005) 
Sec. 82-247. - Stormwater discharge prohibition. 
    No person shall discharge or cause to be discharged any stormwater, surface water, groundwater, roof runoff, subsurface drainage, cooling water or unpolluted industrial process waters to any sanitary sewer. Yard drains, patio drains, catchbasins, downspouts, weep tile, perimeter drains or any other structure used for the collection and conveyance of stormwater shall not be permitted to discharge into any sanitary sewer connected directly or indirectly to the city system. 
(Ord. No. 39(4),  401, 7-12-1960; Ord. No. 39-11, 9-10-1968) 
Sec. 82-248. - Discharge of stormwater and unpolluted drainage in designated storm sewers; industrial cooling water and process waters. 
    Stormwater and all other unpolluted drainage shall be discharged to such sewers as are specifically designated as storm sewers, or to a natural outlet approved by the city. Industrial cooling water or unpolluted process waters may be discharged, upon approval of the city, to a storm sewer or natural outlet. 
(Ord. No. 39(4),  402, 7-12-1960) 
Sec. 82-249. - Prohibited discharges. 
    Except as provided in this article, no person shall discharge or cause to be discharged any of the following described waters or wastes to any public sewer: 
(1)	Any liquid or vapor having a temperature higher than 100 degrees Fahrenheit.
(2)	Any water or waste which may contain more than 100 parts per million, by weight, of fat, oil, or grease. 
(3)	Any gasoline, benzene, naphtha, fuel oil, or other flammable or explosive liquid, solid or gas. 
(4)	Any garbage that has not been properly shredded.
(5)	Any ashes, cinders, sand, mud, straw, shavings, metal, glass, rags, feathers, tar, plastics, wood, paunch manure, or any other solid or viscous substance capable of causing obstruction to the flow in sewers or other interference with the proper operation of the sewage works. 
(6)	Any waters or wastes having a pH lower than 5.5 or higher than 9.0 or having other corrosive property capable of causing damage or hazard to structures, equipment, and personnel of the sewage works. 
(7)	Any waters or wastes containing a toxic or poisonous substance in sufficient quantity to injure or interfere with any sewage treatment process, constitute a hazard to humans or animals, or create any hazard in the receiving waters of the sewage treatment plant. 
(8)	Any waters or wastes containing suspended solids of such character and quantity that unusual attention or expense is required to handle such materials at the sewage treatment plant. 
(9)	Any noxious or malodorous gas or substance capable of creating a public nuisance.
(Ord. No. 39(4),  403, 7-12-1960) 
Sec. 82-250. - Grease, oil, and sand interceptors. 
(a)	Grease, oil, and sand interceptors shall be provided when, in the opinion of the city, they are necessary for the proper handling of liquid wastes containing grease in excessive amounts, or any flammable wastes, sand, and other harmful ingredients; except that such interceptors shall not be required for private living quarters or dwelling units. All interceptors shall be of a type and capacity approved by the city and shall be located as to be readily and easily accessible for cleaning and inspection. 
(b)	Grease and oil interceptors shall be constructed of impervious materials capable of withstanding abrupt and extreme changes in temperature. Grease and oil interceptors shall be of substantial construction, watertight, and equipped with easily removable covers which when bolted in place shall be gastight and watertight. 
(Ord. No. 39(4),  404, 7-12-1960) 
Sec. 82-251. - Maintenance of interceptors. 
    Where installed, all grease, oil and sand interceptors shall be maintained by the owner, at his expense, in continuously efficient operation at all times. 
(Ord. No. 39(4),  405, 7-12-1960) 
Sec. 82-252. - Discharge limitations; plans and specifications of preliminary treatment facilities. 
(a)	The admission into the public sewers of any waters or wastes (i) having a five-day biochemical oxygen demand greater than 300 parts per million by weight, or (ii) containing more than 350 parts per million by weight of suspended solids, or (iii) containing any quantity of substances having the characteristics described in section 82-249, or (iv) having an average daily flow greater than two percent of the average daily sewage flow of the city, shall be subject to the review and approval of the superintendent. Where necessary, in the opinion of the city, the owner shall provide, at his expense, such preliminary treatment as may be necessary to: (i) reduce the biochemical oxygen demand to 300 parts per million and the suspended solids to 350 parts per million by weight, or (ii) reduce objectionable characteristics or constituents to within the maximum limits provided for in section 82-249, or (iii) control the quantities and rates of discharge of such waters or wastes. Plans, specifications, and any other pertinent information relating to proposed preliminary treatment facilities shall be submitted for the approval of the city and of the state water resources commission and no construction of such facilities shall be commenced until such approvals are obtained in writing. 
(b)	Such plans and specifications shall be submitted for approval by the city and the state water resources commission within 30 days after notification of the necessity thereof. In the event that satisfactory plans and specifications are not furnished, or if furnished and construction does not proceed according to agreed upon construction time, the city shall, upon 30-day notice in writing to such person admitting wastes above the approved standards, terminate sewer service to such owner. All costs of termination of service and resumption, after completion of required construction, shall be borne by the owner. 
(Ord. No. 39(4),  406, 7-12-1960; Ord. No. 64,  1, 10-20-1964) 
Sec. 82-253. - Maintenance of preliminary treatment facilities. 
    Where preliminary treatment facilities are provided for any waters or wastes, they shall be maintained continuously in satisfactory and effective operation by the owner at his expense. In the event such preliminary treatment facilities are not maintained continuously in satisfactory and effective operation by the owner, the city may, after notice as provided for in section 82-252, terminate sewer service until proper operation is provided for. 
(Ord. No. 39(4),  407, 7-12-1960; Ord. No. 64,  2, 10-20-1964) 
Sec. 82-254. - Control manhole.
